column1: 0@Gloomhaven@Gloomhaven  is a game of Euro-inspired tactical combat in a persistent world of shifting motives. Players will take on the role of a wandering adventurer with their own special set of skills and their own reasons for traveling to this dark corner of the world. Players must work together out of necessity to clear out menacing dungeons and forgotten ruins. In the process
column2: they will enhance their abilities with experience and loot
column3: discover new locations to explore and plunder
column4:
and expand an ever-branching story fueled by the decisions they make.

This is a game with a persistent and changing world that is ideally played over many game sessions. After a scenario
column5: players will make decisions on what to do
column6: which will determine how the story continues
column7:
kind of like a “Choose Your Own Adventure” book. Playing through a scenario is a cooperative affair where players will fight against automated monsters using an innovative card system to determine the order of play and what a player does on their turn.

Each turn
column8: a player chooses two cards to play out of their hand. The number on the top card determines their initiative for the round. Each card also has a top and bottom power
column9: and when it is a player’s turn in the initiative order
column10: they determine whether to use the top power of one card and the bottom power of the other
column11: or vice-versa. Players must be careful
column12: though
column13: because over time they will permanently lose cards from their hands. If they take too long to clear a dungeon
column14:
they may end up exhausted and be forced to retreat.

@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/sZYp_3BTDGjh2unaZfZmuA__original/img/7d-lj5Gd1e8PFnD97LYFah2c45M=/0x0/filters:format(jpeg)/pic2437871.jpg@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/sZYp_3BTDGjh2unaZfZmuA__thumb/img/veqFeP4d_3zNhFc3GNBkV95rBEQ=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic2437871.jpg@3.8884@120@1@4

column1: 1@Food Chain Magnate@"Lemonade? They want lemonade? What is the world coming to? I want commercials for burgers on all channels
column2: every 15 minutes. We are the Home of the Original Burger
column3: not a hippie health haven. And place a billboard next to that new house on the corner. I want them craving beer every second they sit in their posh new garden." The new management trainee trembles in front of the CEO and tries to politely point out that... "How do you mean
column4: we don't have enough staff? The HR director reports to you. Hire more people! Train them! But whatever you do
column5: don't pay them any real wages. I did not go into business to become poor. And fire that discount manager
column6: she is only costing me money. From now on
column7: we'll sell gourmet burgers. Same crap
column8:
double the price. Get my marketing director in here!"

Food Chain Magnate is a heavy strategy game about building a fast food chain. The focus is on building your company using a card-driven (human) resource management system. Players compete on a variable city map through purchasing
column9: marketing and sales
column10:
and on a job market for key staff members. The game can be played by 2-5 serious gamers in 2-4 hours.

@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/Wtxml94LAXsIWQCxGPS63Q__original/img/9c-MJB6x54vN5eB-1hT4XQaHtP8=/0x0/filters:format(png)/pic2649434.png@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/Wtxml94LAXsIWQCxGPS63Q__thumb/img/LKU2KoMev222qUIKyNqaCF_ZLPY=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic2649434.png@4.2082@240@2@5

column1: 2@Power Grid@Power Grid is the updated release of the Friedemann Friese crayon game Funkenschlag. It removes the crayon aspect from network building in the original edition
column2:
while retaining the fluctuating commodities market like Crude: The Oil Game and an auction round intensity reminiscent of The Princes of Florence.

The objective of Power Grid is to supply the most cities with power when someone's network gains a predetermined size.  In this new edition
column3: players mark pre-existing routes between cities for connection
column4:
and then bid against each other to purchase the power plants that they use to power their cities.

However
column5: as plants are purchased
column6: newer
column7: more efficient plants become available
column8: so by merely purchasing
column9:
you're potentially allowing others access to superior equipment.

Additionally
column10: players must acquire the raw materials (coal
column11: oil
column12: garbage
column13: and uranium) needed to power said plants (except for the 'renewable' windfarm/ solar plants
column14: which require no fuel)
column15:
making it a constant struggle to upgrade your plants for maximum efficiency while still retaining enough wealth to quickly expand your network to get the cheapest routes.

Power Grid FAQ - Please read this before posting a rules question!  Many questions are asked over and over in the forums... If you have a question about a specific expansion
column16:
please check the rules forum or FAQ for that particular expansion.

@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/yd6LuatytHRhcFCxCf-EEg__original/img/OS13C6W4i1XW__wWVVVaqF7BV0c=/0x0/filters:format(jpeg)/pic4459753.jpg@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/yd6LuatytHRhcFCxCf-EEg__thumb/img/jWTonZ5oYNlPzpELKHIJGWSS0Y8=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic4459753.jpg@3.2606@120@2@6

column1: 3@CATAN@In CATAN (formerly The Settlers of Catan)
column2: players try to be the dominant force on the island of Catan by building settlements
column3: cities
column4: and roads. On each turn dice are rolled to determine what resources the island produces. Players build by spending resources (sheep
column5: wheat
column6: wood
column7: brick and ore) that are depicted by these resource cards; each land type
column8: with the exception of the unproductive desert
column9: produces a specific resource: hills produce brick
column10: forests produce wood
column11: mountains produce ore
column12: fields produce wheat
column13:
and pastures produce sheep.

Setup includes randomly placing large hexagonal tiles (each showing a resource or the desert) in a honeycomb shape and surrounding them with water tiles
column14: some of which contain ports of exchange. Number disks
column15: which will correspond to die rolls (two 6-sided dice are used)
column16: are placed on each resource tile. Each player is given two settlements (think: houses) and roads (sticks) which are
column17: in turn
column18:
placed on intersections and borders of the resource tiles. Players collect a hand of resource cards based on which hex tiles their last-placed house is adjacent to. A robber pawn is placed on the desert tile.

A turn consists of possibly playing a development card
column19: rolling the dice
column20: everyone (perhaps) collecting resource cards based on the roll and position of houses (or upgraded cities—think: hotels) unless a 7 is rolled
column21: turning in resource cards (if possible and desired) for improvements
column22: trading cards at a port
column23: and trading resource cards with other players. If a 7 is rolled
column24:
the active player moves the robber to a new hex tile and steals resource cards from other players who have built structures adjacent to that tile.

Points are accumulated by building settlements and cities
column25: having the longest road and the largest army (from some of the development cards)
column26: and gathering certain development cards that simply award victory points. When a player has gathered 10 points (some of which may be held in secret)
column27:
he announces his total and claims the win.

CATAN has won multiple awards and is one of the most popular games in recent history due to its amazing ability to appeal to experienced gamers as well as those new to the hobby.

Die Siedler von Catan was originally published by KOSMOS and has gone through multiple editions. It was licensed by Mayfair and has undergone four editions as The Settlers of Catan. In 2015
column28: it was formally renamed CATAN to better represent itself as the core and base game of the CATAN series. It has been re-published in two travel editions
column29: portable edition and compact edition
column30: as a special gallery edition (replaced in 2009 with a family edition)
column32: as a deluxe 3D collector's edition
column33: in the basic Simply Catan
column35:
and with an entirely new theme in Japan and Asia as Settlers of Catan: Rockman Edition. Numerous spin-offs and expansions have also been made for the game.

@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/W3Bsga_uLP9kO91gZ7H8yw__original/img/xV7oisd3RQ8R-k18cdWAYthHXsA=/0x0/filters:format(jpeg)/pic2419375.jpg@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/W3Bsga_uLP9kO91gZ7H8yw__thumb/img/8a9HeqFydO7Uun_le9bXWPnidcA=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic2419375.jpg@2.3063@120@3@4

column1: 4@Barrage@In the dystopic 1930s
column2: the industrial revolution pushed the exploitation of fossil-based resources to the limit
column3:
and now the only thing powerful enough to quench the thirst for power of the massive machines and of the unstoppable engineering progress is the unlimited hydroelectric energy provided by the rivers.

Barrage is a resource management strategic game in which players compete to build their majestic dams
column4: raise them to increase their storing capacity
column5:
and deliver all the potential power through pressure tunnels connected to the energy turbines of their powerhouses.

Each player represents one of the four international companies who are gathering machinery
column6:
innovative patents and brilliant engineers to claim the best locations to collect and exploit the water of a contested Alpine region crossed by rivers.

Barrage includes two innovative and challenging mechanisms. First
column7: the players must carefully plan their actions and handle their machinery
column8: since both their action tokens and resources are stored on a Construction Wheel and will only be available after a full turn of the wheel. The better you manage your wheel
column9:
the earlier your resources and actions come back to you.

Second
column10: the water flow on the rivers depicted on the board is a shared and contested resource. Players have to intercept and store as much of the water as they can
column11: build dams (upstream dams are expensive but can block part of the water before it reaches the downstream dams)
column12: raise the dams to increase their capacity
column13: and build long tunnels to channel the water to their powerhouses. Water is never consumed — its flow is just used to produce energy —
column14: it is instead released back to the rivers
column15:
so you have to strategically place your dams to recover the water diverted by you and the other players.

Over five rounds
column16: the players must fulfill power requirements represented by a common competitive power track and meet specific requests of personal contracts. At the same time
column17: by placing a limited number of engineers
column18:
they attempt to enhance their machinery to acquire new and more efficient construction actions and to build and activate special unique-effect buildings to forward their own developing strategy.

@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/jEPmWvvYpqkWrKOzqIHFsg__original/img/rkHKwkUqpQC7PAGG7n2gbrcQiUY=/0x0/filters:format(png)/pic4336469.png@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/jEPmWvvYpqkWrKOzqIHFsg__thumb/img/kMLIpeqA6UcUvQg2AdMwwQoEIfU=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic4336469.png@4.0685@120@1@4

column1: 5@Sleeping Gods@"Are the stars unfamiliar here?" she asked
column2: and the sky grew suddenly dark
column3: the star's patterns alien and exotic. "This is the Wandering Sea. The gods have brought you here
column4:
and you must wake them if you wish to return home."

In Sleeping Gods
column5: you and up to 3 friends become Captain Sofi Odessa and her crew
column6: lost in a strange world in 1929 on your steamship
column7: the Manticore. You must work together to survive
column8: exploring exotic islands
column9: meeting new characters
column10:
and seeking out the totems of the gods so that you can return home.

Sleeping Gods is a campaign game. Each session can last as long as you want. When you are ready to take a break
column11: you mark your progress on a journey log sheet
column12: making it easy to return to the same place in the game the next time you play. You can play solo or with friends throughout your campaign. It's easy to swap players in and out at will. Your goal is to find at least fourteen totems hidden throughout the world. Like reading a book
column13: you'll complete this journey one or two hours at a time
column14: discovering new lands
column15: stories
column16:
and challenges along the way.

Sleeping Gods is an atlas game. Each page of the atlas represents only a small portion of the world you can explore. When you reach the edge of a page and you want to continue in the same direction
column17:
you simply turn to a new page and sail onward.

Sleeping Gods is a storybook game. Each new location holds wild adventure
column18: hidden treasures
column19: and vivid characters. Your choices affect the characters and the plot of the game
column20:
and may help or hinder your chances of getting home!

Welcome to a vast world. Your journey starts now.

—description from the publisher

column1:
6@Cosmic Encounter@Build a galactic empire...

In the depths of space
column2: the alien races of the Cosmos vie with each other for control of the universe. Alliances form and shift from moment to moment
column3:
while cataclysmic battles send starships screaming into the warp.

This classic game of alien politics returns from the warp once more!

In Cosmic Encounter
column4: each player becomes the leader of one of dozens of alien races
column5: each with its own unique power. On a player's turn
column6:
he or she becomes the offense. The offense encounters another player on a planet by moving a group of his or her ships through the hyperspace gate to that planet. Both sides can invite allies and play cards to try and tip the encounter in their favor.

The object of the game is to establish colonies in other players' planetary systems. The winner(s) are the first player(s) to have five colonies on any planets outside his or her home system. These colonies may all be in one system or scattered over multiple systems. The players must use force
column7: cunning
column8: and diplomacy to ensure their victory. And
column9: because alliances are a key part of the game
column10:
multiple players can win together!

column1:
7@Agricola@Description from BoardgameNews

In Agricola
column2: you're a farmer in a wooden shack with your spouse and little else. On a turn
column3: you get to take only two actions
column4: one for you and one for the spouse
column5: from all the possibilities you'll find on a farm: collecting clay
column6: wood
column7: or stone; building fences; and so on. You might think about having kids in order to get more work accomplished
column8:
but first you need to expand your house. And what are you going to feed all the little rugrats?

The game supports many levels of complexity
column9: mainly through the use (or non-use) of two of its main types of cards
column10: Minor Improvements and Occupations. In the beginner's version (called the Family Variant in the U.S. release)
column11: these cards are not used at all. For advanced play
column12: the U.S. release includes three levels of both types of cards; Basic (E-deck)
column13: Interactive (I-deck)
column14: and Complex (K-deck)
column15:
and the rulebook encourages players to experiment with the various decks and mixtures thereof. Aftermarket decks such as the Z-Deck and the L-Deck also exist.

Agricola is a turn-based game. There are 14 game rounds occurring in 6 stages
column16: with a Harvest at the end of each stage (after Rounds 4
column21:
and 14).
Each player starts with two playing tokens (farmer and spouse) and thus can take two turns
column22: or actions
column23: per round. There are multiple options
column24: and while the game progresses
column25: you'll have more and more: first thing in a round
column26:
a new action card is flipped over.
Problem: Each action can be taken by only one player each round
column27:
so it's important to do some things with high preference.
Each player also starts with a hand of 7 Occupation cards (of more than 160 total) and 7 Minor Improvement cards (of more than 140 total) that he/she may use during the game if they fit in his/her strategy. Speaking of which
column28: there are countless strategies
column29: some depending on your card hand. Sometimes it's a good choice to stay on course
column30:
and sometimes it is better to react to your opponents' actions...

@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/dDDo2Hexl80ucK1IlqTk-g__original/img/toobKoejPiHpfpHk4SYd1UAJafw=/0x0/filters:format(jpeg)/pic831744.jpg@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/dDDo2Hexl80ucK1IlqTk-g__thumb/img/GHGdnCfeysoP_34gLnofJcNivW8=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic831744.jpg@3.637@150@1@5

column1: 8@The Crew: The Quest for Planet Nine@In the co-operative trick-taking game The Crew: The Quest for Planet Nine
column2:
the players set out as astronauts on an uncertain space adventure. What are the rumors regarding the unknown planet about? The eventful journey through space extends over 50 exciting missions. But this game can only be defeated by meeting common individual tasks of each player. In order to meet the varied challenges communication is essential in the team. But this is more difficult than expected in space.

With each mission the game becomes more difficult. After each mission the game can be paused and continued later. During each mission it is not the number of tricks but the right tricks at the right time that count.

The team completes a mission only if every single player is successful in fulfilling their tasks.

The game comes with 50 missions
column3:
with three additional missions published in spielbox 2/2020.

@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/98LnQShydr11OBKS46xY-Q__original/img/Q-ZkgnuBu9OTBr7J3qnqPjqamAE=/0x0/filters:format(jpeg)/pic5687013.jpg@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/98LnQShydr11OBKS46xY-Q__thumb/img/et-fnuozyOdBOVL-5kSS3_7I8fw=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic5687013.jpg@1.9735@20@2@5

column1: 9@Oath: Chronicles of Empire and Exile@In Oath
column2: one to six players guide the course of history in an ancient land. Players might take the role of agents bolstering the old order or scheme to bring the kingdom to ruin. The consequences of one game will ripple through those that follow
column3:
changing what resources and actions future players may have at their disposal and even altering the game's core victory condition.

If a player seizes control by courting anarchy and distrust
column4: future players will have to contend with a land overrun by thieves and petty warlords. In a later game
column5: a warlord might attempt to found a dynasty
column6: creating a line of rulers that might last generations or be crushed by the rise of a terrible
column7:
arcane cult.

In Oath
column8: there are no fancy production tricks
column9:
app-assisted mechanisms or production gimmicks. The game can be reset at any time and doesn't require the same play group from one game to the next. A player might use the fully-featured solo mode to play several generations during the week and then use that same copy of the game for Saturday game-night with friends. There are no scripted narratives or predetermined end points. The history embedded in each copy of Oath will grow to be as unique as the players who helped build it.

—description from the publisher

@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/gTxav_KKQK1rDg-XuCjCSA__original/img/lG-iXVzDlfFrD6VPggvg2WQ7228=/0x0/filters:format(jpeg)/pic5164812.jpg@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/gTxav_KKQK1rDg-XuCjCSA__thumb/img/tFTOAKG5aDXxYfNRmJNmfyxH83M=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic5164812.jpg@4.0588@150@1@6

column1: 10@Argent: The Consortium@The time has come for the selection of a new Chancellor at Argent University of Magic
column2: and you are among the likely candidates for the job. Gather your apprentices
column3: ready your spellbook
column4: and build your influence
column5:
while secretly discovering and competing over the votes of a limited Consortium of influential board members. Only the one who is able to fulfill the most criteria will claim the title of most influential mage in the World of Indines!

Argent: The Consortium is a cutthroat worker-placement/engine-building game of manipulation and secrecy in which the criteria for victory are secret and the capabilities of your opponents are constantly changing. You'll need to outwit the other candidates
column6: use your spells at the right moment
column7:
and choose the correct apprentices to manage your plan.

Argent: The Consortium is a European-style game that minimizes luck and focuses on player interaction and strong core mechanisms that allow new strategies to emerge each time you play.

The designer keeps an updated Official Errata/Typo/FAQ thread on BGG.

column8: and a story-driven campaign
column9: each mission will be unique
column10: putting your teamwork
column11: programming
column12:
and piloting skills to the test.

There are ten missions in total

column14: four command lines (one for each player)

column1: 12@Chinatown@This is a negotiation game in the truest sense of the word. In it
column2: players acquire ownership of sections of city blocks then place tiles
column3: representing businesses
column4: onto the block-sections.  At the end of each turn
column5: each tile you've laid gives you some sort of payout
column6: but completed businesses (formed of three to six connected tiles of the same type) pay quite a bit better.  All these resources are dealt to the players randomly
column7: however
column8:
so players must trade to get matching businesses and adjacent locations.

This game is #2 in the Alea big box series.

column1: 13@So Clover!@So Clover! is a cooperative word-association game. Play as a team to get the highest score. Get Keywords and secretly write their common features on your Clover board; these are your Clues. Then work together to try to figure out each player’s Keywords. At the end of the game
column2:
add up your score according to how many Keywords you found and write it in the Record of Legends. Try to beat your high score each game!

-description from the publisher

column1:
14@Street Masters@THE GAMEPLAY

Street Masters is a 1-4 player cooperative miniatures board game inspired by classic fighting video games. Featuring over 65 highly detailed miniatures
column2: unique decks for fighters & enemies
column3: custom dice
column4: and lightning-fast gameplay
column5: Street Masters lets players match up powerful fighters against villainous organizations in a wide array of exciting scenarios. Designed by Adam Sadler and Brady Sadler
column6:
the game offers modular and elegant gameplay set in a unique and exciting world of brutal combat.

THE STORY

Warriors from around the world
column7: known for their legendary fighting abilities and skills
column8: receive mysterious invitations to participate in a martial arts tournament. During the tournament
column9: the organization surrounding it reveals their true identity — The Kingdom — and their purpose to recruit fighters to join their militia or enslave those against them. While several of these warriors made it out in time
column10:
many were never heard from again.

Five years later
column11: a government project called "Street Masters" initiates in order to counter-act the war against The Kingdom
column12: now having divided and seized control over the world by several of its factions. Those who join the Street Masters project must work together to take down each faction
column13:
crippling parts of The Kingdom before they're able to launch their end game.

@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/ieUOjJ9WKW7G0-XUtrBBBA__original/img/hicYEXqmD5H9JwQ6gLHTXx-bACQ=/0x0/filters:format(jpeg)/pic4194059.jpg@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/ieUOjJ9WKW7G0-XUtrBBBA__thumb/img/uie9pFWxdRuCO1zmNaCIHPdXLes=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic4194059.jpg@2.8293@120@1@4

column1: 15@Dominion (Second Edition)@"You are a monarch
column2: like your parents before you
column3: a ruler of a small pleasant kingdom of rivers and evergreens. Unlike your parents
column4: however
column5: you have hopes and dreams! You want a bigger and more pleasant kingdom
column6: with more rivers and a wider variety of trees. You want a Dominion! In all directions lie fiefs
column7: freeholds
column8: and feodums. All are small bits of land
column9: controlled by petty lords and verging on anarchy. You will bring civilization to these people
column10:
uniting them under your banner.

"But wait! It must be something in the air; several other monarchs have had the exact same idea. You must race to get as much of the unclaimed land as possible
column11: fending them off along the way. To do this you will hire minions
column12: construct buildings
column13: spruce up your castle
column14: and fill the coffers of your treasury. Your parents wouldn't be proud
column15: but your grandparents
column16: on your mother's side
column17:
would be delighted.'"'

In Dominion
column18: each player starts with an identical
column19: very small deck of cards. In the center of the table is a selection of other cards the players can "buy" as they can afford them. Through their selection of cards to buy and how they play their hands as they draw them
column20: the players construct their deck on the fly
column21:
striving for the most efficient path to the precious victory points by game end.

Dominion is not a collectible card game (CCG)
column22:
but the play of the game is similar to the construction and play of a CCG deck. The game comes with 500 cards. You select 10 of the 26 Kingdom card types to include in any given play—leading to immense variety.

Dominion (Second Edition) replaces six Kingdom card types from the first edition with six new types of Kingdom cards
column23: while also replacing the blank cards in the game with a seventh new Kingdom card. These new cards are available on their own in the Dominion: Update Pack. The rulebook has been rewritten
column24: three cards have mild functional changes ("you may" added to Moneylender
column25: Mine
column26: Throne Room)
column27:
and other cards have been rephrased (while remaining functionally the same).

Dominion: Update Pack contains the seven new kingdom cards introduced in the second edition of Dominion
column28:
thereby allowing owners of the first edition to obtain these new cards without needing to repurchase the entire game.

column1: 16@Battlestar Galactica: The Board Game@Battlestar Galactica: The Board Game is an exciting game of mistrust
column2: intrigue
column3: and the struggle for survival. Based on the epic and widely-acclaimed Sci Fi Channel series
column4: Battlestar Galactica: The Board Game puts players in the role of one of ten of their favorite characters from the show. Each playable character has their own abilities and weaknesses
column5: and must all work together in order for humanity to have any hope of survival. However
column6: one or more players in every game secretly side with the Cylons. Players must attempt to expose the traitor while fuel shortages
column7: food contaminations
column8:
and political unrest threatens to tear the fleet apart.

After the Cylon attack on the Colonies
column9: the battered remnants of the human race are on the run
column10: constantly searching for the next signpost on the road to Earth. They face the threat of Cylon attack from without
column11: and treachery and crisis from within. Humanity must work together if they are to have any hope of survival…but how can they
column12: when any of them may
column13: in fact
column14:
be a Cylon agent?

Battlestar Galactica: The Board Game is a semi-cooperative game for 3-6 players ages 10 and up that can be played in 2-3 hours. Players choose from pilots
column15: political leaders
column16: military leaders
column17: or engineers to crew Galactica. They are also dealt a loyalty card at the start of the game to determine if they are a human or Cylon along with an assortment of skill cards based on their characters abilities. Players then can move and take actions either on Galactica
column18: on Colonial 1
column19: or in a Viper. They need to collect skill cards
column20: fend off Cylon ships
column21: and keep Galactica and the fleet jumping. Each turn also brings a Crisis Card
column22: various tasks that players must overcome. Players need to play matching skill cards to fend off the problems; skill cards that don't match hinder the players success. Fate could be working against the crew
column23: or there could be a traitorous Cylon! As players get closer and closer towards reaching their Earth
column24: another round of loyalty cards are passed out and more Cylons may turn up. If players can keep their up their food stores
column25: fuel levels
column26: ship morale
column27: and population
column28: and they can keep Galactica in one piece long enough to make it to Earth
column29: the Humans win the game. But if the Cylon players reveal themselves at the right moment and bring down Galactica
column30:
the Humans have lost.

column1:
17@Empire Builder@Epic Railroad Building in North America

Discover a modern North American classic.  Celebrate one of our most vital and enduring passions: railroads.  Use your initial investment to build track.  Then pick up commodities where they are grown
column2: mined
column3: or manufactured and deliver them to a lucrative place of demand.  Complete a delivery and make the money you need to buy larger
column4: faster trains
column5:
and expand your railroad empire.  Win the game by building the most effective railroad empire!

The original and flagship of Mayfair's crayon-rails line allows players
column6: using washable crayons
column7: to draw their train routes over a map of North America.  Players start with an initial sum of money which they use to build short lengths of track during their first couple of turns.  For the rest of the game
column8: players operate their trains over the track network drawn on the board to pick up and deliver loads to various cities
column9: and then have the opportunity to add to their track network or improve their train.  The game uses demand cards which list three demands
column10:
each of a commodity to be delivered to a specified city for a given payoff.  Each player has three demand cards to provide opportunities for income.

Each turn consists of an operations phase and a building phase.  During the operations phase
column11: trains are moved to cities where commodities are picked up at no cost and moved to one of the cities on that player's demand cards.  When the commodity is delivered
column12:
the player receives the payoff and trades that demand card for a new one.  Event cards are mixed in the deck with the demand cards.  When an event card is drawn the instructions are followed.  During the building phase a player may pay to build more track or upgrade his train.

A player wins by being the first to connect his track network to six of the seven major cities on the board and acquire $250
column14:
000 in cash on hand.

column1: 18@Kingdom Death: Monster@Kingdom Death: Monster is a fully cooperative tabletop hobby game experience.  Set in a unique nightmarish world devoid of most natural resources
column2: you control a settlement at the dawn of its existence. Fight monsters
column3: craft weapons and gear
column4:
and develop your settlement to ensure your survival from generation to generation.

Campaign System
Embark alone or with up to 3 friends (5 with game variant) on a 5-30-lantern-year campaign
column5: with each year consisting of a cycle of hunt
column6: showdown
column7: and settlement phases. The settlement phase is an intricate civilization building game in which you spend very limited resources to build buildings
column8: research new technologies
column9: train your warriors
column10: and set up your strategy for survival.  During the hunt
column11: you'll encounter a series of stories in a "choose your own adventure" style journey through various events and encounters.  Finally
column12: when you meet the monster you're pursuing
column13: you'll engage it in an a massive arena-style battle where only one party is going to survive.  If your party lives
column14:
you'll be able to bring the spoils back home to use in expanding your settlement.

Monster AI System
Each of the 7 monsters included are controlled by their own pair of decks that scale to 3 levels of difficulty (except for the final encounter
column15: which has only 1 level and it's HARD!). Every encounter
column16: even with the same monster
column17:
is highly variable and no two showdowns will resolve the same way. Players will have to plan their gear and keep their minds sharp to prevail.

Gear System
In Kingdom Death: Monster
column18: survivors will craft gear from resources earned from defeating monsters or found on their hunt. Each survivor has a 3x3 gear grid. Selection and arrangement of your gear cards is critical
column19:
as many provided bonuses and activate special rules when aligned correctly.

Story Event System
40+ Story Events plus over 100 hunt encounters will shape and guide your campaign. Story Events detail important evolutions in your civilization
column20: introduce new monsters
column21: and provide rich detail for your campaign.  Some will trigger automatically as you progress through the campaign
column22:
but most will be entirely based on choices players make.

Story Events cover everything from setting up and fighting a monster to key events that happen within the overall story. Some are triggered directly from the timeline and others from choices you make in game.

column1: 19@Decrypto@Players compete in two teams in Decrypto
column2:
with each trying to correctly interpret the coded messages presented to them by their teammates while cracking the codes they intercept from the opposing team.

In more detail
column3: each team has their own screen
column4: and in this screen they tuck four cards in pockets numbered 1-4
column5: letting everyone on the same team see the words on these cards while hiding the words from the opposing team. In the first round
column6: each team does the following: One team member takes a code card that shows three of the digits 1-4 in some order
column7: e.g.
column8: 4-2-1. They then give a coded message that their teammates must use to guess this code. For example
column9: if the team's four words are "pig"
column10: "candy"
column11: "tent"
column12: and "son"
column13: then I might say "Sam-striped-pink" and hope that my teammates can correctly map those words to 4-2-1. If they guess correctly
column14: great; if not
column15:
we receive a black mark of failure.

Starting in the second round
column16: a member of each team must again give a clue about their words to match a numbered code. If I get 2-4-3
column17: I might now say
column18: "sucker-prince-stake". The other team then attempts to guess our numbered code. If they're correct
column19: they receive a white mark of success; if not
column20:
then my team must guess the number correctly or take a black mark of failure. (Guessing correctly does nothing except avoid failure and give the opposing team information about what our hidden words might be.)

The rounds continue until a team collects either its second white mark (winning the game) or its second black mark (losing the game). Games typically last between 4-7 rounds. If neither team has won after eight rounds
column21:
then each team must attempt to guess the other team's words; whichever team guesses more words correctly wins.

column1: 20@Glass Road@The game Glass Road commemorates the 700-year-old tradition of glass-making in the Bavarian Forest. (Today
column2: the "Glass Road" is a route through the Bavarian forest that takes visitors to many of the old glass houses and museums of that region.) You must skillfully manage your glass and brick production in order to build the right structures that help you keep your business flowing. Cut the forest to keep the fires burning in the ovens
column3: and spread and remove ponds
column4: pits
column5:
and groves to supply yourself with the items you need. Fifteen specialists are there at your side to carry out your orders...

In more detail
column6: the game consists of four building periods. Each player has an identical set of fifteen specialist cards
column7: and each specialist comes with two abilities. At the beginning of each building period
column8: you choose a hand of five specialists. If during this building period
column9: you play a specialist that no other player has in hand
column10: you may use both abilities on that card; if two or more players play the same specialist
column11: each of them may use only one of the two abilities. Exploiting the abilities of these specialists lets you collect resources
column12: lay out new landscape tiles (e.g.
column13: ponds and pits)
column14: and build a variety of buildings
column15:
which come in three types:


    Processing buildings
    "Immediate" buildings with a one-time effect 
    Buildings that provide bonus points at the end of the game for various accomplishments


Mastering the balance of knowing the best specialist card to play and being flexible about when you play it — together with assembling a clever combination of buildings — is the key to this game.

The 2021 edition of Glass Road includes previously released promotional material: the Oktoberfest and Adventskalender tiles and the Harlekin card for use in the solitaire version of the game.

column1:
22@Fields of Arle@Welcome to Arle
In Fields of Arle
column2: created by Uwe Rosenberg
column3: one to two players live as farmers in the small and peaceful town of Arle in East Frisia. The flax grown in the land surrounding the village makes it a profitable place to work and live. Fields of Arle takes players through four and a half years of this era of prosperity
column4: with different opportunities available as the seasons change. Farm the land to capitalize on the demand for flax
column5:
or find other ways to make the most of the small town’s prosperity.

Work the Land
Whether you delve into flax farming or leverage other areas of expertise
column6: always make sure that you have the land to build up your village. Construct dikes to keep the waters at bay and expand your fields. Dry out bogs to harvest peat and then clear the land for cultivation. Create more fields for your livestock
column7: buildings
column8: or future crops; after that
column9: you can decide whether to house animals or cultivate a forest for timber. Perhaps you’d like to take up some flax farming for yourself
column10:
or diversify and try out a little bit of everything.

Tools of the Trade
At the outset of each half year
column11: you’ll choose how you’d like to spend that time working. There are many ways to build your fortune. Use the Master space to increase the tools at your disposal
column12: focus on the Cattle Trainer to make the most of your livestock
column13: or build up your fleet of vehicles and ship out goods. Taking stock of your progress differs depending on the season. You may milk your existing livestock or care for a bunch of newborn animals. You could harvest your flax in the fall
column14: and sheer your sheep in spring. At the end of each half year
column15: you’ll need to take stock of your progress by unloading your vehicles and feeding your family and animals
column16:
so keep an eye on the season and do your best to keep the farm growing and everyone well fed!

Travel and Prosper
Once you’ve made headway in clearing fields and stocking up goods

column18: the more goods you can ship. Send things into the wide world to increase your Travel Experience and grant you points over the course of the four and a half years of the game. Build up your farm and your vehicles and get your goods out into the world to make the most of every season. There are many roads to success in Fields of Arle

column1: 23@1829@1829 was the first of the 18xx series. First published in the mid-'70s it was way ahead of its time. The game works by alternating stock dealing rounds and operating rounds. Stock dealing rounds allow players to buy shares in the available railway companies. Operating rounds allow the presidents of those companies to build track
column2:
run trains & generate revenue for shareholders.

This basic system has been much copied and is an integral part of all 18xx games.

The original board covered the southern half of Britain
column3:
from the south coast to Darlington. In 1981 a northern board was published covering northern Britain & Scotland.

Where 1829 differs from most others in the 18xx series is the means by which track is laid. Companies each have a token on the board called a Survey Party. Track is laid by moving the company's Survey token and placing a track tile in the area just vacated... if it is still vacant. This mechanism was discarded in the later 18xx titles
column4: and creates much more of a tactical tile-laying game. It also slows down the game
column5:
and 1829 is one of the longer 18xx titles. A typical game can take anything from 4 to 10 hours to play.

In 1994 Francis Tresham published 1825
column6: which is largely a modular version of 1829 with simpler rules and a few other enhancements. It plays quite differently from 1829
column7: though
column8:
as 1829 was always about competition for routes.

The board gaming hobby has in its history a few landmark games
column9: which redefine a part of board games in general
column10:
or even spawn an entire genre. 1829 is just such a landmark.

Expanded By:

    MSK 1 Extension Kit for 1829 (Northern & Southern Boards)
    MSK 2 Extension Kit for 1829 (Southern & Northern boards)
    MSK 3 Extension Kit for 1829 (Northern & Southern Boards)
    MSK 5 Extension Kit for 1829 (Northern & Southern Boards)
    MSK 6 Extension Kit for 1829 (Northern & Southern Boards)
    1829 Conversion Kit
    1829 Northern Board

column1: 24@Le Havre@In Le Havre

column10:

column1: 29@Stone Age@The "Stone Age" times were hard indeed. In their roles as hunters
column2: collectors
column3: farmers
column4: and tool makers
column5: our ancestors worked with their legs and backs straining against wooden plows in the stony earth. Of course
column6:
progress did not stop with the wooden plow. People always searched for better tools and more productive plants to make their work more effective.

In Stone Age
column7: the players live in this time
column8: just as our ancestors did. They collect wood
column9: break stone and wash their gold from the river. They trade freely
column10: expand their village and so achieve new levels of civilization. With a balance of luck and planning
column11:
the players compete for food in this pre-historic time.

Players use up to ten tribe members each in three phases. In the first phase
column12: players place their men in regions of the board that they think will benefit them
column13: including the hunt
column14: the trading center
column15: or the quarry. In the second phase
column16: the starting player activates each of their staffed areas in whatever sequence they choose
column17: followed in turn by the other players. In the third phase
column18: players must have enough food available to feed their populations
column19:
or they face losing resources or points.

@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/elmZegVZ6gp4_5izUgxGQQ__original/img/cR92Dm6yQ3Lgxt1yR81zUb0ooqQ=/0x0/filters:format(jpeg)/pic1632539.jpg@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/elmZegVZ6gp4_5izUgxGQQ__thumb/img/MXq3DEKWIozO-PmB4S64BiE5fd0=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic1632539.jpg@2.4667@90@2@4

column1: 30@Obsession@You are the head of a respected but troubled family estate in mid-19th century Victorian England. After several lean decades
column2:
family fortunes are looking up! Your goal is to improve your estate so as to be in better standing with the truly influential families in Derbyshire.

Obsession is a game of 16 to 20 turns in which players build a deck of Victorian gentry (British social upper class)
column3: renovate their estate by acquiring building tiles from a centralized builders' market
column4: and manipulate an extensive service staff of butlers
column5: housekeepers
column6: underbutlers
column7: maids
column8: valets
column9: and footmen utilizing a novel worker placement mechanic. Successfully hosting prestigious social activities such as Fox Hunts
column10: Music Recitals
column11: Billiards
column12: Political Debates
column13: and Grand Balls increases a player's wealth
column14: reputation
column15:
and connections among the elite.

Each turn
column16: players choose a building tile representing a room or outdoor space in and around their 19th century British country house. The tile chosen dictates the event that can be hosted and the guests to be invited. Players must carefully plan
column17: however
column18: to have the proper staff available to service the event and support guests as needed. The reward for success is new investment opportunities
column19: permitting further renovation of the estate (acquisition of more valuable/powerful building tiles)
column20: an increase in reputation in the county
column21: an expanding circle of influential acquaintances
column22:
and a larger and highly-trained domestic staff.

Throughout the game
column23:
a competitive courtship for the hand of the most eligible young gentleman and lady in the county presents specific renovation and reputation objectives. The player who best meets these objectives while accumulating victory points will win the hand of the wealthy love interest and the game.

—description from the publisher

@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/sy89BiuZXfbSnG7Cag9tBQ__original/img/uArsqbWyUALa982zGWsy8QQWnjE=/0x0/filters:format(png)/pic5902073.png@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/sy89BiuZXfbSnG7Cag9tBQ__thumb/img/eTnMwfCC2jCGDPXC08SIaMXNOTM=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic5902073.png@3.1171@90@1@4

column1: 31@Age of Steam@Steam-belching iron horses roar across the wild plains! Age of Steam relives the era when pioneering U.S. railroads built the tracks that transformed America's economy. The cut-throat action is centered on the industrial powerhouses of the growing nation: Pittsburgh
column2: Cincinnati
column3: Chicago
column4:
and beyond.

Challenges that await you:


     Can you finance both the most extensive track network and the most powerful locomotives?
     Which routes will give the best returns on their costs?
     Can you beat the opposition to the most lucrative shipments?
     Will you make enough money to pay your aggressive creditors?


Competition is brutal
column5:
with the game usually going to the player who plans most carefully.

Each self-contained phase in the game keeps players constantly involved in making vital decisions and interacting with other players. Age of Steam also allows towns to be developed into cities
column6:
ensuring that no two games are exactly the same.

See also Age of Steam FAQ

column1:
32@Res Arcana@Prepare Your Place of Power!

In a high tower
column2: an Alchemist prepares potions
column3: using vials filled with otherworldly fluids. In a sacred grove
column4: a Druid grinds herbs for a mystical ritual. In the catacombs
column5:
a Necromancer summons a bone dragon... Welcome to the world of Res Arcana!

In it
column6: Life
column7: Death
column8: Elan
column9: Calm
column10: and Gold are the essences that fuel the art of magic. Choose your mage
column11: gather essences
column12: craft unique artifacts
column13: and use them to summon dragons
column14: conquer places of power
column15:
and achieve victory!

A game typically lasts 4-6 rounds. In each round
column16:
players do these steps:


    Collect essences: performs  any Collect abilities
column17:
and may take essences from components.
    Do actions
column18: 1 per turn
column19: clockwise from the First Player: place an artifact
column20: claim a monument or Place of Power
column21: discard a card for 1 Gold or any 2 other essences
column22: use a power on a straightened component
column23:
or pass: exchange magic items and draw 1 card. Play continues until all players have passed.
    Pass procedure: If you are first to pass

column25: swap your magic item for a different magic item
column26:
draw 1 card.
    Check victory points (10+ VPs). If no one has won: straighten all turned components

and begin the next round.

column1: 33@The Resistance@The Empire must fall. Our mission must succeed. By destroying their key bases
column2: we will shatter Imperial strength and liberate our people. Yet spies have infiltrated our ranks
column3:
ready for sabotage. We must unmask them. In five nights we reshape destiny or die trying. We are the Resistance!

The Resistance is a party game of social deduction. It is designed for five to ten players
column4: lasts about 30 minutes
column5: and has no player elimination. The Resistance is inspired by Mafia/Werewolf
column6: yet it is unique in its core mechanics
column7: which increase the resources for informed decisions
column8: intensify player interaction
column9:
and eliminate player elimination.

Players are either Resistance Operatives or Imperial Spies. For three to five rounds
column10: they must depend on each other to carry out missions against the Empire. At the same time
column11: they must try to deduce the other players’ identities and gain their trust. Each round begins with discussion. When ready
column12: the Leader entrusts sets of Plans to a certain number of players (possibly including himself/herself). Everyone votes on whether or not to approve the assignment. Once an assignment passes
column13: the chosen players secretly decide to Support or Sabotage the mission. Based on the results
column14: the mission succeeds (Resistance win) or fails (Empire win). When a team wins three missions
column15:
they have won the game.

Rule Correction:

For first printing (2010 purchases)
column16: the expansion rules should read: "Games of 5-6 players use 7 plot cards
column17: games with 7+ players use all 15 Plot Cards." and "...each Round
column18: the leader draws Plot cards (1 for 5-6 players
column19: 2 for 7-8 players
column20:
and 3 for 9-10 players)" - This has been corrected in the subsequent printings.

column1: 34@Azul@Introduced by the Moors
column2: azuleijos (originally white and blue ceramic tiles) were fully embraced by the Portuguese when their king Manuel I
column3: on a visit to the Alhambra palace in Southern Spain
column4: was mesmerized by the stunning beauty of the Moorish decorative tiles. The king
column5: awestruck by the interior beauty of the Alhambra
column6: immediately ordered that his own palace in Portugal be decorated with similar wall tiles. As a tile-laying artist
column7:
you have been challenged to embellish the walls of the Royal Palace of Evora.

In the game Azul
column8: players take turns drafting colored tiles from suppliers to their player board. Later in the round
column9:
players score points based on how they've placed their tiles to decorate the palace. Extra points are scored for specific patterns and completing sets; wasted supplies harm the player's score. The player with the most points at the end of the game wins.

column1:
35@Star Realms@Star Realms is a spaceship combat deck-building game by Magic Hall of Famers Darwin Kastle (The Battle for Hill 218) and Rob Dougherty (Ascension Co-designer).

Star Realms is a fast paced deck-building card game of outer space combat. It combines the fun of a deck-building game with the interactivity of Trading Card Game style combat. As you play
column2: you make use of Trade to acquire new Ships and Bases from the cards being turned face up in the Trade Row from the Trade Deck. You use the Ships and Bases you acquire to either generate more Trade or to generate Combat to attack your opponent and their bases. When you reduce your opponent’s score (called Authority) to zero
column3:
you win!

Multiple decks of Star Realms and/or Star Realms: Colony Wars
column4: one for every two people
column5: allows up to six players to play a variety of scenarios. Also
column6: in the newest version
column7: there are new ways to play that allow up to 6 players with modes like Boss
column8: Hunter
column9: and Free for All. You can also add Star Realms Colony Wars to the deck to make it 4 players. This is the first game of the Star Realms series. When you play Star Realms
column10: you will be able to acquire and use Ships and Bases of any and all of the four factions. Many cards have powerful Ally abilities that reward you for using Ships and Bases of the same faction together
column11:
however.

As you acquire cards using Trade
column12: you put them into your discard pile
column13: to be later shuffled into your personal deck. When you draw Ships
column14: you do what they say and they get placed into your discard pile at the end of your turn. When you draw a Base
column15: you play it face up in front of you and may use its abilities once every turn. In addition to Combat being the way you reduce your opponent’s Authority to zero and win the game
column16:
it’s also useful for destroying your opponent’s Bases. Some Bases are designated as Outposts. Your opponent’s Outposts must be destroyed before you can use Combat to attack your opponent’s Authority directly.

Star Realms is easy to learn
column17: especially if you’re familiar with deck-building games
column18: but it’s a game that takes time to master. Each time you play
column19: the game is filled with various strategic decision points. Should I take the best card for me or the best card for my opponent? Should I focus on taking cards of a particular faction or on taking the best card available? Should I be focusing on acquiring more Trade or more Combat? Should I attack my opponent’s Base or their Authority? These are just some of the many choices you’ll be faced with. New players needn’t agonize over these choices just to play
column20: but as they become more advanced players
column21:
they will find this depth of strategy leads to great replayability.

@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/EsJqPL5CB_TMt0MYL-lnVg__original/img/QXgamCDRuBoRJyU1PQjeh58Pvr8=/0x0/filters:format(jpeg)/pic1903816.jpg@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/EsJqPL5CB_TMt0MYL-lnVg__thumb/img/s_CE1b1XXUnYj9auTPhLrvkNsYA=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic1903816.jpg@1.9333@20@2@2

column1: 36@The Isle of Cats@The Isle of Cats is a competitive
column2: medium-weight
column3: card-drafting
column4:
polyomino cat-placement board game for 1-4 players (6 with expansions).

In the game
column5: you are citizens of Squalls End on a rescue mission to The Isle of Cats and must rescue as many cats as possible before the evil Lord Vesh arrives. Each cat is represented by a unique tile and belongs to a family
column6:
you must find a way to make them all fit on your boat while keeping families together. You will also need to manage resources as you:


     Explore the island (by drafting cards)
     Rescue cats
     Find treasures
     Befriend Oshax
     Study ancient lessons


Each lesson you collect gives you another personal way of scoring points
column7: and 38 unique lessons are available. Complete lessons
column8: fill your boat
column9: and keep cat families together to score points
column10:
and the player with the most points after five rounds wins.

Note: The Isle of Cats: Kickstarter Edition is a compilation item consisting of The Isle of Cats base game and The Isle of Cats: Kickstarter Pack
column11:
each of which are available as separate items and listed individually in the BGG database.

column1:
37@The Gallerist@This age of art and capitalism has created a need for a new occupation - The Gallerist.

Combining the elements of an Art dealer
column2: museum curator
column3: and Artists’ manager
column4: you are about to take on that job! You will promote and nurture Artists; buy
column5: display
column6: and sell their Art; and build and exert your international reputation. As a result
column7:
you will achieve the respect needed to draw visitors to your Gallery from all over the world.

There's a lot of work to be done
column8: but don't worry
column9:
you can hire assistants to help you achieve your goals. Build your fortune by running the most lucrative Gallery and secure your reputation as a world-class Gallerist!

Maximize your money and thus win the game by: 

     having visitors in your gallery; 
     exhibiting and selling works of art;
     investing in artists’ promotion to increase art value;
     achieving trends and reputation as well as curator and dealer goals.

column1:
38@Biblios@THE GAME CONCEPT
You are an abbot of a medieval monastery competing with other abbots to amass the greatest library of sacred books. To do so
column2: you need to have both the workers and resources to run a well-functioning scriptorium. To acquire workers and resources
column3: you use a limited supply of donated gold. In addition
column4: you must be on good terms with the powerful bishop
column5:
who can help you in your quest.

OUTLINE OF GAME PLAY
The object of the game is to score the most Victory Points. You win Victory Points by winning any of the 5 categories: Illuminators
column6: Scribes
column7: Manuscripts
column8: Scrolls
column9: and Supplies. You win a category by having the highest total number of workers (Scribes
column10: Illuminators) or resources (Manuscripts
column11: Scrolls
column12: Supplies) in that category. This is determined by the numbers in the upper left corner on the cards. At the start of the game
column13: each category is worth 3 Victory Points. As the game progresses
column14: the values on the Value Board will change and some categories will become worth more or fewer Victory Points than others. The game is divided into 2 stages: a Donation stage and an Auction stage. During the Donation stage
column15: players acquire free cards according to an established plan. In the Auction stage
column16: players purchase cards in auction rounds. After the two stages
column17:
winners of each category are determined and Victory Points awarded. The player with the most Victory Points wins.

GAME CHARACTERISTICS
The game involves a good deal of strategic planning
column18: some bluffing
column19: and a little bit of luck. The rules are easy to understand
column20: but you have to play it a few times to develop a playing strategy. It plays differently from 2-4 players
column21:
but each game is equally fun and challenging.

@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/w9pHmbMbHEFYtuOUcWcruA__original/img/jOmzNb1JROlzeqEmCDScX_IkHVU=/0x0/filters:format(jpeg)/pic759154.jpg@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/w9pHmbMbHEFYtuOUcWcruA__thumb/img/BYid-ptJy9xNI_kK3IDWOGLWJVM=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic759154.jpg@1.6844@30@2@4

column1: 39@Five Tribes@Crossing into the Land of 1001 Nights
column2: your caravan arrives at the fabled Sultanate of Naqala. The old sultan just died and control of Naqala is up for grabs! The oracles foretold of strangers who would maneuver the Five Tribes to gain influence over the legendary city-state. Will you fulfill the prophecy? Invoke the old Djinns and move the Tribes into position at the right time
column3:
and the Sultanate may become yours!

Designed by Bruno Cathala
column4: Five Tribes builds on a long tradition of German-style games that feature wooden meeples. Here
column5: in a unique twist on the now-standard "worker placement" genre
column6: the game begins with the meeples already in place – and players must cleverly maneuver them over the villages
column7: markets
column8: oases
column9: and sacred places tiles that make up Naqala. How
column10: when
column11: and where you dis-place these Five Tribes of Assassins
column12: Elders
column13: Builders
column14: Merchants
column15:
and Viziers determine your victory or failure.

As befitting a Days of Wonder game
column16: the rules are straightforward and easy to learn. But devising a winning strategy will take a more calculated approach than our standard fare. You need to carefully consider what moves can score you well and put your opponents at a disadvantage. You need to weigh many different pathways to victory
column17:
including the summoning of powerful Djinns that may help your cause as you attempt to control this legendary Sultanate.

@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/dmo-WD6HZHVUPrbVHunaTw__original/img/PS9HXrThM8Pepbd-cuA1tX8KCYU=/0x0/filters:format(jpeg)/pic2055255.jpg@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/dmo-WD6HZHVUPrbVHunaTw__thumb/img/I6KVJlQgS1GfWDPSWAFNqce4Cgc=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic2055255.jpg@2.8519@80@2@4

column1: 40@Space Base@In Space Base
column2:
players assume the roles of Commodores of a small fleet of ships. Ships begin docked at their stations and are then deployed to sectors as new ships are commissioned under your command. Use cargo vessels to engage in trade and commerce; mining vessels to build reoccurring base income; and carriers to spread your influence. Establish new colonies for a new Commodore in a sector to gain even more influence. Gain enough influence and you can be promoted to Admiral!

Space Base is a quick-to-learn
column3: quick-to-play dice game using the core "I roll
column4: everyone gets stuff" mechanism seen in other games. It's also a strategic engine builder using a player board (your space base) and tableaus of ship cards you can buy and add to your board. The cards you buy and the order you buy them in have interesting implications on your engine beyond just the ability on the card you buy
column5: making for a different type of engine construction than seen in similar games. Players can take their engine in a number of directions: long odds and explosive gains
column6: low luck and steady income
column7: big end-game combos to launch from last to first
column8: or a mix-and-match approach. Ultimately
column9:
Space Base is a game you can just start playing and teach everyone how to play in the first round or two and has a satisfying blend of dice-chucking luck and challenging strategic choices.

@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/MHhQxXVjiaa6C-04nGiIWw__original/img/QyWen0FVOKD_4wf7Na7fdsMTjis=/0x0/filters:format(jpeg)/pic6640638.jpg@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/MHhQxXVjiaa6C-04nGiIWw__thumb/img/rgETRyeuYs_wiZ5y-9Zj5H8kyFo=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic6640638.jpg@2.1034@60@2@5

column1: 41@Gravwell: Escape from the 9th Dimension@In Gravwell
column2: players command spaceships that have been pulled through a black hole
column3: transporting them into a different dimension. With each ship lacking fuel to get home
column4: each player must collect basic elements from surrounding asteroids
column5: using the gravity of the dimension and what little resources they have in order to reach the warp gate that will take them home. But in this dimension
column6: moving ships will travel towards the nearest object
column7: which is usually another ship
column8: and when those objects are moving either forward or backward
column9: reaching the warp gate isn't always easy. Time is running out to save your crew and your ship! As a grim reminder of the cost of failing to escape
column10: the frozen hulks of dead spacecraft litter the escape route — but with careful card play
column11:
you can slingshot past these derelict craft and be the first to escape from the Gravwell!

Gravwell uses 26 alphabetized cards to determine movement order and thrust; most cards move your ship towards the nearest object
column12: but a few move you away from it. At the start of each round
column13: players draft fuel cards
column14: picking up three pairs of two cards
column15: with only the top card of each pile being visible; you get some information as to which moves you can expect from the other spaceships
column16:
but you won't know which moves you'll be forced to make when you draft your cards!

During a round
column17: each player will play all of their fuel cards in the order of their choosing. During each phase of a round
column18: each player chooses one card
column19: then all cards are revealed and resolved in alphabetical order. When your opponents move in ways you didn't expect
column20:
you won't always be heading in the direction you thought you would! Each player holds an "Emergency Stop" card that they may tactically play only once per round to avoid such a situation.

Whoever first reaches the warp gate wins
column21: but if no one has escaped after six rounds
column22:
then the player who is closest to the gate wins.

@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/3SZ3nWQTVHNlXLgk0fl4Tg__original/img/FqVeUj6m4P4ZFysUeyuO9TDESbU=/0x0/filters:format(png)/pic2237646.png@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/3SZ3nWQTVHNlXLgk0fl4Tg__thumb/img/4LHnCJQp7GKg0f1SP68DhgprWQQ=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic2237646.png@1.7373@45@1@4

column1: 42@Lost Cities@Lost Cities is a card game in the Kosmos two-player series. The game originally consisted of a single deck of cards of rank 2–10 in five different colors with three special "handshakes" ("HS" in scoring examples below) in each suit
column2: but as of 2019 the game now includes six colored suits
column3:
with the sixth color being optional for gameplay. A game board is included to organize discarded cards and help players organize their card collections.

The object of the game is to gain points by mounting profitable archaeological expeditions to the different sites represented by the colored suits of cards. On a player's turn
column4: they must first play one card
column5: either to an expedition or by discarding it to the color-appropriate discard pile
column6: then draw one card
column7: either from the deck or from the top of a discard pile. Cards played to expeditions must be in ascending order
column8: but they need not be consecutive. Handshakes are considered lower than a 2 and represent investments in an expedition. Thus
column9: if you play a red 4
column10: you may play any other red card higher than a 4 on a future turn but may no longer play a handshake
column11: the 2
column12:
or the 3.

The game continues in this fashion with players alternating turns until the final card is taken from the deck. The rest of the cards in hand are then discarded and players score their expeditions. Each expedition that has at least one card played into it must be scored. Cards played into an expedition are worth their rank in points
column13: and handshakes count as a multiplier against your final total; one handshake doubles an expedition's value
column14: while two handshakes triples that value and three handshakes quadruple it. Expeditions start at a value of -20
column15: so you must play at least 20 points of cards into an expedition in order to make a profit. If you are left with a negative value and have a handshake
column16: the multiplier still applies. A 20-point bonus is awarded to every expedition with at least eight cards played into it. A complete game of Lost Cities lasts three matches
column17:
with scores for each match being added together.

Scoring example 1: An expedition has a 2
column21:
10 for a total of 30. This expedition is worth 10 total points: 30 plus the initial -20.

Scoring example 2: An expedition has 2 HS
column22: and 4
column27: 10 for a total of 40. This expedition is worth 80 total points: 40 points for cards
column28: plus the initial -20
column29: ×3 for the two multipliers
column30:
plus the 20-pt bonus for playing 8+ cards.

Scoring example 3: An expedition has 1 HS

column1: 47@Oceans@Three years in the making
column2: Oceans is a stand-alone game in the award-winning Evolution series.  With over 120 works of art
column3: 40 scenarios cards
column4: and more than 100 unique trait cards
column5:
Oceans is the most ambitious project North Star Games has ever tackled.

Theme
Oceans depicts the boundaries between the known world near the ocean’s surface
column6: and the mysteries lurking in Earth’s deepest unexplored region. Enter a vast
column7: underwater cosmos: a mysterious interconnected world of sharp teeth
column8: glowing eyes
column9: and black ink
column10:
where your survival depends on your ability to adapt to the unknown.

The foundation of the oceanic food chain are billions of one-celled organisms called phytoplankton that capture the sun's energy through photosynthesis. Every other species in the ocean is a predator
column11: each bigger than the next
column12:
all the way up to the dreaded Apex Predator. And even bigger than Apex Predators are enormous Whales that gently swim through the ocean scooping up everything in their path. This ecosystem mimics the known world near the surface.

But there is more if you are willing to dive deeper...

Oceans also includes a deck of 100 unique power cards called The Deep that represents the unknown. These powerful cards break the seams of the reality you've come to accept
column13: ranging from astonishing things found in the ocean
column14:
to the fantastical Kraken or Leviathan.

Gameplay
Oceans is an interactive engine builder
column15: where players evolve their species in a continually changing ecosystem. Players must adapt their interconnected ecosystem to survive against the inevitable march of time (Aging)
column16:
as well as a multitude of predators looking for food.

During the first half of the game
column17: players use traits from a deck of Surface cards to modify their species.  With only 12 Surface traits
column18: it’s easy to wade into your first game without being overwhelmed by new cards. These traits were chosen for their rich thematic interconnections
column19:
providing synergistic card play that mimics an oceanic ecosystem.  The Surface traits bring stability to the game environment.

During the second half of the game
column20: players can use power cards from The Deep to disrupt the stability. With over 100 unique traits in The Deep
column21:
players will slowly discover game-altering traits over the course of many games.  These traits were designed to evoke wonder and disbelief - to spark your imagination as you consider the fantastic synergies that are possible in Oceans.

Additionally
column22: there are 2 randomly chosen scenario cards that activate and deactivate at various points during the game. The scenario cards impact the basic tenets of gameplay
column23:
encouraging people to vary their play style and strategy each game.

The Evolution Series
Oceans is a stand-alone game in the Evolution series
column24: but it's a vast departure from other games in the series. The turn structure has been simplified
column25: the game play is much more forgiving
column26: and the web of interconnections has increased dramatically. Whereas Evolution has the feeling of a traditional back-and-forth battle game like Magic: The Gathering
column27: Oceans has the feel of an interactive engine builder where everything is interconnected
column28:
and where your engine must continually adapt to a changing environment.

column29: strategy discussions
column30:
and to get involved in future playtesting.

column1: 48@Puerto Rico@In Puerto Rico
column2:
players assume the roles of colonial governors on the island of Puerto Rico. The aim of the game is to amass victory points by shipping goods to Europe or by constructing buildings.

Each player uses a separate small board with spaces for city buildings
column3: plantations
column4: and resources. Shared between the players are three ships
column5: a trading house
column6:
and a supply of resources and doubloons.

The resource cycle of the game is that players grow crops which they exchange for points or doubloons. Doubloons can then be used to buy buildings
column7:
which allow players to produce more crops or give them other abilities. Buildings and plantations do not work unless they are manned by colonists.

During each round
column8: players take turns selecting a role card from those on the table (such as "Trader" or "Builder"). When a role is chosen
column9: every player gets to take the action appropriate to that role. The player that selected the role also receives a small privilege for doing so - for example
column10: choosing the "Builder" role allows all players to construct a building
column11: but the player who chose the role may do so at a discount on that turn. Unused roles gain a doubloon bonus at the end of each turn
column12:
so the next player who chooses that role gets to keep any doubloon bonus associated with it. This encourages players to make use of all the roles throughout a typical course of a game.

Puerto Rico uses a variable phase order mechanism in which a "governor" token is passed clockwise to the next player at the conclusion of a turn. The player with the token begins the round by choosing a role and taking the first action.

Players earn victory points for owning buildings
column13: for shipping goods
column14: and for manned "large buildings." Each player's accumulated shipping chips are kept face down and come in denominations of one or five. This prevents other players from being able to determine the exact score of another player. Goods and doubloons are placed in clear view of other players and the totals of each can always be requested by a player. As the game enters its later stages
column15:
the unknown quantity of shipping tokens and its denominations require players to consider their options before choosing a role that can end the game.

In 2011 and mostly afterwards
column16: Puerto Rico was published to include both Puerto Rico: Expansion I – New Buildings and Puerto Rico: Expansion II – The Nobles. These versions are included in the other game entry Puerto Rico (with two expansions)
column17: not this regular game entry for Puerto Rico. Some editions of Puerto Rico list the player count as 2-5 instead of 3-5
column18:
and they include variant rules for games with only two players.

column1: 57@Detective: A Modern Crime Board Game@In Detective: A Modern Crime Board Game you are going to solve FIVE different cases and find out what connects them

and you will be able to COOPERATE with other agents or solve the mystery on your own.

they will unveil an immersive meta-plot based on facts and fiction alike.

column1: 58@Nations@From the humble beginnings of civilization through the historical ages of progress

column3: fought
column4: and built together in nations. Great nations protect and provide for their own
column5: while fighting and competing against both other nations and nature itself. Nations must provide food and stability as the population increases. They must build a productive economy. And all the while
column6:
they must amaze the world with their great achievements to build up their heritage as the greatest nations in the history of mankind!

Nations is an intense historical board game for 1–5 players that takes 40 minutes per player to play. Players control the fate of nations from their humble start in prehistoric times until the beginning of World War I. The nations constantly compete against each other and must balance immediate needs
column7: long-term growth
column8: threats
column9:
and opportunities.

Gameplay introduction

Players choose a Nation and a difficulty to play at
column10: similar to the Civilization computer games series. After the growth phase
column11: 2 historical events are revealed
column12: which the players will compete for during the round. Then players take a single small action each
column13: in player order
column14:
as many times as they wish until all have passed. Actions are:


     Buy a card
     Deploy a worker
     Hire an architect for a wonder
     Special action provided by a card


Players each have individual boards that represent their Nation. There are many ways that players affect
column15: compete
column16: and indirectly interact with other players. But there is no map
column17: no units to move around
column18:
and no direct attacks on other players.

When all have passed
column19: there is production
column20: new player order is determined (every position is competed for)
column21: the historical events happen
column22: and if this is the last round of an age
column23: the books are scored. At the start of a new round
column24:
most old cards are removed and new ones are put on the display.

Victory points are gained and lost during the game
column25:
and also awarded at the end of the game. The player with the most victory points is the winner.

See 'More information' below for link to rules
column26:
etc.

column1: 59@Time's Up!@Time's Up! is a charades-based party game for teams of two or more players (and is best with teams of two). Before the game begins
column2: each player looks at several cards featuring famous historical or fictional characters and chooses some of them. Each player's cards are shuffled to form a deck
column3:
and this deck of famous names is used for each of the game's three rounds.

In each round
column4: team members take turns trying to get their teammates to guess as many names as possible in 30 seconds. In round 1
column5: almost any kind of clue is allowed
column6: and the cluegiver cannot pass on a card. In round 2
column7: no more than one word can be used in each clue (but unlimited sounds and gestures are permitted); the cluegiver can pass on any card he likes
column8: and the teammates can give only a single answer. In round 3
column9: the cluegiver can use no words at all and can pass as often as he likes; again
column10: teammates are allowed only a single guess. Give good physical clues in round 1
column11:
and they'll pay dividends down the road when you need to keep your mouth shut and gesture like a maniac before time's up!

Time's Up! is based on the public domain game known as Celebrities.  Also known as Salad Bowl or Fish Bowl.

column1: 60@Legendary: A Marvel Deck Building Game@Legendary: A Marvel Deck Building Game is set in the Marvel Comics universe. To set up the game

column17: possibly punishing the heroes in some way. Some villains also take an action when showing up for the first time

the mastermind villain (controlled by the game) takes a bonus action.

As players fight and defeat villains

column22: which will be worth points at game's end. Players can also fight the mastermind; if a player has enough fighting power
column23: he claims one of the attack cards beneath the mastermind

or imposing a certain number of wounds on the heroes – then the players all lose.

Hero decks in the base game: Gambit
