column1:
63@Victory in the Pacific@"Victory in the Pacific" is a simple strategic wargame covering the Pacific Theater of World War 2.  It is a successor to the system developed in "War at Sea" which covers the Battle of the Atlantic.

The game divides the Pacific into 13 sea areas.  Each turn the players move their ships
column2:
land based air and marines from the ports and bases (which are located on the borders of sea areas) to one of the areas.

Ships can either be patrollers  (the only ships that will take control of area after battle
column3:
but they must commit their move first) or raiders.

After all ships have been moved
column4: the players dice off determine whether a day battle (where air power is decisive) or night battle (when ship board gunnery rules) is fought.  After a number of rounds
column5: until one side or the other retreats or loses all of his ships
column6:
the player with patrolling ships left takes control of the area and a scores a number of "Points of Control".

The Japanese will almost always take a large lead that will be inevitably turned back by the Americans as they get large numbers of carriers as the game goes on.

Avalon Hill Complexity Rating - 2

column1:
66@Bohnanza@Bohnanza is the first in the Bohnanza family of games and has been published in several different editions.

In the game
column2: you plant
column3: then harvest bean cards in order to earn coins. Each player starts with a hand of random bean cards
column4: and each card has a number on it corresponding to the number of that type of beans in the deck. Unlike in most other cards games
column5: you can't rearrange the order of cards in hand
column6: so you must use them in the order that you've picked them up from the deck — unless you can trade them to other players
column7:
which is the heart of the game.

On a turn
column8: you must plant the first one or two cards in your hand into the "fields" in front of you. Each field can hold only one type of bean
column9: so if you must plant a type of bean that's not in one of your fields
column10: then you must harvest a field to make room for the new arrival. This usually isn't good! Next
column11: you reveal two cards from the deck
column12:
and you can then trade these cards as well as any card in your hand for cards from other players. You can even make future promises for cards received right now! After all the trading is complete — and all trades on a turn must involve the active player — then you end your turn by drawing cards from the deck and placing them at the back of your hand.

When you harvest beans
column13: you receive coins based on the number of bean cards in that field and the "beanometer" for that particular type of bean. Flip over 1-4 cards from that field to transform them into coins
column14: then place the remainder of the cards in the discard pile. When the deck runs out
column15: shuffle the discards
column16: playing through the deck two more times. At the end of the game
column17: everyone can harvest their fields
column18:
then whoever has earned the most coins wins.

The original German edition supports 3-5 players. The English version from Rio Grande Games comes with the first edition of the first German expansion included in a slightly oversized box. One difference in the contents
column19: however
column20: is that bean #22's Weinbrandbohne (Brandy Bean) was replaced by the Wachsbohne
column21: or Wax Bean. This edition includes rules for up to seven players
column22: like the Erweiterungs-Set
column23:
but also adapts the two-player rules of Al Cabohne in order to allow two people to play Bohnanza.

column1:
67@Crokinole@Crokinole is a dexterity traditional game.

Crokinole is played on a circular wooden board
column2:
with wooden circular disks as playing pieces.

Players take turns shooting disks across the circular wooden board by flicking the disks with their fingers.  Players try to land their disks in scoring regions on the board
column3: with the highest scoring area the recessed hole in the very center of the board.  Each round
column4: each player/side alternately shoots a set number of disks (usually 12 or 8)
column5:
shooting one disk each turn.

As a traditional game
column6: there are often many variations played
column7:
but the following method is based on the National Crokinole Association's rules which also govern the World Crokinole Championship.

Players must position their disk on the start of each of their turns in their quadrant in front of them
column8:
touching the outer scoring ring boundary.

If there are no opponent's disks on the board
column9:
they must aim for the center of the board.

If there is an opponent's disk on the board
column10: they must aim and hit an opponent's piece first
column11: either directly
column12:
or by a carrom shot.

The center recessed hole is worth 20 points
column13:
and disks are removed and scored at the end of the round if they land in the center hole.

Disks that are outside the outer scoring ring at the end of each shot
column14: or are touching the outer scoring ring at the end of each shot
column15:
are removed from play for the round.

Scoring is by cancellation scoring (e.g. Player/Side One scores 250
column16: and Player/Side Two scores 225
column17:
Player/Side One scores 25.)

It is usually played as a two-player game or as a four-player game with partners.

Play is to a set score
column18:
usually the first player/side to 100.

Alternately
column19: play is set at "Match Scoring" where the winner of each round scores 2 points
column20: and if a tie
column21: each player scores 1 point. A "game" is usually played to four rounds
column22:
with the winner of each "game" being the one with the most points. The numbers of "games" in a match is set by the tournament.

The World Crokinole Championship uses "Match Scoring."

column1:
70@Magic: The Gathering@


    
        GAME SYSTEM

    
    
         This entry is to allow for discussion/rating of the game system as a whole. It is not for a specific product or release. Versions will appear on the individual item pages.

    


From the official website:  In the Magic game
column2: you play the role of a planeswalker—a powerful wizard who fights other planeswalkers for glory
column3: knowledge
column4:
and conquest. Your deck of cards represents all the weapons in your arsenal. It contains the spells you know and the creatures you can summon to fight for you.

This is the grandfather of the collectible card game (or CCG) genre.  Cards are categorized as common
column5: uncommon
column6: rare
column7:
and mythic rare.  Players collect cards and build decks out of their collection.

Players build a deck of cards and duel against an opponent's deck.  Players are wizards attempting to reduce their opponent's life total to zero.  The first player to reduce his opponent's life to zero (or meet another set win condition) wins the game.

An important part of the game is deck construction
column8: which is done prior to the actual game by selecting what cards are included in a particular deck.  There are nearly 20
column9:
000 different cards from which to build your deck!

Cards can be lands
column10: which usually generate mana of various colors
column11: or spells
column12: which require a certain amount of mana to be used.  Some cards (creatures
column13: artifacts
column14: and enchantments) stay on the board and continue to affect the game
column15:
while others have a one-time effect.

Players randomly draw spells to see what they get and can play each turn.  Although this limits your choices
column16: there is a lot of strategy in how you play those spells.  A robust list of game mechanics
column17: including intricate rules for reactive card play called "the stack
column18:
" provide for rich tactics and tough choices each turn.

Though traditionally a two-player duel
column19:
there are several casual and tournament formats to Magic that allow more players to play.

column1: 71@Eldritch Horror@Across the globe
column2: ancient evil is stirring. Now
column3: you and your trusted circle of colleagues must travel around the world
column4: working against all odds to hold back the approaching horror. Foul monsters
column5: brutal encounters
column6: and obscure mysteries will take you to your limit and beyond. All the while
column7:
you and your fellow investigators must unravel the otherworldy mysteries scattered around the globe in order to push back the gathering mayhem that threatens to overwhelm humanity. The end draws near! Do you have the courage to prevent global destruction?

Eldritch Horror is a co-operative game of terror and adventure in which one to eight players take the roles of globetrotting investigators working to solve mysteries
column8: gather clues
column9: and protect the world from an Ancient One – that is
column10: an elder being intent on destroying our world. Each Ancient One comes with its own unique decks of Mystery and Research cards
column11:
which draw you deeper into the lore surrounding each loathsome creature. Discover the true name of Azathoth or battle Cthulhu on the high seas.

While the tasks on these Mystery cards (along with the locations of otherworldly gates
column12: menacing monsters
column13: and helpful clues) will often inform both your travel plans and the dangers you confront
column14: you can find adventure anywhere in the world...even where you least expect it. It is during the Encounter Phase of each turn that players resolve combat or
column15: alternatively
column16:
build their investigators' personal stories by reading an encounter narrative from one of several types of Encounter cards. You might go head to head with a monster in Istanbul or find yourself in a tough spot with the crime syndicate in a major city. Maybe you will embark on an expedition to the Pyramids or research a clue you uncover in the unnamed wilderness. You may even find your way through a gate and explore a dimension beyond time and space.

Should you fail an encounter
column17: the cost is steep. If you are fortunate
column18: you will merely incur physical or mental trauma. However
column19: you might also be compelled to take a Condition card
column20: which represents a specific injury or restriction gained throughout your journey
column21: such as a Leg Injury or Amnesia. You could find yourself getting in over your head to acquire assets and receive a Debt condition – or maybe you'll owe a favor to something far more insidious than a debt collector
column22: and enter into a Dark Pact! Whatever your condition
column23: you would be wise to find a resolution with haste; many conditions have a "reckoning effect" which
column24: if triggered
column25:
ensure a much more sinister fate.

All the while
column26: the arrival of the Ancient One approaches. Its malign influence is manifested in Eldritch Horror as you draw Mythos Cards
column27: which govern the appearance of otherworldly gates
column28: fearsome monsters
column29: and other ominous elements. Mythos cards keep your investigators under pressure
column30: introducing new threats
column31: even as the arrival of the Great Old One draws nearer! Since the investigators draw a new Mythos card each round
column32: they're certain to have their hands full battling foul creatures and following up on strange rumors
column33:
even as they work to solve their three all-important mysteries.

With twelve unique investigators
column37:
world-spanning adventure with each and every game.

column1: 72@Secret Hitler@Secret Hitler is a dramatic game of political intrigue and betrayal set in 1930s Germany. Each player is randomly and secretly assigned to be a liberal or a fascist
column2:
and one player is Secret Hitler. The fascists coordinate to sow distrust and install their cold-blooded leader; the liberals must find and stop the Secret Hitler before it's too late. The liberal team always has a majority.

At the beginning of the game
column3: players close their eyes
column4: and the fascists reveal themselves to one another. Secret Hitler keeps his eyes closed
column5: but puts his thumb up so the fascists can see who he is. The fascists learn who Hitler is
column6: but Hitler doesn't know who his fellow fascists are
column7:
and the liberals don't know who anyone is.

Each round
column8: players elect a President and a Chancellor who will work together to enact a law from a random deck. If the government passes a fascist law
column9:
players must try to figure out if they were betrayed or simply unlucky. Secret Hitler also features government powers that come into play as fascism advances. The fascists will use those powers to create chaos unless liberals can pull the nation back from the brink of war.

The objective of the liberal team is to pass five liberal policies or assassinate Secret Hitler. The objective of the fascist team is to pass six fascist policies or elect Secret Hitler chancellor after three fascist policies have passed.

column1: 73@The Voyages of Marco Polo@In 1271
column2: 17-year-old Marco Polo started on a journey to China with his father and older brother. After a long and grueling journey that led through Jerusalem and Mesopotamia and over the "Silk Road"
column3:
they reached the court of Kublai Khan in 1275.

In The Voyages of Marco Polo
column4: players recreate this journey
column5: with each player having a different character from history with a special power in the game. The game is played over five rounds. Each round
column6: the players roll their five personal dice and can perform one action each turn with them. Each action requires the use of one or more dice
column7: and can be collecting resources or money
column8: acquiring contracts or traveling on the board. When traveling
column9: each player begins at Venice and can decide between several routes eastward
column10: all the way to Beijing. When a player stops at a city
column11: they place a trading post there
column12: giving them access to extra actions or resources for the rest of the game. The higher the value of the dice used for an action
column13: the better the options that may be chosen
column14:
but also the more money the player must pay if an opponent has already chosen the same action.

After five rounds
column15: the game ends with players receiving extra victory points for having trading posts in Beijing
column16: fulfilling the most orders
column17:
and having trading posts in the cities on secret city cards that each player gets at the start of the game.

This game should not be confused with Marco Polo Expedition
column18:
which has the same German title.

column1:
74@The 7th Continent@It's the early 20th century. You have decided to sail back to the newly discovered seventh continent to attempt to lift the terrible curse that has struck you since your return from the previous expedition.

In The 7th Continent
column2: a solo or cooperative "choose-your-own-adventure" exploration board game

column5: you have to use every ounce of wit and cunning to survive

column8:
and shelter to ensure your survival.

Unlike most board games

column10:
MANY hours of exploring and searching the seventh continent until you eventually discover how to remove the curse(s)...or die trying.

The 7th Continent features an easy saving system so that you can stop playing at any time and resume your adventure later on

just like in a video game!

column1: 76@Nanty Narking@Immersed deeply in the world of Dickens’s and Doyle’s literature

Nanty Narking moves you into the realities of the myths and legends of the Victorian era. The events in the game are tied to real and fictional characters and places in Victorian London The same London which inspired so many stories…

The cards bring the game to life as they include most of the famous characters who have appeared in the various books. The rules are relatively simple: Play a card and do what it says. Most cards have more than one action on them

so you can chain actions.

At the beginning of the game

which means that you can never be sure what the other players need to do in order to win. You need to fulfill your goal while also trying to prevent others from winning!

column1: 77@Architects of the West Kingdom@Architects of the West Kingdom is set at the end of the Carolingian Empire

column4: hire apprentices
column5: and keep a watchful eye on their workforce. These are treacherous times
column6: and rival architects will stop at nothing to slow your progress. Will you remain virtuous
column7:
or be found in the company of thieves and black marketeers?

The aim of Architects of the West Kingdom is to be the player with the most victory points (VP) at game's end. Points are gained by constructing various buildings and advancing work on the Archbishop's cathedral. Throughout the game
column8: players need to make a lot of moral decisions. However

column10:
but fall too far and you will be punished. The game ends once a set number of constructions have been completed.

@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/OAX7HfOz-9N60StgADzd0g__original/img/x2Y_DYWrzzleMETfnu7Jm3R8jPo=/0x0/filters:format(png)/pic3781944.png@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/OAX7HfOz-9N60StgADzd0g__thumb/img/sBMaoJ-Kz74lJ6djcl-NNMTr0Wo=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic3781944.png@2.7546@80@1@5

column1:
78@Monopoly@Theme
Players take the part of land owners
column2: attempting to buy and then develop their land. Income is gained by other players visiting their properties and money is spent when they visit properties belonging to other players. When times get tough
column3: players may have to mortgage their properties to raise cash for fines
column4:
taxes and other misfortunes.

Gameplay
On his turn
column5: a player rolls two dice and moves that number of spaces around the board. If the player lands on an as-yet-unowned property
column6: he has the opportunity to buy it and add it to his portfolio or allow the bank to auction it to the highest bidder. If a player owns all the spaces within a color group
column7: he may then build houses and hotels on these spaces
column8: generating even more income from opponents who land there. If he lands on a property owned by another player
column9: he must pay that player rent according to the value of the land and any buildings on it. There are other places on the board which can not be bought
column10: but instead require the player to draw a card and perform the action on the card
column11: pay taxes
column12: collect income
column13:
or even go to jail.

Goal
The goal of the game is to be the last player remaining with any money.

Cultural impact on rules
Monopoly is unusual in that the game has official
column14: printed rules
column15: but most players learn how to play from others
column16: never actually learning the correct way to play. This has led to the canonization of a number of house rules that make the game more palatable to children (and sore losers) but harm the gameplay by preventing players from going bankrupt or slowing down the rate of property acquisition. One common house rule has players put any money paid to the bank in the center of the board
column17: which jackpot a player may earn by landing on Free Parking. This prevents the game from removing money from play
column18: and since players collect $200 each time they pass Go
column19: this results in ever-increasing bankrolls and players surviving rents that should have bankrupted them. Another house rule allows players to take "loans" from the bank instead of going bankrupt
column20: which means the game will never end. Some house rules arise out of ignorance rather than attempts to improve the game. For instance
column21: many players don't know that properties landed on but left unbought go up for auction
column22: and even some that know to auction don't know that the bidding starts at $1
column23:
meaning a player may pay well below the listed price for an auctioned property.

Background
In the USA in 1933
column24: Charles Darrow devised Monopoly based on an earlier game by Elizabeth J. Magie. The patent was filed 31st August 1935 while the game was on sale in America. Based on an earlier game
column25: The Landlord's Game
column26: it was at first rejected by Parker Bros.
column27: as being too complicated to be a success. How wrong could they be! It came to the UK in 1936
column28:
made under licence by Waddingtons. Darrow died in 1967 having realised he had developed one of the most successful board games of all times. It was awarded as Game of the Century by the TRA (Toy Retailers Association).

Monopoly was patented in 1935 by Charles Darrow and released by Parker Brothers. The game was actually one of a number of variants in existence at the time
column29: all of which date back to an earlier
column30:
1904 game by Elizabeth J. Magie called The Landlord's Game. Magie was a proponent of the Single Tax put forth by famous author Henry George.  The game was designed to show the evils of earning money from renting land (as it leads to the destitution of all but one player) and the virtues of the proposed Single Tax - players could choose to play under regular rules or alternate "Single Tax" rules.

The game didn't really go anywhere and Magie lost interest in it. Variations of the game evolved
column32: and homemade versions traveled up and down the Atlantic coast and even as far west as Michigan and Texas
column33: being developed all along the way. Eventually the game was noticed by Charles Darrow
column34:
who introduced it to the world in its current form.

Re-implements:

    The Landlord's Game

Official

    Monopoly Free Parking Mini Game
    Monopoly Get Out of Jail Mini Game

    Super Add-Ons: Monopoly (fan expansion for Monopoly)
    Entrepreneur's Accessory to Monopoly (fan expansion for Monopoly)
    Game Spice: Monopoly Expansion (fan expansion for Monopoly)
    Mafiopoly

    Final Fantasy Monopoly

column1: 80@Pax Pamir: Second Edition@In Pax Pamir
column2: players assume the role of nineteenth century Afghan leaders attempting to forge a new state after the collapse of the Durrani Empire. Western histories often call this period "The Great Game" because of the role played by the Europeans who attempted to use central Asia as a theater for their own rivalries. In this game
column3:
those empires are viewed strictly from the perspective of the Afghans who sought to manipulate the interloping ferengi (foreigners) for their own purposes.

In terms of game play
column4: Pax Pamir is a pretty straightforward tableau builder. Players spend most of their turns purchasing cards from a central market
column5: then playing those cards in front of them in a single row called a court. Playing cards adds units to the game's map and grants access to additional actions that can be taken to disrupt other players and influence the course of the game. That last point is worth emphasizing. Though everyone is building their own row of cards
column6:
the game offers many ways for players to interfere with each other directly and indirectly.

To survive
column7: players will organize into coalitions. Throughout the game
column8: the dominance of the different coalitions will be evaluated by the players when a special card
column9: called a "Dominance Check"
column10: is resolved. If a single coalition has a commanding lead during one of these checks
column11: those players loyal to that coalition will receive victory points based on their influence in their coalition. However
column12: if Afghanistan remains fragmented during one of these checks
column13:
players instead will receive victory points based on their personal power base.

After each Dominance Check
column14: victory is checked and the game will be partially reset
column15:
offering players a fresh attempt to realize their ambitions. The game ends when a single player is able to achieve a lead of four or more victory points  or after the fourth and final Dominance Check is resolved.

column1:
81@Mage Wars Arena@What would it be like for Mages of vastly different schools and philosophies of magic to come together in an arena and fight to the death? How would an Illusionist battle a Druid? Or a Warlock fight a Beastmaster? Or a Priestess fare against a Wizard?

Mage Wars — redubbed Mage Wars Arena in 2015 to distinguish it from Mage Wars Academy — pits powerful Mages against each other in deadly arena combat. Each Mage uses his own fully-customizable book of spells to achieve total victory over his opponent. Summon mighty creatures to do battle in your name; cast powerful spells to attack your foe and thwart his every plan and strategy; use hidden enchantments to turn the tables and rule the day; adorn yourself with mighty weapons
column2: armor
column3:
and arcane artifacts – all of this and more await you in the arena of Mage Wars!

Mage Wars is a tactical board game
column4: a combination of a card game and miniatures game
column5: combining the best elements from each genre. The game is played on an arena game board divided into square areas called "zones"
column6: which regulate movement and the placement of objects. Each Mage (player) starts in a corner of the arena
column7:
opposite his enemy.

Each player holds a spellbook
column8: from which spell cards are pulled out as they are cast during the game. This has the feel of being a real Mage
column9: turning the pages of your tome of magic
column10: as you plan your strategy each turn. A point system allows you to choose spells for your spellbook
column11: with more powerful spells and spells outside your schools of training costing more points. You have full access to cast any spell you want each turn
column12: allowing for an unprecedented level of rich strategy and tactics. Many of these spells – such as creatures
column13: equipment
column14: and enchantments – are placed on the board and become objects in the game. Creatures can move around the arena
column15: and attack each other and the enemy Mage. Attacks deal damage
column16: as well as interesting special effects such as Burn
column17: Corrode
column18: Stun
column19: Daze
column20: Push
column21: Cripple
column22: Paralyze
column23: etc. Creatures can be destroyed when they receive too much damage
column24: or can be controlled by powerful curses and enchantments
column25:
or contained by walls and other creatures.

Every Mage comes from a different school of magic
column26:
each with unique spells and strategies:


    The Beastmaster will try to rush and swarm the enemy with his hordes of animals
column27:
buffed by his nature enchantments.
    The Warlock will go right for the throat
column28: armed with his powerful Lash of Hellfire
column29: Helm of Fear
column30: and Demonhide Armor. Along the way to the enemy Mage
column31:
he'll use his curses and fire attacks to contain and destroy enemy creatures.
    The Wizard is a trickster
column32: a master of meta-magic: countering
column33: stealing
column35:
and destroying enemy spells and mana. He's also a master of teleportation and portals/gates.
    The Priestess will defend with knights and angels and powerful healing and protection spells. She'll wear down the enemy
column36:
then overwhelm them in the end.


The base game comes with all you need to get started: spellbooks
column37: extra spells to customize with the spellbooks
column41:
etc.

New Mages will be released every few months to add new spells
column43: and variety to the game. The game is NOT collectible
column44:
but is fully customizable!

    Mage Wars: Core Spell Tome 2

column1: 82@Hansa Teutonica@The players act as traders trying to get victory points for building a network of offices

column1: 83@Rococo@Welcome to the Rococo era during the reign of Louis XV when it’s safe to say that holding lavish balls is quite trendy. Important personalities wrap up in noble coats and dresses
column2: anxious to outshine one another. As the biggest event is coming up in just a few weeks
column3: everyone is turning to you with their requests: an elegant coat here
column4: a stunning dress there
column5:
or a donation to fund the fireworks at the event. Soon you realize that it’s not just about your dressmaking business anymore — it’s about managing the most prestigious ball of the era…and now it’s time to roc(k)!

Rococo is a Eurostyle board game with an interesting take on deck-building. Each turn you play one of your employee cards and let that employee perform a task: hire a new employee
column6: buy resources
column7: manufacture a coat or dress
column8: or invest in the ball’s decorations. But not every employee is up to every task

so you must choose and lead your employees wisely — especially since each employee grants a unique bonus and some of these bonuses generate prestige points.

After seven rounds
column10:
the game ends with the big ball and a final scoring. Then you gain prestige points for certain employee bonuses and for coats and dresses that you rent out to guests at the ball as well as for decorations that you funded. The player who collected the most prestige points wins.

column1:
84@Cascadia@Cascadia is a puzzly tile-laying and token-drafting game featuring the habitats and wildlife of the Pacific Northwest.

In the game
column2: you take turns building out your own terrain area and populating it with wildlife. You start with three hexagonal habitat tiles (with the five types of habitat in the game)
column3: and on a turn you choose a new habitat tile that's paired with a wildlife token
column4: then place that tile next to your other ones and place the wildlife token on an appropriate habitat. (Each tile depicts 1-3 types of wildlife from the five types in the game
column5: and you can place at most one tile on a habitat.) Four tiles are on display
column6: with each tile being paired at random with a wildlife token
column7:
so you must make the best of what's available — unless you have a nature token to spend so that you can pick your choice of each item.

Ideally you can place habitat tiles to create matching terrain that reduces fragmentation and creates wildlife corridors
column8: mostly because you score for the largest area of each type of habitat at game's end
column9: with a bonus if your group is larger than each other player's. At the same time
column10: you want to place wildlife tokens so that you can maximize the number of points scored by them
column11: with the wildlife goals being determined at random by one of the four scoring cards for each type of wildlife. Maybe hawks want to be separate from other hawks
column12:
while foxes want lots of different animals surrounding them and bears want to be in pairs. Can you make it happen?

A Frozen themed reimplementation of the Milton Bradley game Ice Cube

salt and other means.

column1: 86@Alhambra@Granada
column2: 1278. At the foot of the Sierra Nevada mountains
column3:
one of the most exciting and interesting project of the Spanish Middle Ages begins: the construction of the ALHAMBRA.

The best master builders in the whole of Europe and Arabia want to demonstrate their skill.  Employ the most suitable teams of builders and make sure that you always have enough of the right currency.  Because no matter whether they are stonemasons from the north or horticulturalists from the south
column4: they all want a proper wage and insist on their "native" currency.  With their help towers can be constructed
column5: gardens laid out
column6:
pavilions and arcades erected and seraglios and chambers built.

In Alhambra
column7:
players are acquiring buildings to be placed within their Alhambra complex.

The money in Alhambra comes in four different currencies and is available in the open money market.  The 54 buildings of six types become available for purchase in the building market four at a time; one building is available in each of the four different currencies.  On a player's turn
column8: a player may 1) take money from the open money market
column9: 2) purchase a building from the building market and either place it in his Alhambra or reserve
column10: or 3) engage in construction and re-construction projects with buildings that have been placed in the player's Alhambra or reserve. The game rewards efficiency
column11: as when a player purchases a building from the market for the exact amount of money
column12:
the player may take another turn.

Players with the most buildings in each of the six building types in his Alhambra score in each of the scoring phases
column13: and points are awarded for players' longest external "wall" section within their complex. The game ends when the building market can no longer be replenished from the building tile supply
column14: and there is a final scoring
column15:
whereupon the player with the highest score wins.

Integrates with:

    Alhambra: The Dice Game (a variant in which you can combine Alhambra buildings with Alhambra dice.)

column1: 87@Glen More II: Chronicles@Glen More II: Chronicles is a sequel to Glen More
column2:
expanding the gameplay substantially compared to the original game.

In Glen More II: Chronicles
column3: each player represents the leader of a Scottish clan from the early medieval ages until the 19th century
column4: a leader looking to expand their territory and wealth. The success of your clan depends on your ability to make the right decision at the right time
column5: be it by creating a new pasture for your livestock
column6: growing barley for whisky production
column7: selling your goods on the various markets
column8:
or gaining control of special landmarks such as lochs and castles.

The game lasts four rounds
column9: represented by four stacks of tiles. After each round
column10: a scoring phase takes place in which players compare their number of whisky casks
column11: scotsmen in the home castle
column12: landmark cards
column13: and persons against the player with the fewest items in each category and receives victory points (VPs) based on the relative difference. After four rounds
column14: additional VPs are awarded for gold coins and some landmarks while VP penalties are assessed based on territory size
column15:
comparing each player's territory to the smallest one in play.

The core mechanism of Glen More II: Chronicles and Glen More functions the same way: The last player in line takes a tile from a time track
column16: advancing as far as they wish on this track. After paying the cost
column17: they place this tile in their territory
column18: with this tile activating itself and all neighboring tiles
column19: triggering the production of resources
column20: movement points
column21: VPs
column22:
etc. Then the player who is last in line takes their turn.

Improvements over the original Glen More include bigger tiles
column23: better materials
column24: new artwork
column25: the ability for each player to control the end of the game
column26: and balancing adjustments to the tiles for a better suspense curve. The game is designed to consist of one-third known systems
column27: one-third new mechanisms
column28:
and one-third improvements to Glen More.

The "Chronicles" in the title — a set of eight expansions to the base game — are a major part of these new mechanisms. Each Chronicle adds a new gameplay element to the base game. The "Highland Boat Race" Chronicle
column29: for example
column30: tells the story of a boat race in which the winner needs to be the first to reach their home castle after navigating their boat along the river through all the other players' territories. The "Hammer of the Scots" Chronicle adds a neutral "Englishman" playing piece to the time track that players struggle to control to get an additional turn — if they can afford him
column32: as he is paid using the market mechanism. All Chronicles can be freely combined
column33:
although designer Matthias Cramer suggests that players use only one or two unless they want a "monster game".

Another major change to the game is the ability to invest in famous Scottish people of the time
column34: who are represented through a new "person" tile type. Persons not only have their own scoring
column35: they also trigger one-time or ongoing effects on the tactical clan board. This adds a new layer of decision making
column36:
especially since the ongoing effects allow players to focus on a personal strategy of winning through the use of the clan board.

—description from the publisher

column1: 88@Babylonia@The Neo-Babylonian empire
column2: especially under the reign of Nebuchadnezzar II (605-562 B.C.)
column3: was a period of rebirth for southern Mesopotamia. Irrigation systems improved and expanded
column4: increasing agricultural production. Urban life flourished with the creation of new cities
column5: monuments and temples
column6:
and the consequent increase in trade.

In Babylonia
column7: you try to make your clan prosper under the peace and imperial power of that era. You have to place your nobles
column8: priests
column9: and craftsmen tokens on the map to make your relations with the cities as profitable as possible. Properly placing these counters next to the court also allows you to gain the special power of some rulers. Finally
column10:
the good use of your peasants in the fertile areas gives more value to your crops. The player who gets the most points through all these actions wins.

column1:
89@PARKS@PARKS is a celebration of the US National Parks featuring illustrious art from Fifty-Nine Parks.

In PARKS
column2: players will take on the role of two hikers as they trek through different trails across four seasons of the year. While on the trail
column3:
these hikers will take actions and collect memories of the places your hikers visit. These memories are represented by various resource tokens like mountains and forests. Collecting these memories in sets will allow players to trade them in to visit a National Park at the end of each hike.

Each trail represents one season of the year
column4: and each season
column5: the trails will change and grow steadily longer. The trails
column6: represented by tiles
column7: get shuffled in between each season and laid out anew for the next round. Resources can be tough to come by especially when someone is at the place you’re trying to reach! Campfires allow you to share a space and time with other hikers. Canteens and Gear can also be used to improve your access to resources through the game. It’ll be tough to manage building up your engine versus spending resources on parks
column8:
but we bet you’re up to the challenge. Welcome to PARKS!

column1: 90@Anachrony@It is the late 26th century. Earth is recovering from a catastrophic explosion that exterminated the majority of the population centuries ago and made most of the surface uninhabitable due to unearthly weather conditions. The surviving humans organized along four radically different ideologies
column2: called Paths
column3: to rebuild the world as they see fit: Harmony
column4: Dominance
column5: Progress
column6: and Salvation. Followers of the four Paths live in a fragile peace
column7: but in almost complete isolation next to each other. Their only meeting point is the last major city on Earth
column8:
now just known as the Capital.

By powering up the mysterious Time Rifts that opened in the wake of the cataclysm
column9: each Path is able to reach back to specific moments in their past. Doing so can greatly speed up their progress
column10: but too much meddling may endanger the time-space continuum. But progress is more important than ever before: if the mysterious message arriving through the Time Rift is to be believed
column11: an even more terrible cataclysm is looming on the horizon: an asteroid bearing the mysterious substance called Neutronium is heading towards Earth. Even stranger
column12:
the scientists show that the energy signature of the asteroid matches the explosion centuries ago...

Anachrony features a unique two-tiered worker placement system. To travel to the Capital or venture out to the devastated areas for resources
column13: players need not only various specialists (Engineers
column14: Scientists
column15: Administrators
column16:
and Geniuses) but also Exosuits to protect and enhance them — and both are in short supply.

The game is played in 4-7 turns
column17: depending on the time when the looming cataclysm occurs — unless
column18: of course
column19: it is averted! The elapsed turns are measured on a dynamic timeline. By powering up the Time Rifts
column20: players can reach back to earlier turns to supply their past "self" with resources. Each Path has a vastly different objective that rewards it with a massive amount of victory points when achieved. The Paths' settlements will survive the impact
column21: but the Capital will not. Whichever Path manages to collect most points will be the new seat for the Capital
column22:
thus the most important force left on the planet...

column1: 91@Fantasy Realms@As ruler
column2: it's up to you to build the mightiest realm in the world! Will you choose to follow military tactics and sweep away all in your path with a massive army? Will you turn towards sorcery and control an inaccessible island surrounded by impenetrable flames? The choice is yours
column3: and no two realms will ever be the same in Fantasy Realms
column4:
a combo-licious card game.

Fantasy Realms takes seconds to learn: Draw a card
column5:
discard a card — though you can draw from the deck or the discard area!

Make the best hand you can by making the best combos. The game ends when ten cards are in the discard area. Aim for the highest score to win!

To make scoring easier

input your cards into the app & instantly see who won! Also a handy lookup of all cards! Available on iOS and Google Play.

column1: 95@Russian Railroads@In Russian Railroads
column2: players compete in an exciting race to build the largest and most advanced railway network. In order to do so
column3:
the players appoint their workers to various important tasks.

The development of simple tracks will quickly bring the players to important places
column4: while the modernization of their railway network will improve the efficiency of their machinery. Newer locomotives cover greater distances and factories churn out improved technology. Engineers
column5: when used effectively
column6:
can be the extra boost that an empire needs to race past the competition.

There are many paths to victory: Who will ride into the future full steam ahead and who will be run off the rails? Whose empire will overcome the challenges ahead and emerge victorious?


Game Summary
Each player has their own board
column7: with space for factories
column8: and 3 rail tracks (to 3 different cities). On each track
column9:
use a track token to mark the progression of your rails (different colored marker for each type or rail). Some interesting twists:
- The different track types must be built in a specific order (black
column10: gray
column11: brown
column12: natural
column13:
white). Later tracks may never be advanced further on the track than the earlier tracks.
- On each track
column14: as the track head advances

column16: victory points
column17: bonus tiles
column18:
etc.
- Each track line can have one (two for the first rail) engine(s) associated with it; the size of the loco(s) determines how far down the track you actually score VP.

The central board has (almost) all the locations for placing workers. Each location requires 1-3 workers (of one player; played all together). Players
column19: who start the game with 5 workers (or 6 workers
column20: in 2-3 player games)
column21: will take turns using a location. These provide a variety of abilities
column22:
for example:
- advance 1 or more track heads by 1-3 spaces
- acquire an engine or factory; engines are allocated to rail lines
column23:
while factories (the reverse side of the tile) are placed on your factory line.
- earn 2 coins
- take 2 temporary workers
- jump ahead in turn order
- acquire an engineer
column24:
which has a unique power and becomes a worker-placement location only for you

Each round ends when all players have passed on placing/using workers. Then
column25: score VP for each track and factory line. On each track line
column26: only spaces as far down the track as the loco level will score. Each track type scores VP for every space from its track head back to where the next color of track starts. Track types built earlier (e.g. black) score less/space than later tracks (e.g.
column27:
white). On each factory line the position of the purple industry marker(s) show how many VP are scored.

After 7 rounds (or 6 rounds
column28: in 2-3 player games)
column29:
the game ends; most VP wins!

column1: 96@Downforce@High-stakes bidding on million-dollar race cars. Frantic bets placed in secret even as the cars race around the track. And to the victor
column2: the biggest purse of all. But in the world of motor racing
column3: the margin between victory and defeat can be a single moment: a steep banked turn
column4: tires screaming and spitting out smoke
column5: and the downforce
column6:
pressing you down in your seat and keeping you on the track as you make your move inside to pull ahead.

Downforce is a card-driven bidding
column7: racing
column8: and betting game for 2-6 players based on Top Race
column9: the award-winning design by the legendary Wolfgang Kramer. Players first bid to own the six cars in the race
column10: then they play cards from their hand to speed them around the track. However
column11: most cards will also move their opponents' cars. So figuring out just the right time to play a card is the key to victory. Along the way
column12: players make secret bets on who they think will win the race. Whoever has the most money from their prize money
column13: winning bets
column14:
and remaining bank wins.

This is a game whose design needed no attention. Years of play and multiple versions have honed it to near perfection. On the contrary
column15: one of the design challenges was figuring which of the many rules modules to incorporate to create the most fun version. Downforce also adds variable player powers to improve replayability. But mostly
column16: it improves the look of the game to make it gorgeous and easy to play. Special attention was paid to the colors
column17: the layout of the cards
column18: the design of the cars
column19: the details on the board
column20:
and more.

column1: 97@Dominion: Intrigue@In Dominion: Intrigue (as with Dominion)

Part of the Dominion series.

column1: 99@Feudum@Blimey! You and your blokes have been banished and stripped of everything but a few shillings and table scraps. Undaunted

column3:
fight as knights or finagle your own feudums?

Feudum (latin for fiefdom) is an economic medieval game of hand and resource management for 2-5 players. With many strategies at their disposal
column4:
players optimize four actions per turn in attempt to score the most victory points over five epochs.

Each player controls several medieval characters that roam the countryside tending farms
column5:
taxing towns and taking outposts in effort to rise in power.

column6:
which increase your membership status in one of six guilds. But beware! Feudum owners must pay homage to the king through military service or face the charge of disloyalty.

Once a guild member

column8: whereby the farmer ships goods to the merchant who equips the alchemist
column9: who invents black powder
column10: which arms the knight
column11:
and so on.

If you run your guilds wisely
column12: maintain control of key locations and adapt best to changing events
column13: you will be victorious. Unless
column14: of course

get sidetracked by sea serpents or develop an unhealthy interest in fermented grapes. Long live the King!

column1: 102@Medici@Another Reiner Knizia standby

column4: with the highest bid taking all cards.  The cards denote a commodity type and quantity/value.  The round ends when each player's ships are full
column5: or the commodity card deck is exhausted.  After each round
column6: points are awarded to each player having the most of a given commodity

column1: 103@The Estates@The City Council recently approved the zoning map for a new urban development — The Estates — featuring high-end infrastructure and a modern atmosphere for its citizens. Soon after
column2: the banks awarded millions of dollars in loans to six real estate investment firms to help develop this new area. The zoning map for The Estates calls for two rows of four buildings each
column3:
located between the River and Main Street. The meadows on the other side of the River are to remain a recreational area for the City.

But
column4: with hopes of larger profits
column5: investors and building tycoons entirely ignore the City Council's demands and begin developing three rows of buildings instead. The Mayor catches wind of the potential for profit and begins planning a new mansion in The Estates
column6: which would double the value of one of the building rows! With some sketchy building permits
column7: investors begin developing buildings on the other side of the River
column8: beyond the designated building zone. However
column9: the City Council takes rigorous steps to put an end to the racketeering with an ultimatum: As soon as the first two rows are completed
column10: the buildings in the uncompleted row will be torn down
column11: resulting in a huge loss for all who invested there. At the end of the day
column12:
the investor with the highest-valued buildings will come out on top.

The players take on the role of investors seeking to make the most money by developing buildings in The Estates. Players will bid for the various building pieces and place them in The Estates to their benefit. All buildings in completed rows score positive points
column13:
while all buildings in incomplete rows score negative points. It is possible to have zero completed rows of buildings.

A game of The Estates lasts around 40 minutes and can be played in several rounds to experience a shifting economy.

column1:
104@Caylus@Once upon a time ...
1289. To strengthen the borders of the Kingdom of France

the player who has earned the most prestige wins the game.  The expansion Caylus Expansion: The Jeweller was included in the 2nd Edition.

Each turn
column10: players pay to place their workers in various buildings in the village. These buildings allow players to gather resources or money
column11: or to build or upgrade buildings with those resources. Players can also use their resources to help build the castle itself
column12: earning points and favors from the king
column13: which provide larger bonuses. Building a building provides some immediate points
column14: and potentially income throughout the game
column15: since players receive bonuses when others use their buildings. The buildings chosen by the players have a heavy impact on the course of the game

since they determine the actions that will be available to all the players.

As new buildings are built
column17: they stretch along a road stretching away from the castle
column18: and not all buildings can be used every turn. Players have some control over which buildings are active by paying to influence the movement of the Provost marker. The final position of the marker is the newest building that can be used that turn. The Provost marker also helps determine the movement of the Bailiff marker

column1: 105@The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game@The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game is a cooperative adventure game in which the players attempt to complete a scenario

column3: events and attachments to support them. Each round

column5: as the heroes and allies exhaust after questing
column6: defending
column7: or attacking

column9: players need to determine whether it is more urgent to quest and make progress in the scenario while the enemy forces gain power

column11:
not knowing what will come next.

The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game is the base game of a Living Card Game for which new adventure packs are released monthly. The base game contains three scenarios

Although this game is set in Tolkien's Middle Earth

column1: 108@Ra@Ra is an auction and set-collection game with an Ancient Egyptian theme.  Each turn players are able to purchase lots of tiles with their bidding tiles (suns).  Once a player has used up his or her suns
column2: the other players continue until they do likewise
column3: which may set up a situation with a single uncontested player bidding on tiles before the end of the round occurs.  Tension builds because the round may end before all players have had a chance to win their three lots for the epoch.  The various tiles either give immediate points

column5: or give points after the final round.  The game lasts for three "epochs" (rounds).  The game offers a short learning curve
column6:
and experienced players find it both fast-moving and a quick play.

column1: 110@A War of Whispers@A War of Whispers is a competitive board game for 2 to 4 players. Five mighty empires are at war for the world
column2: but you are no mighty ruler. Instead
column3: you play a secret society that is betting on the results of this war while pulling strings to rig the results and ensure their bets pay off. A War of Whispers is a game of deep strategy
column4: hidden agendas
column5:
and shifting loyalties.

You start the game with five loyalty tokens
column6: each corresponding to one of the five different empires
column7: bet randomly on a loyalty value. Your primary goal is to ensure that when the game ends
column8:
the empires you are most loyal to control the most cities across the globe. Gameplay consists of turns broken down into four phases:


    Deploy agents phase: In player order (starting with the first player and proceeding clockwise)
column9: each player removes
column10: then deploys agents to empire councils
column11: the positions on the board marked Sheriff
column12: Steward
column13: Marshall
column14:
and Chancellor.
    Empire turns phase: Each council position on each empire council will take an action. If a player has acquired cards
column15:
they may play them during this phase.
    Cleanup phase: Add the turn marker to the next space on the turn tracker
column16:
then each player discards down to the hand limit of five cards.
    Swap phase: In player order
column17: each player may swap two of their unrevealed loyalty tokens. If you choose to do so
column18:
you must reveal both of the swapped loyalty tokens. They remain revealed for the rest of the game.


Gameplay repeats itself in this order four times. When the last space on the turn track is filled
column19:
the game ends immediately and scoring commences. The player with the most points based off their empire loyalties and the cities they control wins.

column1: 112@Beyond the Sun@Beyond the Sun is a space civilization game in which players collectively decide the technological progress of humankind at the dawn of the Spacefaring Era

new heroes arrive to provide all new match-ups.

Battle of Legends
column6: Volume One features four heroes. King Arthur sacrifices cards to power up his attacks and gets some timely assistance from Merlin's magic. Alice is back from Wonderland with a giant vorpal blade and the Jabberwock by her side as she grows and shrinks to gain advantages on attack and defense. Medusa is happy to attack from range and let her harpies hound you
column7:
but just one devastating glance could end the battle quickly. Sinbad grows in power as he gains experience on each of his voyages.

Combat is resolved quickly by comparing attack and defense cards. However
column8:
each card's unique effects and a simple but deep timing system lead to interesting decisions each time. The game also features an updated version of the line-of-sight system from Tannhäuser for ranged attacks and area effects.

The game includes a double-sided board with two different battlefields
column9: pre-washed miniatures for each hero
column10:
and custom life trackers that's brought to life with the stunning artwork of Oliver Barrett and the combined design teams of Restoration Games and Mondo Games.

@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/4AlLbprNustr9G7pbkGRuw__original/img/d7Z89SEv9T_HqPaYEomeKcFmgeA=/0x0/filters:format(jpeg)/pic4621579.jpg@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/4AlLbprNustr9G7pbkGRuw__thumb/img/nVkIL7RgCkFpBuxbJ3BfOxIJscU=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic4621579.jpg@1.9194@40@2@4

column1:
115@Millennium Blades@Millennium Blades is a CCG-Simulator -- A game in which you play as a group of friends who play the fictional CCG "Millennium Blades".

In this game you will build decks

column3: acquire valuable collections

and compete in tournaments for prizes and fame. The game takes you from Starter Deck to Regionals in about 2-3 hours.

Multiple games can also be chained together to form a Campaign
column6: going from Regionals to Nationals in game 2 and from Nationals to Worlds in game 3
column7: with each game introducing ever more powerful cards and higher stakes
column8:
but also resetting the power of the game so that each player has a fair chance to win each 'season' of the campaign.

The game draws heavily on Manga/Anime inspiration for its art
column9: and parodies Magic: the Gathering
column10: Yugioh
column11:
and many other collectible games.

At its heart
column12: it’s a commodity trading game
column13: except that instead of cubes or stocks
column14: the things you’ll be buying
column15: selling
column16: and speculating on are trading cards that can be used throughout the game in periodic tournaments. By trading wisely
column17: playing the market
column18: working together with friends
column19: building collections
column20: and winning tournaments
column21:
you’ll secure points and become the Millennium Blades World Champion.

The game features a system of card pods
column22:
where you will play with about 400 of the base game’s 600 cards every game.

column1: 116@Space Alert@Space Alert is a cooperative team survival game. Players become crew members of a small spaceship scanning dangerous sectors of the galaxy. The missions last just 10 real-time minutes (hyperspace jump
column2: sector scan
column3:
hyperspace jump back) and the only task the players have is to protect their ship.

During play
column4: the central computer will announce the presence of various threats on one the supplied 10 minute soundtracks that also acts as a game timer. The threats vary from space battleships and interceptors to different interstellar monsters and abominations
column5: asteroids or even intruders and malfunctions on the spaceship. Players have to agree who will take care of which task and coordinate their actions (moving around the ship
column6: firing weapons
column7: distributing energy
column8: using battlebots to deal with intruders
column9: launching guided missiles
column10:
etc.) in real time to defend the ship. Only a well-working team can survive 10 minutes and make the jump back to safety.

The game offers several difficulty levels
column11: huge variability and a unique experience for one to five player teams. One mission lasts only about 30 minutes
column12:
including setup and evaluation.

(Based on a description from Czech Games Edition)

column1: 117@Imperial Struggle@In 1697 the Sun King
column2: Louis XIV
column3: emerged from a decade of war with his Continental ambitions still unsatisfied. Meanwhile
column4: King William III of England sat easier on his new throne than he ever had before. With the Spanish succession crisis unresolved and looming
column5: there were no illusions that the new century would be a quiet one. But neither France nor England could have anticipated the tumult of the years to come: a Second Hundred Years' War
column6:
during which these two tenacious adversaries would compete fiercely and proudly along every axis of human achievement. On battlefields from India to Canada to the Caribbean Sea their armies and fleets would clash; in the salons of Paris and the coffee-houses of London the modern world’s politics and economics would be born; and finally a revolution would rock the foundations of society – a revolution that could have ended not in blood and terror but in a triumph of democracy and liberty that might have transformed the world beyond imagining.

Imperial Struggle is a two-player game depicting the 18th-century rivalry between France and Britain. It begins in 1697
column7: as the two realms wait warily for the King of Spain to name an heir
column8: and ends in 1789
column9: when a new order brought down the Bastille. The game is not merely about war: both France and Britain must build the foundations of colonial wealth
column10: deal with the other nations of Europe
column11:
and compete for glory across the span of human endeavor.

Imperial Struggle covers almost 100 years of history and four major wars. Yet it remains a low-complexity game
column12: playable in a short evening. It aims to honor its spiritual ancestor
column13: Twilight Struggle
column14: by pushing further in the direction of simple rules and playable systems
column15: while maintaining global scope and historical sweep in the scope of a single evening. In peace turns
column16: players build their economic interests and alliances
column17: and take advantage of historical events represented by Event cards. They must choose their investments wisely
column18: but also with an eye to denying these opportunities to their opponent. In war turns
column19: each theater can bring great rewards of conquest and prestige
column20: but territorial gains can disappear at the treaty table. At the end of the century
column21: will the British rule an empire on which the sun never sets? Or will France light the way for the world
column22:
as the superpower of the Sun King's dreams or the republic of Lafayette's?

—description from the publisher

column1: 118@Canvas@In Canvas
column2: you play as a painter competing in an art competition. Players will collect art cards
column3:
layering 3 of them together to create their own unique Painting. Each card contains a piece of artwork as well as a set of icons used during scoring. Icons will be revealed or hidden based on the way players choose to layer the cards making for an exciting puzzle. Paintings are scored based on a set of Scoring cards which will change each game. Once players have created and scored 3 paintings the game ends.

On your turn you may take an Art card or make a painting. Art cards are selected from a row of cards in the center of play. Each of these cards has a cost associated with their position. After selecting an Art card you must pay its cost by placing an Inspiration token on each of the cards to its left. If you do not have enough Inspiration tokens
column4:
you may not select that card. Any tokens on the card you have selected are kept for future turns. The far left card costs no Inspiration tokens to take.

If you have three or more Art cards you may choose to make a painting. Select 3 of your art cards
column5:
arrange them in any order and then score them by comparing the visible icons on your painting to the Scoring conditions.

Once all players have made 3 paintings the game ends.

The player with the most points wins!

—description from the publisher

Skull & Roses is the quintessence of bluffing
column2: a game in which everything is played in the players' heads. Each player plays a face-down card
column3: then each player in turn adds one more card – until someone feels safe enough to state that he can turn a number of cards face up and get only roses. Other players can then overbid him
column4: saying they can turn even more cards face up. The highest bidder must then turn that number of cards face up
column5: starting with his own. If he shows only roses
column6: he wins; if he reveals a skull
column7: he loses
column8:
placing one of his cards out of play. Two successful challenges wins the game. Skull & Roses is not a game of luck; it's a game of poker face and meeting eyes.

Skull & Roses Red features the same gameplay as Skull & Roses
column9: with the only change being alternate rules that allow each player to control two biker gangs. Both Skull & Roses Red and Skull are playable on their own

with each game containing six different biker gangs. Each Skull or Skull & Roses set can be combined with another to allow for games with more than six players.

 The Ãœberplay 2005 Edition has new art

column1: 129@The Mind@The Mind is more than just a game. It's an experiment
column2: a journey
column3: a team experience in which you can't exchange information
column4:
yet will become one to defeat all the levels of the game.

In more detail
column5: the deck contains cards numbered 1-100
column6: and during the game you try to complete 12
column8: or 8 levels of play with 2
column10: or 4 players. In a level
column11: each player receives a hand of cards equal to the number of the level: one card in level 1
column12: two cards in level 2
column13: etc. Collectively you must play these cards into the center of the table on a single discard pile in ascending order but you cannot communicate with one another in any way as to which cards you hold. You simply stare into one another's eyes
column14: and when you feel the time is right
column15: you play your lowest card. If no one holds a card lower than what you played
column16: great
column17: the game continues! If someone did
column18: all players discard face up all cards lower than what you played
column19:
and you lose one life.

You start the game with a number of lives equal to the number of players. Lose all your lives
column20: and you lose the game. You start with one shuriken as well
column21: and if everyone wants to use a shuriken
column22: each player discards their lowest card face up
column23: giving everyone information and getting you closer to completing the level. As you complete levels
column24: you might receive a reward of a shuriken or an extra life. Complete all the levels
column25:
and you win!

For an extra challenge

column1: 130@Wavelength@Wavelength is a social guessing game in which two teams compete to read each other's minds. Teams take turns rotating a dial to where they think a hidden bullseye is located on a spectrum. One of the players on your team — the Psychic — knows exactly where the bullseye is

column5: Sad Song - Happy Song
column6:
etc). The Psychic must then provide a clue that is *conceptually* where the bullseye is located between those two binaries.

For example
column7: if the card this round is HOT-COLD and the bullseye is slightly to the "cold" side of the centre
column8:
the Psychic needs to give a clue somewhere in that region. Perhaps "salad"?

After the Psychic gives their clue
column9: their team discusses where they think the bullseye is located and turns the dial to that location on that spectrum. The closer to the center of the bullseye the team guess
column10:
the more points they score!

@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/z4fbPdmJg_5yphJEvql4ZA__original/img/bP1gM8RC-o5iz20_WazBaBNDHnU=/0x0/filters:format(png)/pic4552862.png@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/z4fbPdmJg_5yphJEvql4ZA__thumb/img/bxLuHVLF-Y06jWRSKA-tuQ3YYcE=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic4552862.png@1.1189@45@2@12

column1:
131@No Thanks!@No Thanks! is a card game designed to be as simple as it is engaging.

The rules are simple.  Each turn
column2:
players have two options:

    play one of their chips to avoid picking up the current face-up card
    pick up the face-up card (along with any chips that have already been played on that card) and turn over the next card


However
column3: the choices aren't so easy as players compete to have the lowest score at the end of the game.  The deck of cards is numbered from 3 to 35
column4: with each card counting for a number of points equal to its face value.  Runs of two or more cards only count as the lowest value in the run - but nine cards are removed from the deck before starting
column5: so be careful looking for connectors.  Each chip is worth -1 point
column6:
but they can be even more valuable by allowing you to avoid drawing that unwanted card.

The first versions of the game supported up to five players
column7:
but a 2011 edition supports up to seven.

This game was originally published in Germany by Amigo as Geschenkt ...ist noch zu teuer!
column8: meaning Even given as a gift
column9: it is still too expensive!.  Amigo's international edition
column10: titled No Merci! (a delightful multi-lingual pun)
column11: had rules in several languages
column12:
including English.  The game has subsequently been released in other countries under an assortment of names.

@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/2DyxMVASynw87LRULZuyqA__original/img/IHLuH9f5dB6jJn74cdVdMixAUKg=/0x0/filters:format(jpeg)/pic4657706.jpg@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/2DyxMVASynw87LRULZuyqA__thumb/img/yIUSMoN8O5FeDZjXa4vreKj5Ogw=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic4657706.jpg@1.1353@20@3@7

column1: 132@Perudo@Liar's Dice
column2: a.k.a. Bluff
column3: Perudo or Dudo
column4: is a South American dice game in which each player is given five dice and cup to roll and hide them with. Players make successively higher declarations regarding the results of all the dice remaining in the game
column5: e.g. "there are ten sixes". However
column6: someone can always contest the bid. When that happens
column7: all the dice are revealed and either the bidder or the caller loses dice
column8:
depending on who was correct. The last player with dice is the winner.

As a public domain dice game
column9: there are a number of variants or similar games called Liar's Dice. This includes one that is often played with Poker Dice
column10: and differs from the marketed versions in that players only declare on their own hand's value (as opposed to all dice being in play)
column11:
using poker-hand values.

column1: 133@Snowdonia@The peaks of Snowdonia rise before you
column2: encased in mist
column3: their summits barely visible. The highest is Snowdon (Wyddfa) herself at 1
column4: 085 metres. The year is 1894
column5:
and the Snowdon Mountain Tramroad and Hotels Company Limited has been formed to build a branch line from Llanberis to the summit. You can scarcely believe it's possible!

In Snowdonia players represent work gangs providing labour for the construction of the Snowdon Mountain Railway. Unlike other train games you will have to excavate your way up a mountain side
column6: as well as make and lay the track
column7:
construct viaducts and stations. All this in competition with the weather of the Welsh mountains (and the game itself)!

You may be assisted by a train (though that's not always best) and you'll be able to collect essential materials from the Stock Yard. You will obtain special work contracts that give you bonuses.

Can you contribute more than the other players to the magnificence of the Snowdon Mountain Railway?

column1:
134@Combat Commander: Europe@Combat Commander: Europe is a card-driven board game covering tactical infantry combat in the European Theater of World War II. One player takes the role of the Axis (Germany) while another player commands the Allies (America or Russia). These two players will take turns playing one or more “Fate” cards from their hands in order to activate his units on the mapboard for various military functions.

Players attempt to achieve victory by moving their combat units across the game map to attack their opponent’s combat units and occupy as many objectives as possible. The degree to which a player succeeds or fails is measured by a scenario’s specific “Objective” chits
column2: the destruction of enemy units
column3:
and the exiting of friendly units off the opponent’s board edge.

A game of Combat Commander is divided into several measures of Game Time. There is no sequence of play to follow
column4: however: each Time segment is divided into a variable number of Player Turns
column5:
each of which may consist of one or more Fate Card "Orders" conducted by the active player. Fate Card "Actions" may generally be conducted by either player at any time. "Events" — both good and bad — will occur at random intervals to add a bit of chaos and uncertainty to each player’s perfect plan.

SCALE: Each hex of a Combat Commander map is roughly 100 feet of distance (about 30 meters). Each complete Player Phase abstractly represents several seconds of real time. Each complete measure of Game Time abstractly represents several minutes of real time.

Each unit in the game is approximated as either a single Leader
column6: a 5-man Team
column7: or a 10-man Squad. Radios — and individual weapons larger than a pistol
column8:
rifle or BAR — are represented by their own counters.

column1:
135@The Grizzled@The Grizzled is a cooperative game about survival in the trenches during the first World War where players win or lose together.

Each round
column2: the current team leader will choose how many cards every player draws. Then
column3: going around the table
column4: players must either play a card in their hand or back out of the mission. Each card represents either threats to the team (such as mortar shells and weather conditions) or negative personality traits (such as frightened or obsessive). At the end of the round
column5:
more cards are added to the draw deck. The game ends only if the players can deplete the draw deck as well as their hands without letting time run out.

If one threat shows up too many times
column6: the team fails the mission. The team must play their threats correctly in order to gain any progress. However
column7:
most of the information in a players hand remains secret throughout the game.

Planning
column8: teamwork
column9:
and a little luck are the tools you'll need to win this cooperative game for two to five players.

column1: 136@Cartographers@Queen Gimnax has ordered the reclamation of the northern lands. As a cartographer in her service
column2: you are sent to map this territory
column3: claiming it for the Kingdom of Nalos. Through official edicts
column4: the queen announces which lands she prizes most
column5: and you will increase your reputation by meeting her demands. But you are not alone in this wilderness. The Dragul contest your claims with their outposts
column6:
so you must draw your lines carefully to reduce their influence. Reclaim the greatest share of the queen’s desired lands and you will be declared the greatest cartographer in the kingdom.

In Cartographers: A Roll Player Tale
column7: players compete to earn the most reputation stars by the time four seasons have passed. Each season

players draw on their map sheets and earn reputation by carrying out the queen's edicts before the season is over. The player with the most reputation stars at the end of winter wins!

column1: 137@Fallout@Fallout is a post-nuclear adventure board game for one to four players. Based on the hit video game series by Bethesda Softworks

column5: fight ferocious enemies
column6:
and build the skills of their survivor as they attempt to complete challenging quests and balance feuding factions within the game.

As they advance their survivors' stories
column7: players come across new quests and individual targets
column8: leading them to gain influence. Who comes out ahead depends on how keenly and aggressively each player ventures through the game; however
column9: if a single faction is pushed to power too quickly
column10: the wasteland will be taken for their own

and the survivors conquered along with it.

column1:
138@Arkham Horror@
        The year is 1926
column2:
and it is the height of the Roaring Twenties. Flappers dance till dawn in smoke-filled speakeasies drinking alcohol supplied by rum runners and the mob. It's a celebration to end all celebrations in the aftermath of the war to end all wars.



        Yet a dark shadow grows in the city of Arkham. Alien entities known as Ancient Ones lurk in the emptiness beyond space and time
column3:
writhing at the gates between worlds. These gates have begun to open and must be closed before the Ancient Ones make our world their ruined domination.



        Only a handful of investigators stand against the Arkham Horror.  Will they Prevail? 


Arkham Horror is a cooperative adventure game themed around H.P Lovecraft's Cthulhu Mythos. Players choose from 16 Investigators and take to the streets of Arkham. Before the game
column4: one of the eight Ancient Ones is chosen and it's up to the Investigators to prevent it from breaking into our world. During the course of the game
column5: players will upgrade their characters by acquiring skills
column6: allies
column7: items
column8: weapons
column9: and spells. It's up to the players to clean out the streets of Arkham by fighting many different types of monsters
column10:
but their main goal is to close gates to other dimensions that are opening up around town. With too many gates open the Ancient One awakens and the players only have one last chance to save the world - defeat the Ancient One in combat!

heroes and support cards. Each will come with a series of mini-adventures and a story booklet that tells players what happens as they progress through the scenarios.

column1: 140@Lockup: A Roll Player Tale@During the Dragul Invasion of Nalos
column2: King Taron’s loyal soldiers throw captured minions into Kulbak Prison
column3: where enchanted gates and Construct guards make escape all but impossible. Once each year
column4:
Taron releases the toughest gang of war prisoners into the royal Colosseum.

You command a squadron of these captured Dragul. Gather goons and craft contraband to raise your reputation. Keep your suspicion with the guards low while establishing yourself as the most powerful crew in Kulbak. In six short days
column5:
Taron may offer you the chance to fight for your freedom.

Lockup: A Roll Player Tale is a competitive worker-allocation game for one to five players. In the game
column6: players manage groups of minions -- gnolls
column7: kobolds
column8: bugbears
column9: goblins
column10:
or insectoids -- locked up in Kulbak Prison.

Each round
column11: players try to keep their suspicion from the guards under control while allocating their crew to different locations within Kulbak. The player with the strongest crew in each location at the end of each round gains the most resources
column12: hires the most powerful crew
column13: and builds the most powerful items
column14: increases their reputation. The player with the highest reputation at the end of six rounds
column15:
wins the game.

Lockup is a worker placement game set in the Roll Player universe.

Play takes place over three phases in each round:

     Roll Call - Players take turns placing their minions in different parts of the prison
column16: some face up showing a unit's strength and some face down
column17:
hiding the strength from the other players.
     Lights Out - Each area with minions is scored based on the strength of each player's crew. Players receive resources and have the opportunity to recruit goons and build items.

column18: and the guards patrol the dungeon. Players with high suspicion are raided
column19:
and their chambers are searched.

column1: 145@Star Wars: Imperial Assault@Star Wars: Imperial Assault is a strategy board game of tactical combat and missions for two to five players
