 Now you can join them. You will gain access to prefabricated spaceship components cleverly made from sewer pipes. Can you build a space ship durable enough to weather storms of meteors? column8:
and being the furthest along the track at the end of the flying phase.

Building happens in real time and has players build their personal space ships by grabbing tiles from the middle of the table before the timer runs out. Tiles start out facedown so they won't know what they have until they take it
column9: but they may choose to return it faceup if they don't want it. They must place the tiles they keep in a legal manner in their space ship. Usually this just means lining up the connectors appropriately (single to single
column10: double to double
column11: universal to anything) but also includes proper positioning of guns and engines. Tiles represent a variety of things including guns
column12: engines
column13: storage containers
column14: crew cabins
column15: shields
column16: and batteries. They may also peek at the cards they will encounter in phase 2
column17:
but they must sacrifice building time to do this. At any time players may call their ships finished and take an order marker from the center.

Once building is completed
column18: and ships have been checked for errors
column19: the flight begins. The flight cards are shuffled and player markers are placed on the flight board according to the order markers taken. Cards are revealed one at a time and players interact with them in order. They may include things such as pirates
column20: abandoned vessels
column21: disease outbreaks
column22: meteor showers
column23: worlds with goods to pick up
column24: player-on-player combat zones
column25:
and other various things.

Most of the cards will cause players to move back on the flight track and they must decide if the delay is worth their efforts. When all the cards are encountered players sell any goods they have collected
column26: collect their rewards for finishing in first
column27: second
column28: or third place or having the most intact ship
column29: and then lose some credits for damaged components. Space can be a very dangerous place and it is not uncommon to see your ship break into smaller and smaller pieces or lose some very valuable cargo off the side. If your ship gets damaged too much you can get knocked out of the race
column30:
so be careful!

3 rounds of this are done
column31:
and in each round players get a bigger board to build a ship that can hold more components. After the 3rd round the player with the most credits wins!

column1: 147@Cribbage@Cribbage is a card game invented in the early 17th century
column2:
based on the earlier game Noddy. It is played with a deck of standard playing cards and a signature piece of equipment called the cribbage board.  Cribbage is traditionally played as a 2 player game.

In the version usually played today
column3: each player is dealt a hand of 6 cards
column4: from which they discard 2 into a special pile called the Crib.  One card is then cut from the draw pile and turned face up - it is considered part of each player's hand and of the Crib.  The players then play cards in turn
column5: scoring points for hitting certain totals
column6:
or for making sets or sequences.  Score is kept by moving pegs along tracks on the cribbage board.  This is repeated until both players have exhausted their hand of cards.

Next
column7: each player picks up their hand and determines all possible scoring combinations
column8:
pegging points again on the cribbage board.  The dealer then picks up the Crib and scores it for all possible points.  Then the cards are shuffled and the deal alternates.  The winner is the first to reach 121 points.

The origin date listed for this game is approximate.

column1: 148@Mind MGMT: The Psychic Espionage Game.@Working from the shadows
column2: Mind MGMT once used its psychically-powered agents to put a stop to global crises. However
column3: absolute power corrupts absolutely
column4: and Mind MGMT is now rotting from the inside. To tighten its iron grip on the world stage
column5: Mind MGMT deploys covert operatives around the world to recruit other psychically-attuned individuals to their side. How can this enigmatic organization
column6: hell bent on global domination
column7:
be defeated?

Thankfully
column8: a few renegade agents have figured out that Mind MGMT has been compromised and have defected
column9:
turning their backs on the syndicate. They now use their own psychic abilities to prevent Mind MGMT from achieving its nefarious goals.

In Mind MGMT: The Psychic Espionage "Game."
column10: one player controls Mind MGMT and must scour the city for new recruits. They move around on a secret map
column11:
trying to visit locations that match one of their three randomly drawn feature cards. They can also use their four Immortals to protect locations from being exposed.

All other players control the rogue agents who must try to stop Mind MGMT before it's too late! They ask questions to the Recruiter and deduce their whereabouts from the answers they receive. Rogue agents can use dry-erase "mental notes" to track all the information they're given.

Mind MGMT wins by either collecting twelve recruits or surviving sixteen turns. The rogue agents can win only by capturing Mind MGMT
column12:
which they do when they believe they're on the same block as Mind MGMT.

—description from the publisher

column1: 149@Tzolk'in: The Mayan Calendar@Tzolkin: The Mayan Calendar presents a new game mechanism: dynamic worker placement. Players representing different Mayan tribes place their workers on giant connected gears
column2:
and as the gears rotate they take the workers to different action spots.

During a turn
column3: players can either (a) place one or more workers on the lowest visible spot of the gears or (b) pick up one or more workers. When placing workers
column4: they must pay corn
column5: which is used as a currency in the game. When they pick up a worker
column6: they perform certain actions depending on the position of the worker. Actions located "later" on the gears are more valuable
column7: so it's wise to let the time work for you – but players cannot skip their turn; if they have all their workers on the gears
column8:
they have to pick some up. 

The game ends after one full revolution of the central Tzolkin gear. There are many paths to victory. Pleasing the gods by placing crystal skulls in deep caves or building many temples are just two of those many paths...

column1:
150@Blood Rage@"Life is Battle; Battle is Glory; Glory is ALL"

In Blood Rage
column2: each player controls their own Viking clan’s warriors
column3: leader
column4: and ship. Ragnarök has come
column5: and it’s the end of the world! It’s the Vikings’ last chance to go down in a blaze of glory and secure their place in Valhalla at Odin’s side! For a Viking there are many pathways to glory. You can invade and pillage the land for its rewards
column6: crush your opponents in epic battles
column7: fulfill quests
column8: increase your clan's stats
column9: or even die gloriously either in battle or from Ragnarök
column10:
the ultimate inescapable doom.

Most player strategies are guided by the cards drafted at the beginning of each of the three game rounds (or Ages). These “Gods’ Gifts” grant you numerous boons for your clan including: increased Viking strength and devious battle strategies
column11: upgrades to your clan
column12: or even the aid of legendary creatures from Norse mythology. They may also include various quests
column13: from dominating specific provinces
column14: to having lots of your Vikings sent to Valhalla. Most of these cards are aligned with one of the Norse gods
column15: hinting at the kind of strategy they support. For example
column16: Thor gives more glory for victory in battle
column17: Heimdall grants you foresight and surprises
column18: Tyr strengthens you in battle
column19: while the trickster Loki actually rewards you for losing battles
column20:
or punishes the winner.

Players must choose their strategies carefully during the draft phase
column21: but also be ready to adapt and react to their opponents’ strategies as the action phase unfolds. Battles are decided not only by the strength of the figures involved
column22: but also by cards played in secret. By observing your opponent’s actions and allegiances to specific gods
column23: you may predict what card they are likely to play
column24: and plan accordingly. Winning battles is not always the best course of action
column25:
as the right card can get you even more rewards by being crushed. The only losing strategy in Blood Rage is to shy away from battle and a glorious death!

column1: 151@Dominant Species: Marine@Sixty-Something Millions of Years Ago — A great ice age has ended. With massive warming altering the globe
column2:
another titanic struggle for supremacy has unwittingly commenced between the varying animal species.

Dominant Species: Marine is a game that abstractly recreates a small portion of ancient history: the ending of an onerous ice age and what that entails for the living creatures trying to adapt to the slowly-changing earth.

Each player will assume the role of one of four major aquatic-based animal classes — reptiles
column3: fish
column4:
cephalopod or crustacean. Each begins the game more or less in a state of natural balance in relation to one another. But that won’t last: It is indeed “survival of the fittest.”

Through wily action pawn placement
column5: you will attempt to thrive in as many different habitats as possible in order to claim powerful card effects. You will also want to propagate your individual species in order to earn victory points for your animal. You will be aided in these endeavors via speciation
column6: migration and adaptation actions
column7:
among others.

All of this eventually leads to the end game – the final ascent of a vast tropical ocean and its shorelines – where the player having accumulated the most victory points will have their animal crowned the Dominant Species.

But somebody better become dominant quickly
column8:
because there’s a large asteroid heading this way....

Game Play

The large hexagonal tiles are used throughout the game to create an ever-expanding interpretation of the main ocean on earth as it might have appeared tens of millions of years ago. The smaller Hydrothermal Vent tiles will be placed atop some of the larger tiles throughout play
column9:
converting them into Vents in the process.

The action pawns drive the game. Each pawn allows a player to perform the various actions that can be taken—such as speciation
column10: environmental change
column11: migration or evolution. When placed on the action display
column12:
a pawn will immediately trigger that particular action for its owning player. Dominant Species: Marine includes new “special” pawns that can be acquired during the course of play. These special pawns have enhanced placement capabilities over the “basic” pawns that each player begins the game with.

Generally
column13: players will be trying to enhance their own animal’s survivability while simultaneously trying to hinder that of their opponents’—hopefully collecting valuable victory points along the way. The various cards will aid in these efforts
column14: giving players useful one-time abilities
column15: ongoing benefits
column16:
or an opportunity for recurring VP gains.

Throughout the game species cubes will be added to
column17: moved about on
column18:
and removed from the tiles in play (“earth”). Element disks will be added to and removed from both animals and earth.

When the game ends
column19:
players will conduct a final scoring of each tile and score their controlled special pawns—after which the player controlling the animal with the highest VP total wins the game.

Dominant Species Veterans

For players of the original Dominant Species
column20:
this iteration introduces several key evolutions to the system (pun definitely intended): 

     Actions are taken immediately whenever a pawn is placed instead of waiting to execute actions after all pawns are on the board. This gives players a bit more flexibility in their strategy
column21: doesn’t increase game time when more pawns are acquired by players
column22:
and lessens the brain-burn quite a bit since it alleviates the burden of having to plan out an entire turn in advance. 
     Domination is no longer on a per-tile basis
column23: and is no longer ‘competitive’ with other players. In this game you check dominance for each element type over the entire earth
column24:
and whether or not you dominate an element type is independent of whether one or more opponents also dominate it. Domination of an element is how you acquire – and try to maintain – control of the special pawns.
     Animals no longer have default special abilities. Now
column25: players are dealt 3 Trait cards during setup
column26:
choosing one to keep and putting the others back in the box. The chosen Trait gives their animal one of eighteen unique abilities spread amongst the Trait cards. 
     Acquiring special pawns through domination gives a player great flexibility in planning and executing a strategy. Special pawns can ‘bump’ an opponent’s basic pawn in order to take an action that would otherwise be blocked. They can be placed anywhere on the action display (where basic pawns must be placed in top-to-bottom order only). There are powerful action spaces where only a special pawn can be placed. And at the end of the game
column27:
each special pawn awards its owner VPs according to its highest achieved dominance value.


—description from the publisher

column1: 152@Acquire@In Acquire
column2: each player strategically invests in businesses
column3: trying to retain a majority of stock.  As the businesses grow with tile placements
column4: they also start merging
column5: giving the majority stockholders of the acquired business sizable bonuses
column6: which can then be used to reinvest into other chains.  All of the investors in the acquired company can then cash in their stocks for current value or trade them 2-for-1 for shares of the newer
column7:
larger business.  The game is a race to acquire the greatest wealth.

History of Acquire: This Sid Sackson classic has taken many different forms over the years depending on the publisher
column8:
yet the rules and game play have stayed the same. The 1966 version of the 3M bookshelf edition included rules for a 2-player variant. The original version is part of the 3M Bookshelf Series.

Many books and websites incorrectly list this as a 1962 publication as the 3M Company used previously copyrighted artwork when they released the game in 1964. 3M actually received the idea for the game of "Vacations" from Sid Sackson in May of 1963 and decided to take his idea and put it into artwork they had developed the year before for a game called "ACQUIRE." 3M's original game idea for a game called ACQUIRE must not have been very good so they decided to take Sid's idea of Vacations and put it into their concept of ACQUIRE. They released some limited test market games in 8 Midwestern U.S. cities in December of 1963 with a box that had a 1963 copyright. These games had Sid's original rules. When 3M released the mass market games in 1964
column9:
they had taken liberties with some of Sid's original ideas and changed some rules and game play to match their production desires. They released them with outer boxes that were copyrighted 1962 and inner boxes with rules that were dated 1963.

December 1963 - Test Market World Map Wood Tile Edition
1964 - Dated 1962/63 wood tiles
column10:
chipboard with plastic overlay & stocks with printed backs
1965 - Dated 1962/63 plastic tiles
column11:
chipboard with plastic overlay & stocks with printed backs (last edition made with printed backs until 1999)
1966 - Dated 1962/66 plastic tiles
column12:
chipboard with plastic overlay & non-wax coated stocks (Only edition with these stocks)
1968 - Dated 1968/66 plastic tiles
column13:
clear plastic board with paper underlay (Both 1966 inner box games have a lot of mixed parts)
1971 - Dated 1968/71 plastic tiles
column14:
yellow hard plastic board
1975 - 3M sells rights for game of ACQUIRE to the Avalon Hill Company
1976 - Dated 1976 plastic tiles
column15: yellow hard plastic board
column16: redesigned money
column17: no inner box (This edition was also produced in 1977
column21:
& 86)
1989 - Dated 1976 Gray box edition with new box artwork same contents as regular 1976 editions (This edition was also produced in 1992)
1995 - Dated 1995 Large box cardboard edition with chipboard board and tiles
column22:
Special Powers Variant Tiles inspired by German editions
1997 - Avalon Hill sells the rights to the game of ACQUIRE to Hasbro
1999 - Dated 1999 Large box with large plastic board and tiles
column23: 3D company buildings
column24: redesigned stocks & money
column25:
large info cards
2006 - Hasbro assigns rights for the game of ACQUIRE to their subsidiary
column26:
Wizards of the Coast
2006 - Lloyd's Rules of ACQUIRE are made public
column27:
two major rule changes that help to bring the balance of the game of ACQUIRE back to the  intentions of Sid Sackson's original ideas 
2008 - Dated 2008 cardboard edition with chipboard board & tiles
column28:
redesigned stocks & money
2016 - Dated 2016 The current affordable mass-market edition. It looks at first sight to be similar to previous modern editions
column29: but has been criticised for the use of inferior design choices such as hard-to-read grey-on-grey embossed slots and the unusual tile fonts. It contains modified rules and a slightly smaller playing grid. Although these changes have been criticised for not ultimately improving upon Sackson's original design
column30:
they are generally regarded as not being too damaging to it.

In the time period in which the game Nusfjord is set

column1: 159@Dominant Species@90
column2:
000 B.C. — A great ice age is fast approaching. Another titanic struggle for global supremacy has unwittingly commenced between the varying animal species. 
Dominant Species is a game that abstractly recreates a tiny portion of ancient history: the ponderous encroachment of an ice age and what that entails for the living creatures trying to adapt to the slowly-changing earth. 
Each player will assume the role of one of six major animal classes—mammal
column3: reptile
column4: bird
column5: amphibian
column6: arachnid
column7:
or insect. Each begins the game more or less in a state of natural balance in relation to one another. But that won’t last: It is indeed "survival of the fittest".
Through wily action pawn placement
column8: players will strive to become dominant on as many different terrain tiles as possible in order to claim powerful card effects. Players will also want to propagate their individual species in order to earn victory points for their particular animal. Players will be aided in these endeavors via speciation
column9: migration
column10: and adaptation actions
column11:
among others. 
All of this eventually leads to the end game—the final ascent of the ice age—where the player having accumulated the most victory points will have his animal crowned the Dominant Species. 
But somebody better become dominant quickly
column12:
because it’s getting mighty cold...

Game Play
The large hexagonal tiles are used throughout the game to create an ever-expanding interpretation of earth as it might have appeared a thousand centuries ago. The smaller tundra tiles will be placed atop the larger tiles—converting them into tundra in the process—as the ice age encroaches.
The cylindrical action pawns (or "AP"s) drive the game. Each AP will allow a player to perform the various actions that can be taken
column13: such as speciation
column14: environmental change
column15: migration
column16: or glaciation. After being placed on the action display during the Planning Phase
column17:
an AP will trigger that particular action for the owning player during the Execution Phase.
Generally
column18: players will be trying to enhance their own animal’s survivability while simultaneously trying to hinder that of their opponents’—hopefully collecting valuable victory points (or "VP"s) along the way. The various cards will aid in these efforts
column19:
giving players useful one-time abilities or an opportunity for recurring VP gains.
Throughout the game
column20: species cubes will be added to
column21: moved about in
column22:
and removed from the tiles in play (the "earth"). Element disks will be added to and removed from both animals and earth. 
When the game ends
column23:
players will conduct a final scoring of each tile—after which the player controlling the animal with the highest VP total wins.

column1: 173@Lobbyist: Shaping the Vote@In the world of politics it seems nothing is every completely clear and many c operations work hard and spends millions to see that their interests are put before all others. In the game of Lobbyist - Shaping the Vote
column2: players get to try their hand at lobbying
column3:
working to influence politicians to vote their desired way while competing with other lobbyist who are working towards a different means and outcome.

Lobbyist - Shaping the Vote is a game where players take on the role of Lobbyist trying to influence the political committee to voting in their desired way. Each player is a lobbyist starting with $50
column4: 000. The board is a political committee voting on five issues
column5: Education
column6: Health and Welfare
column7: Infrastructure
column8: Taxes and Revenue
column9: Crime and Punishment. Each issue's influence is represented by a dice value and Lobbyist play cards from their hand to increase and decrease those dice values. Around the board will be 5
column11: or 9 (depending on difficulty of play) unique politicians
column12: all with a voting position value for each of the five issues. Politicians will not vote yes until the die values matches or exceeds their voting position values. Each lobbyist it working to gather desired votes on these issues
column13: wanting to gather yes votes on two issues
column14: and no votes on two issues
column15:
being indifferent on the fifth issue (each player lobbyist card has different yes/no goals on their cards).

Throughout the game players will have cards in hand and will draw and play a card on their turn. Most cards will allow then to influence one or more of the voting issue dice. Vote cards are shuffled into the deck and when one of these is drawn the player immediately plays the Vote card and the committee votes on the issues. Prior to voting though the Lobbyist all have one final chance to influence their politicians by either taking a vote action (indicted on the cards)
column16: or by spending up to $20
column17: 000 of their money to increase or decrease dice values. Once each player has had a chance to take or pass on an action
column18:
the politicians vote on the issues and players get yes/no vote tokens for their successful lobbying. Game ends after the fifth vote happens and final scores are tallied.

I came up with this game idea after sitting through a number of political action committee meetings and hearing the same info numerous times
column19:
so I started jotting ideas. The can has been play tested some and everyone I have played with has enjoyed the game at this point.

—description from the designer

column1: 174@Cuba Libre@In December 1956
column2: paroled rebel Fidel Castro returned to Cuba to launch his revolution with virtually no political base and—after a disastrous initial encounter with government forces—a total of just 12 men.  Two years later
column3: through masterful propaganda and factional maneuver
column4: Castro
column5: his brother Raúl
column6:
and iconic revolutionary Che Guevara had united disparate guerrillas and exploited Cubans’ deep opposition to their dictator Fulgencio Batista y Zaldívar.  Castro’s takeover of the country became a model for Leftist insurgency.

Castro’s Insurgency

Following up on GMT Games’ Andean Abyss about insurgency in modern Colombia
column7: the next volume in the COIN Series
column8: Cuba Libre
column9: takes 1 to 4 players into the Cuban Revolution.  Castro’s “26 July Movement” must expand from its bases in the Sierra Maestra mountains to fight its way to Havana.  Meanwhile
column10: anti-communist student groups
column11: urban guerrillas
column12: and expatriates try to de-stabilize the Batista regime from inside and out
column13: while trying not to pave the way for a new dictatorship under Castro.  Batista’s Government must maintain steam to counter the twin insurgency
column14: while managing two benefactors:  its fragile US Alliance and its corrupting Syndicate skim.  And in the midst of the turmoil
column15:
Meyer Lansky and his Syndicate bosses will jockey to keep their Cuban gangster paradise alive.

COIN Series
column16:
Volume II

Cuba Libre will be easy to learn for Andean Abyss players—both volumes share the same innovative Series: COIN (GMT) system.  Like Volume I
column17:
Cuba Libre is equally playable solitaire or by multiple players up to 4—and with a shorter time to completion than Andean Abyss.  But Cuba Libre’s situation and strategic challenges will be new.  A deck of 48 fresh events brings 1950s Cuba to life and includes …

• The Twelve:  The first wave’s escape to the Sierra Maestra—inspirational legend or harbinger of defeat?
• El Che and Raúl:  Brilliant in the field
column18:
or bungling hostage-takers?
• Operation Fisherman:  Can the rebels pull off a second invasion?
• General Strike:  Urban disruption or rebel embarrassment?
• Radio Rebelde:  Are the masses tuning in
column19:
or just the Army direction finders?
• Pact of Caracas:  Can the rebels unite?
• Armored Cars:  Mobile striking power
column20:
but in whose hands?
• Rolando Masferrer:  Brutal pro-government tactics—will they help or hurt?
• Fat Butcher:  Can the Mob’s enforcer protect its casinos?
• Sinatra:  Frankie’s Havana show a boom or bust
column21:
and who collects?
… and much more.

New twists match the COIN Series system to the situation in 1950s Cuba:

• It’s the insurgents who build lasting capabilities
column22:
while the Government is limited to fleeting bursts of momentum.
• The Syndicate’s bases are Casinos—expensive to build
column23:
but so important to Cuba no army will destroy them.  
• Syndicate special activities include calling in the “muscle” of Government troops and police to protect mob assets.  
• Stacks of Syndicate cash awaiting launder can fall in anyone’s hands—even the corrupt Government’s.
• The Government has its own terror tactic—reprisals—and can skim a portion of Syndicate profits.
• The eroding US Alliance with Batista overshadows all Government actions
column24:
not just through aid levels but also through the day-to-day ability of troops and police to operate.
• Even if Batista flees
column25:
the struggle may not end—the counterrevolutionary government may even become stronger!

Multiplayer
column26: 2-Player
column27:
Solitaire

Cuba Libre provides up to 4 players with contrasting roles and overlapping victory conditions for rich diplomatic interaction. For 2- or 3-player games
column28: players can represent alliances of factions
column29: or the game system can control non-player factions . Or a single player as the Cuban Revolutionaries can attempt to topple Batista and seize power for themselves. The non-player sides will fight one another as well as the players
column30:
but too much power in the hands of any one of them will mean player defeat.

More COIN Series Volumes to Come

Andean Abyss and now Cuba Libre present a game system on modern insurgency readily adaptable to other conflicts
column31: particularly those featuring the interaction of many sides (thus the name COunterINsurgency Series). A rich and under-represented history of guerrilla warfare beckons
column32: as modern insurgency offers virtually unlimited
column33:
under-gamed topics for the COIN Series.  Volume III is A Distant Plainâ€”Insurgency in Afghanistan.  Volume IV is Fire in the Lakeâ€”Insurgency in Vietnam.

column1: 178@Sidereal Confluence@Sidereal Confluence: Trading and Negotiation in the Elysian Quadrant is a singularly unique trading and negotiation game for 4-9 players. Over the course of the game
column2: each race must trade and negotiate with the rest to acquire the resource cubes necessary to fund their economy and allow it to produce goods for the next turn. Scheming
column3: dealing
column4: and mutually beneficial agreements are key to success. While technically a competitive game
column5: Sidereal Confluence has a cooperative feel during the trading phase as no race has the ability to thrive on its own. Trade well
column6:
and you'll develop technologies and colonize planets to form a civilization that is the envy of the galaxy.

Each player chooses one of the nine unique and asymmetrical alien races that have come together to form a trade federation in their quadrant. Each race has its own deck of cards representing all the existing and future technologies it might research. Some races also have other cards related to unique features of their culture. These cards represent portions of the culture's economy and require spending some number of cubes to use
column7: resulting in an output of more cubes
column8: ships
column9: and possibly victory points. Since each culture's outputs rarely match their inputs
column10: players need to trade goods with one another to run their converters to create the resources they truly need to run their society most efficiently and have an effective economy. Almost everything is negotiable
column11: including colonies
column12: ships
column13:
and all kinds of resources.

Each game round contains an open trading phase in which all players can negotiate and execute deals for cubes
column14: ships
column15: colonies
column16: even the temporary use of technologies! Players with enough resources can also research technologies
column17: upgrade colonies
column18: and spend resources on their race's special cards during this phase. Once complete
column19: all players simultaneously run their economies
column20: spending resources to gain more resources. The Confluence follows
column21: starting with players sharing newly researched technologies with all other races and following with bidding to acquire new colonies and research teams. Researching a new technology grants many victory points for the prestige of helping galactic society advance. When one race builds a new technology
column22:
it is shared with everyone else. Technologies can be upgraded when combined with other technologies.

The ultimate goal is victory points
column23: which are acquired by researching technologies
column24: using your economy to convert resources to goods
column25:
and converting your leftover goods into points at the end of the game.

The game is almost all simultaneous play.

Sidereal Confluence: Remastered Edition features the same gameplay as the first edition of the game from 2017
column26: but features an updated card layout
column27: a teaching guide
column28:
and an improved rulebook for easy set-up and learning with more visual examples and clear key terms.

column1: 181@The Manhattan Project: Energy Empire@From the ashes of war

column3: commerce
column4: and government by acquiring resources

not an expansion.

The major threat in Energy Empire is not war

column1: 183@Sprawlopolis@Jackhammers chattering

column1: 184@Cthulhu: Death May Die@In Cthulhu: Death May Die

at some point during the game you'll probably fail to mitigate your dice rolls properly and your insanity will cause you to do something terrible — or maybe advantageous. Hard to know for sure.

column1: 185@Mysterium@In the 1920s
column2: Mr. MacDowell
column3: a gifted astrologer
column4: immediately detected a supernatural being upon entering his new house in Scotland. He gathered eminent mediums of his time for an extraordinary séance
column5:
and they have seven hours to make contact with the ghost and investigate any clues that it can provide to unlock an old mystery.

Unable to talk
column6: the amnesiac ghost communicates with the mediums through visions
column7: which are represented in the game by illustrated cards. The mediums must decipher the images to help the ghost remember how he was murdered: Who did the crime? Where did it take place? Which weapon caused the death? The more the mediums cooperate and guess well
column8:
the easier it is to catch the right culprit.

In Mysterium
column9: a reworking of the game system present in Tajemnicze Domostwo
column10: one player takes the role of ghost while everyone else represents a medium. To solve the crime
column11: the ghost must first recall (with the aid of the mediums) all of the suspects present on the night of the murder. A number of suspect
column12: location and murder weapon cards are placed on the table
column13:
and the ghost randomly assigns one of each of these in secret to a medium.

Each hour (i.e.
column14: game turn)
column15: the ghost hands one or more vision cards face up to each medium
column16: refilling their hand to seven each time they share vision cards. These vision cards present dreamlike images to the mediums
column17: with each medium first needing to deduce which suspect corresponds to the vision cards received. Once the ghost has handed cards to the final medium
column18: they start a two-minute sandtimer. Once a medium has placed their token on a suspect
column19:
they may also place clairvoyancy tokens on the guesses made by other mediums to show whether they agree or disagree with those guesses.

After time runs out
column20: the ghost reveals to each medium whether the guesses were correct or not. Mediums who guessed correctly move on to guess the location of the crime (and then the murder weapon)
column21: while those who didn't keep their vision cards and receive new ones next hour corresponding to the same suspect. Once a medium has correctly guessed the suspect
column22: location and weapon
column23:
they move their token to the epilogue board and receive one clairvoyancy point for each hour remaining on the clock. They can still use their remaining clairvoyancy tokens to score additional points.

If one or more mediums fail to identify their proper suspect
column24: location and weapon before the end of the seventh hour
column25: then the ghost has failed and dissipates
column26: leaving the mystery unsolved. If
column27: however
column28: they have all succeeded
column29:
then the ghost has recovered enough of its memory to identify the culprit.

Mediums then group their suspect
column30: location and weapon cards on the table and place a number by each group. The ghost then selects one group
column31: places the matching culprit number face down on the epilogue board
column32: picks three vision cards — one for the suspect
column33: one for the location
column34: and one for the weapon — then shuffles these cards. Players who have achieved few clairvoyancy points flip over one vision card at random
column35:
then secretly vote on which suspect they think is guilty; players with more points then flip over a second vision card and vote; then those with the most points see the final card and vote.

If a majority of the mediums have identified the proper suspect
column36: with ties being broken by the vote of the most clairvoyant medium
column37: then the killer has been identified and the ghost can now rest peacefully. If not

column1: 195@Mythic Battles: Pantheon@Hera

The underworld trembled from the blow even as a legion of fresh souls ran down the river Styx. Would that have been the extent of the underworld's involvement however...

Rome's goal was to break through the island chain of Sicily

column7: paying resources if needed or collecting resources or interacting with other players in various ways. (Players have individual boards with special powers on which to organize their cards
column8: and the boards are double-sided). Each player then chooses another card from the deck they were passed
column9: and the process repeats until players have six cards in play from that age. After three ages
column10:
the game ends.

In essence
column11: 7 Wonders is a card development game. Some cards have immediate effects
column12: while others provide bonuses or upgrades later in the game. Some cards provide discounts on future purchases. Some provide military strength to overpower your neighbors and others give nothing but victory points. Each card is played immediately after being drafted
column13: so you'll know which cards your neighbor is receiving and how her choices might affect what you've already built up. Cards are passed left-right-left over the three ages
column14:
so you need to keep an eye on the neighbors in both directions.

Though the box of earlier editions is listed as being for 3–7 players
column15:
there is an official 2-player variant included in the instructions.

column1: 203@Ground Floor@The day has come. The paperwork is complete
column2: the registration filed
column3: and the business cards purchased – you're open for business! So now what? Where do you spend your time? Where do you spend your money? Which tasks are most important? What should take priority? Should you hire new employees? Or maybe invest in a marketing campaign? These are just some of the decisions facing you as a fresh entrepreneur who dreams of running a successful business. You must excel at balancing your time
column4:
money and staff because all are scarce and all are required to thrive.

So barter with your fellow colleagues
column5: manage your staff
column6: collect information
column7: expand your office
column8: or schedule your next product shipment. It's up to you – after all
column9: it's your business. Of course
column10: no matter which route you decide to take to reach that corner office at the top of the tallest skyscraper
column11:
you must start with everyone else...

...on the Ground Floor!

Over the course of the game
column12:
you will:


    Convert your employees' time into info
column13: money
column14:
and results.
    Adapt to changing economic conditions and brace for what's ahead. 
    Produce
column15: promote
column16:
and sell your goods in the marketplace.
    Build your company brand through marketing campaigns.
    Challenge other players' enterprises for success and prestige.
    Grow your business and build your high-rise!


@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/b8mrYfdRmAFLAmytvRZpSQ__original/img/KUzRrfQby7qoxq9vq5OamPiCtJw=/0x0/filters:format(jpeg)/pic1560952.jpg@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/b8mrYfdRmAFLAmytvRZpSQ__thumb/img/DzeBYUePyeSpzO0FN0xRFxP1HAg=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic1560952.jpg@3.7216@150@2@6

column1: 204@Targi@Unlike in other cultures
column2: the desert Tuareg men
column3: known as Targi
column4: cover their faces whereas women of the tribe do not wear veils. They run the household and they have the last word at home in the tents. Different families are divided into tribes
column5: headed by the ‘Imascheren’ (or nobles). As leader of a Tuareg tribe
column6: players trade goods from near (such as dates and salt) and far (like pepper)
column7: in order to obtain gold and other benefits
column8: and enlarge their family. In each round their new offerings are made. Cards are a means to an end
column9:
in order to obtain the popular tribe cards.

The board consists of a 5x5 grid: a border of 16 squares with printed action symbols and then 9 blank squares in the centre onto which cards are dealt. Meeples are placed one at a time on the spaces at the edges of the board (not including corner squares). You cannot place a meeple on a square the opponent has a meeple on already
column10: nor on a square facing opponent's meeple. Once all meeples are placed
column11:
players then execute the actions on the border squares the meeples are on and also take the cards from the centre that match the row and column of the border meeples.

The game is predominantly scored and won by playing tribal cards to your display. These give advantages during the game and victory points at the end. Usually cards are played (or discarded) immediately once drawn. A single card can be kept in hand but then requires a special action to play it (or to discard it to free the hand spot for another card). Each card has a cost in goods to play. Goods are obtained either from border spaces or from goods cards.

The display (for scoring) consists of 3 rows of 4 cards that are filled from left to right and cannot be moved once placed (barring some special cards). There is also a balance to be found between the victory point score on the cards themselves (1-3 VP per tribal card) and in the combinations per row (a full row of 4 identical card types gets you an additional 4 VP
column12:
and a full row of 4 distinct card types gets you 2 VP).

The winner at the end of the game is the player with the most victory points.

@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/wHg4fOf48cs1kw1PDOk1tQ__original/img/St4ABQhpauYiq4Mt6-f38JtLOjM=/0x0/filters:format(jpeg)/pic3958793.jpg@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/wHg4fOf48cs1kw1PDOk1tQ__thumb/img/6l-jqYlfECK1SVSsUs7FXUheKzQ=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic3958793.jpg@2.3446@60@2@2

column1: 205@Arkwright@In Arkwright players run up to four factories in England during the late 18th Century. Your goal is to have the most valuable block of own shares. Thus
column2:
you must increase your share value and buy shares from the bank.

To run the factories
column3: you need workers. When hiring Workers
column4:
demand is automatically created. But of course you want to replace your expensive workers (wage 2-5) by machines (1). To have more output from your factories you may employ new Workers or improve your factory to the next technical level.

You fix the price for your goods during an action round. To enhance your chances of selling goods
column5: you improve your factories to higher levels
column6: increase the quality and make some sales promotion. The higher these factors
column7: the better are your chances of success - the higher the price
column8:
the lower.

Each player has an own set of "action tokens" like "build and modernize factories"
column9: "employ new workers"
column10: "improve quality" etc. On your turn you place one of those tokens on one of the free spaces in your line of the "Administration board" and pay the according administration costs
column11: ranging from 2 to 10 (even numbers). Some actions depend on how much you paid
column12: i.e. you may buy more machines with one single action
column13: when you pay more (= use a higher space
column14: which is then blocked for the rest of the round). During the game your actions become more and more effective by new tokens
column15: i.e. allow you to buy 3 machines in a single turn instead of 2
column16:
increase quality 2 levels instead of only 1...).

After each round of actions one kind of factories is active and you have to pay for all your workers and machines there
column17:
then sell the manufactured products. The value of your shares increases for sold products and best quality.

Goods may also be traded to the colonies by ship - provided you have a contract with the monopoly of the East Indian Company.

After four turns each of the factories has produced and the round ends. Players remove the action tokens from the administration board and reveal an event token. After 5 rounds the player with the most valuable block of shares wins. Neither being to be the one with the most shares nor being the one with the highest share value guarantees victory.

Arkwright allows you to act in different ways. Run all four factories with most possible output
column18: set the focus on only two factories and improve them more than the others can; use shipping to colony or focus on the home market. In any way you have to react to the opponents and their strategy. Enter markets with deficit in supply or give up business where the other players start to push you out. Buy shares when they are cheap and increase the value
column19:
or first make money and buy shares later.

To get familiar with the market mechanics you may start with a 120 minutes version "Spinning Jenny"
column20: but for those who like full strategy in economic themed games
column21:
the 240 minute "Waterframe"-Rules come with more options to improve your factory and use ships.

@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/42Arfn__U6EZcAj6biuh4w__original/img/mT2Oug5XPaSWIW0M-nNoZW4qmSY=/0x0/filters:format(png)/pic2776693.png@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/42Arfn__U6EZcAj6biuh4w__thumb/img/zM8pwB0LilhgIQd67L7mOgeZ25o=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic2776693.png@4.5992@240@2@4

column1: 206@Panamax@After one hundred years in service
column2:
the Panama Canal still is one of the most important and impressive engineering achievements in modern times.

Built in 1914
column3: it held a prominent role in the deployment of military vessels during WWI and in the conflicts that have followed. Nowadays commercial usage is the core business of the Canal; its economic impact is profound and has not only developed the region
column4:
but in fact helped define shipping throughout the world.

In the wake of the Canal’s opening hull designs were influenced accordingly; ships fell into three categories
column5: those that could travel through easily and in groups (Feeder class)
column6: massive ocean-going ships too big to enter the Canal (ULCV or Ultra Large Container Vessels)
column7:
and the new standard—designed to the maximum limits of the Panama Canal. These ships are called PANAMAX.

In Panamax each player manages a shipping company established in the Colón Free Trade Zone. Companies accept contracts from both US coasts
column8: China and Europe and deliver cargo in order to make money
column9:
attract investment and pay dividends. At the same time the players accumulate their own stock investments and try to make as much money as possible in an effort to have the largest personal fortune and win the game.

Panamax features several original mechanisms that blend together; an original dice (action) selection table
column10: pickup-and-deliver along a single bi-directional route
column11: a chain reaction movement system—“pushing”  ships to make room throughout the Canal and a level of player interaction that is part self-interest
column12:
part mutual advantage and the freedom to choose how you play.

On their turn
column13: players remove a die from the Action table to select Contracts and Load Cargo or Move ships until the pool of dice is emptied ending the Round. Over the course of three rounds these actions are blended during the turn to create a logistics network which the players use to ship their cargo
column14:
minimize transportation fees and increase the net worth of their Companies. Each Company has a limited amount of Stock that the players can purchase in exchange for investing—receiving a dividend each round. The questions for the players will be which companies are likely to yield higher dividends?

There’s more to explore and several ways to win
column15:
but we ask that you join us at the table and celebrate the 100th Anniversary of the Panama Canal with a session of Panamax!

@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/DjHtKvuSHMdYslgNFyzw1w__original/img/VopILYltj9H--2JkBn2o7Sms-ps=/0x0/filters:format(png)/pic1786212.png@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/DjHtKvuSHMdYslgNFyzw1w__thumb/img/bz4ZAigiXzNCwbFnFScPkczKfvw=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic1786212.png@3.749@120@2@4

column1:
207@This War of Mine: The Board Game@This War Of Mine: The Board Game is the tabletop adaptation of the award-winning video game that pictures the drama of civilians trapped in a war-torn city.

You will enter this experience as a group of civilians trapped in a besieged and conflict-ridden city
column2:
enduring many hardships that often test the essence of humanity.

During day time you will take shelter in a ruined tenement house
column3: which you will care about and manage by: removing rubble
column4: searching through various rooms (often behind barricaded doors)
column5: you will build beds
column6: improvised workshops
column7: stoves
column8: tools
column9: water filters
column10: small animal traps
column11: you will cultivate an improvised vegetable garden
column12: fix the tenements’ shelled facilities
column13: reinforce the security of your shelter and should winter come
column14:
you’ll try to keep it warm.

Upon nightfall your main duties will consist of guarding your shelter and what little possessions you can accumulate against bandits and raiders. Those in your group fit for such a task will use the cover of the night to carefully explore dozens of the ever-changing locations scattered throughout the dangerous city in search of all the things that a person needs to survive (materials
column15: food
column16: meds
column17: equipment
column18: etc.). On your way you will meet tens of characters
column19: each with a unique story (residents of the locations you visit
column20: thieves
column21: bandits
column22: soldiers
column23: war victims
column24: refugees
column25: neighbors
column26: traders and members of local communities)
column27: each encounter is a potential
column28: unique adventure. To guide you through all these events you will have the special SCRIPTS mechanism
column29:
responsible for implementing the deep and complex story and a coherent plot (each game will be unique and different than the previous).

Your goal is to SURVIVE until the cessation of war hostilities. During your struggle as the survivors
column30: you will experience dramas connected with making extremely difficult decisions and choices (you will have to face the consequences of your actions sooner or later in the playthrough). Survival itself will often prove not to be enough. The price each of you will decide to pay
column31:
might be too high in the final outcome. So the goal is really to survive in a way that will let you live on with the decisions you made. The EPILOGUES mechanism will kick in here.

TWOM: The Board Game features a multiplayer experience for up to 6 players
column32:
as well as a solo variant. You will be able to personify one of the well-known characters from the electronic version of the game and face hundreds of new challenges and difficult choices.

The boardgame significantly broadens the original game’s universe and emphasises the depth of plot
column33:
yet its main focus will be on human interactions driven by survival instinct and group decision-making.

The project aims to omit the usual boardgame threshold - TWOM: The Board Game is an INSTANT PLAY game
column34:
with no need for reading the manual before starting the adventure.

Experience the simulation of a struggle for survival as a group of civilians facing a blind and merciless war.

In war

column1: 208@Hadrian's Wall@When visiting the North of Britannia in 122 AD
column2: the Roman Emperor Hadrian Augustus witnessed the aftermath of war between his armies and the savage Picts. In a show of Roman might
column3: he ordered a wall to be built that would separate the Pict tribes from the rest of England. Grand in its design
column4: the wall stretched 80 Roman miles
column5: from coast to coast. Hadrian's Wall stood in service to the Roman Empire for nearly 300 years before its eventual decline. Today
column6: Hadrian's Wall is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and the remains of the forts
column7: towers
column8:
and turrets can still be explored.

In Hadrian's Wall
column9: players take on the role of a Roman General placed in charge of the construction of a milecastle and bordering wall. Over six years (rounds)
column10: players will construct their fort and wall
column11: man the defenses
column12: and attract civilians by building services and providing entertainment — all while defending the honor of the Roman Empire from the warring Picts. The player who can accumulate the most renown
column13: piety
column14: valor and discipline
column15: whilst avoiding disdain
column16:
will prove to the Emperor they are the model Roman citizen and be crowned Legatus Legionis!

—description from the publisher

column1:
209@Whirling Witchcraft@Being a witch is all about wielding powerful magical ingredients — but a witch can wield only so much power before everything blows up in their face. Choose your recipes wisely to clear your workbench and stick others with too much raw material because the first player to overflow their nemesis' cauldron with enough ingredients wins!

In Whirling Witchcraft
column2: you start with a hand of four recipe cards
column3: as well as a number of ingredients on your workbench; ingredients come in five types
column4:
and you have a limited number of spaces for each type on your workbench.

Everyone plays simultaneously during each round. You all choose and reveal a recipe from your hand at the same time
column5: then you can use as many recipes in play in front of you as you wish to convert and transform ingredients. Maybe you'll turn a mushroom into the harder-to-find mandrake
column6: then you can turn two mandrakes (using an older one and the one you just created) to make three mushrooms. You can use each recipe at most once a round
column7: and when you're finished
column8: place all of the final ingredients into a cauldron
column9: then pass it to your neighbor on the right. They must then fit all of these ingredients on their workbench — and if they can't
column10:
they must return the "extra" ingredients to you for placement in your "Witch's Circle".

If you now have at least five ingredients in your Witch's Circle
column11: the game ends and you win; otherwise you all pass your recipe cards in hand to the player on your left
column12: refill your hand to four cards
column13:
then start a new round.

The game includes personality cards you can use to give each player a unique power
column14: in addition to a different set of starting ingredients. Some recipes can be played in either of two directions to help you customize how you transform ingredients
column15:
and recipes might also have arcana symbols that give you bonus powers when you collect enough of them.

Can you put together the right cookbook to land your neighbor in hot water?

column1: 210@Middara: Unintentional Malum  Act 1@Middara is a 1-4 player cooperative choose-your-own-adventure style miniatures board game. Players assume the role of a party of adventurers in an ultra-modern fantasy setting that exists alongside our very own Earth.  During the game

column3:
fully narrative-driven adventure that contains over 90 hours of content. Throughout the narrative you and three of your friends will confront real decisions that change the course of the story and its outcome.

Players will face many dangerous adversaries throughout the story and will take part in heated combat with these foes. Middara features an innovative
column4: dice based combat system for these encounters.  Based on their equipment and abilities
column5: players will have access to unique two-dice combinations that will increase their attack and damage potential in a variety of ways. In addition to numbers
column6: dice have a particular set of symbols on each face that can be spent according to players currently equipped weapons and abilities.  With nine different types of dice
column7:
over 110 unique abilities and 150 unique pieces of equipment the possibilities for different character builds are endless.
 What makes Middara so compelling is that the outcomes of story decisions and encounters have far-reaching effects that determine how the story moves and resolves. Friends and family might get killed
column8: or they may survive. Maybe the players avoid some problems entirely
column9:
only to be faced with a whole new challenge.

Gameplay Features:


    Narrative-driven campaign that contains over 90 hours of content.

and swamps!

and other narrative-driven obstacles.

or even when you are!

column1: 211@Meadow@Meadow is an engaging set collection game with over two hundred unique cards containing hand-painted watercolor illustrations. In the game
column2: players take the role of explorers competing for the title of the most skilled nature observer. To win
column3: they collect cards with the most valuable species
column4: landscapes
column5: and discoveries. Their journey is led by passion
column6: a curiosity of the world
column7: an inquiring mind
column8:
and a desire to discover the mysteries of nature. The competition continues at the bonfire where the players race to fulfill the goals of their adventures.

In this medium-weight board game for 1-4 players
column9: you take turns placing path tokens on one of the two boards. Placing a token on the main board allows the player to get cards
column10: but playing them requires meeting certain requirements. Playing a token on the bonfire board activates special actions (which helps to implement a chosen strategy) and gives the opportunity to achieve goals that provide additional points. Throughout the game

column1: 212@Small World@In Small World
column2:
players vie for conquest and control of a world that is simply too small to accommodate them all.

Designed by Philippe Keyaerts as a fantasy follow-up to his award-winning Vinci
column3: Small World is inhabited by a zany cast of characters such as dwarves
column4: wizards
column5: amazons
column6: giants
column7: orcs
column8: and even humans
column9:
who use their troops to occupy territory and conquer adjacent lands in order to push the other races off the face of the earth.

Picking the right combination from the 14 different fantasy races and 20 unique special powers
column10:
players rush to expand their empires - often at the expense of weaker neighbors. Yet they must also know when to push their own over-extended civilization into decline and ride a new one to victory!

On each turn
column11: you either use the multiple tiles of your chosen race (type of creatures) to occupy adjacent (normally) territories - possibly defeating weaker enemy races along the way
column12:
or you give up on your race letting it go "into decline". A race in decline is designated by flipping the tiles over to their black-and-white side.

At the end of your turn
column13: you score one point (coin) for each territory your races occupy. You may have one active race and one race in decline on the board at the same time. Your occupation total can vary depending on the special abilities of your race and the territories they occupy. After the final round
column14:
the player with the most coins wins.

Clarifications: available in a pinned forum post.

column1: 213@Las Vegas@Developer Stefan Brück at alea describes Las Vegas as "an easy
column2: dice-rolling
column3: fun-and-luck game with a lot of interaction and 'schadenfreude'". Who doesn't love schadenfreude? (Well
column4: other than those being schadened
column5:
I suppose...)

In more detail
column6: Las Vegas includes six cardboard casino mats
column7: one for each side of a normal six-sided die. For each mat
column8: players draw money cards until at least $50k is showing
column9: but the amount may end up being a lot more
column10:
making that casino more desirable.

Each player has eight dice of a different color
column11: which they take turns rolling. When you roll your dice
column12: you can choose to place them on the relevant casino cards; for example
column13: a die showing a 1 will be placed on the casino mat marked "1". You must place all dice of one number on one casino in your turn. All players take turns doing this until all the dice have been used. Finally
column14: the player with the most dice on each casino card takes the money associated with it. In case of a tie
column15:
the next non-tied player takes the highest-valued money card at that casino.

Las Vegas rates a 1 out of 10 on alea's difficulty scale.

column1: 214@Final Girl@Playing on a famous horror movie trope

Final Girl is a solitaire-only game that puts the player in the shoes of a female protagonist who must kill the slasher if she wants to survive.

The Core Box

the more killer/location combinations you can experience!

In game terms

including a game board to track locations and character movement. You can choose from multiple characters when picking someone to play and multiple killers when picking someone to play against. Killers and locations each have their own specific terror cards that will be shuffled together to create a unique experience with various combinations of scenarios for you to play!

column1: 215@Chess@Chess is a two-player
column2: abstract strategy board game that represents medieval warfare on an 8x8 board with alternating light and dark squares. Opposing pieces
column3: traditionally designated White and Black
column4: are initially lined up on either side. Each type of piece has a unique form of movement and capturing occurs when a piece
column5: via its movement
column6: occupies the square of an opposing piece. Players take turns moving one of their pieces in an attempt to capture
column7: attack
column8: defend
column9: or develop their positions. Chess games can end in checkmate
column10: resignation
column11: or one of several types of draws. Chess is one of the most popular games in the world
column12: played by millions of people worldwide at home
column13: in clubs
column14: online
column15: by correspondence
column16: and in tournaments. Between two highly skilled players
column17: chess can be a beautiful thing to watch
column18: and a game can provide great entertainment even for novices. There is also a large literature of books and periodicals about chess
column19:
typically featuring games and commentary by chess masters.

The game has its origins in the Indian game Chaturanga
column20: and became Shatranj when introduced to the Persians. The current form of the game emerged in the second half of the 15th century when the Persians brought Shatranj to Southern Europe. The tradition of organized competitive chess began in the 16th century. The first official World Chess Champion
column21: Wilhelm Steinitz
column22: claimed his title in 1886. The current World Champion is Magnus Carlsen
column23:
Norway. Chess is also a recognized sport of the International Olympic Committee.

column1: 216@Android: Netrunner@Welcome to New Angeles
column2: home of the Beanstalk. From our branch offices in this monument of human achievement
column3: NBN proudly broadcasts all your favorite media programming. We offer fully comprehensive streaming in music and threedee
column4: news and sitcoms
column5: classic movies and sensies. We cover it all. Ours is a brave new age
column6: and as humanity hurtles into space and the future with an astonishing series of new advances every day
column7: NBN and our affiliates are keeping pace
column8:
bringing you all the vid that's fit to view.

Android: Netrunner is an asymmetrical Living Card Game for two players. Set in the cyberpunk future of Android and Infiltration
column9:
the game pits a megacorporation and its massive resources against the subversive talents of lone runners.

Corporations seek to score agendas by advancing them. Doing so takes time and credits. To buy the time and earn the credits they need
column10: they must secure their servers and data forts with "ice". These security programs come in different varieties
column11: from simple barriers
column12: to code gates and aggressive sentries. They serve as the corporation's virtual eyes
column13: ears
column14:
and machine guns on the sprawling information superhighways of the network.

In turn
column15: runners need to spend their time and credits acquiring a sufficient wealth of resources
column16: purchasing the necessary hardware
column17: and developing suitably powerful ice-breaker programs to hack past corporate security measures. Their jobs are always a little desperate
column18: driven by tight timelines
column19: and shrouded in mystery. When a runner jacks-in and starts a run at a corporate server
column20: he risks having his best programs trashed or being caught by a trace program and left vulnerable to corporate countermeasures. It's not uncommon for an unprepared runner to fail to bypass a nasty sentry and suffer massive brain damage as a result. Even if a runner gets through a data fort's defenses
column21: there's no telling what it holds. Sometimes
column22: the runner finds something of value. Sometimes
column23:
the best he can do is work to trash whatever the corporation was developing.

The first player to seven points wins the game
column24:
but not likely before he suffers some brain damage or bad publicity.

The Revised Core Set for Android: Netrunner released in late 2017 includes cards from the original Core Set released in 2012 as well as cards from the Genesis Cycle and Spin Cycle series of Data Packs. While the cards in this set have been released previously
column25:
the art on some of them is new.

column1: 217@Flash Point: Fire Rescue@The call comes in... "911
column2: what is your emergency?"  On the other end is a panicked response of "FIRE!" Moments later you don the protective suits that will keep you alive
column3: gather your equipment and rush to the scene of a blazing inferno. The team has only seconds to assess the situation and devise a plan of attack – then you spring into action like the trained professionals that you are. You must face your fears
column4: never give up
column5: and above all else work as a team because the fire is raging
column6: the building is threatening to collapse
column7:
and lives are in danger.

You must succeed. You are the brave men and women of fire rescue; people are depending on you. This is what you do every day.

Flash Point: Fire Rescue is a cooperative game of fire rescue.

There are two versions of game play in Flash Point
column8:
a basic game and expert game.
In both variants
column9:
players are attempting to rescue 7 of 10 victims from a raging building fire.
As the players attempt to rescue the victims
column10: the fire spreads to other parts of the building
column11: causing structural damage and possibly blocking off pathways through the building.  Each turn a player may spend action points to try to extinguish fires
column12: move through the building
column13: move victims out of the building or perform various special actions such as moving emergency vehicles.  If 4 victims perish in the blaze or the building collapses from taking too much structural damage
column14: the players lose.  Otherwise
column15:
the players win instantly when they rescue a 7th victim.

The expert variant included in the game adds thematic elements such as flash over
column16: combustible materials
column17: random setup
column18:
and variations on game difficulty from novice to heroic.  The game includes a double sided board with two different building plans and several expansion maps are available.

column1: 218@The King's Dilemma@The King's Dilemma is an interactive narrative experience with legacy elements
column2:
featuring several branching storylines leading to many possible finales and an evolving deck of event cards at its core. Players represent the various houses leading the government of the Kingdom of Ankist.

You will draw one card from the "Dilemma deck" each round and experience the game story as it unfolds. Each card poses a problem that the Council has to resolve on the King's behalf. As members of the King's inner circle
column3: your decisions determine how the story proceeds and the fate of the kingdom. Each event happens only once: You discuss and bargain with the other players
column4: then finally you make a choice
column5: determining the outcome
column6: progressing the game story
column7:
and possibly unlocking more events.

You have to keep the kingdom going
column8: while also seeking an advantage for your own house; this power struggle may lead the kingdom into war
column9: famine
column10: or riot
column11: or it could generate wealth and well-being. This will depend on your choices! The thing is
column12: each decision has consequences
column13:
and what is good for the kingdom as a whole may be bad for your family...

Will you act for the greater good
column14:
or will you think only of yourself?

column1: 219@The Resistance: Avalon@The Resistance: Avalon pits the forces of Good and Evil in a battle to control the future of civilization. Arthur represents the future of Britain
column2: a promise of prosperity and honor
column3: yet hidden among his brave warriors are Mordred's unscrupulous minions. These forces of evil are few in number but have knowledge of each other and remain hidden from all but one of Arthur's servants. Merlin alone knows the agents of evil
column4: but he must speak of this only in riddles. If his true identity is discovered
column5:
all will be lost.

The Resistance: Avalon is a standalone game
column6: and while The Resistance is not required to play

the games are compatible and can be combined.

column1: 220@Warehouse 13: The Board Game@The Warehouse is a massive
column2: top-secret government facility in South Dakota that houses dangerous and fantastical objects. Agents assigned to the Warehouse risk their lives to retrieve these artifacts to keep them away from nefarious individuals who seek to use the artifacts for personal gain. In Warehouse 13: The Board Game
column3: players take on the role of Warehouse Agents who must work together to retrieve these artifacts. But is everyone looking out for the Warehouse's interests
column4:
or might one of the Agents be secretly working for the Warehouse's most ruthless adversary?

Warehouse 13: The Board Game can be played by three to five players in about two hours. Each game of Warehouse 13: The Board Game is considered a Season
column5: played over a series of Episodes. Each Episode will involve the investigation and retrieval of one artifact. Warehouse Agents must investigate clues
column6: then use those clues to retrieve the artifact. However
column7: one player is the Traitor
column8: who secretly works for the Adversary. For every artifact that is lost
column9:
the Adversary becomes more powerful and thereby more difficult to defeat.

Each Episode begins with the Ping Phase
column10:
in which the artifact's location is revealed and clue dice are rolled. Clues are represented by 13 custom six-sided dice.

After the Ping Phase
column11: the Investigation Phase begins. During the Adversary turn
column12: the Adversary will act. Afterwards
column13: each Agent must perform an Action
column14: such as drawing Traits
column15: playing a Trait
column16: performing Warehouse Maintenance
column17: or traveling to the Field. Next
column18: each Agent must attempt to claim a clue die. If an Agent cannot claim a clue die
column19: one must be neutralized
column20: removing it from play for the remainder of that Episode. Finally
column21:
each Agent must draw a free Trait.

The Investigation Phase repeats until all of the clue dice are either claimed or neutralized
column22: then the Retrieval Phase begins. Each artifact displays symbols that correspond to the symbols on the clue dice. During each round of the Retrieval Phase
column23: the players secretly roll all of their clue dice and each player chooses one to apply to the artifact. The chosen dice are revealed simultaneously. The Adversary will intervene by rolling Goo dice which can neutralize clue dice. If enough clues are applied to match the artifact's symbols
column24: the artifact is retrieved. If the Agents run out of clue dice before rolling enough symbols
column25:
the artifact is lost to the Adversary.

Play then continues to the next Episode. After three artifacts are retrieved
column26: the Warehouse Agents win. However
column27: if three artifacts are lost
column28: the Finale begins
column29:
in which the Agents have one last chance to thwart the Adversary's grand scheme.

At the beginning of the game
column30: the Traitor is hidden. The Traitor can impact the game by failing to assist the Warehouse Agents
column32: or by failing to apply clues properly. If the Agents believe they have determined who the Traitor is
column33: they can vote to Bronze that player

column1: 221@Hanabi@Hanabi—named for the Japanese word for "fireworks"—is a cooperative game in which players try to create the perfect fireworks show by placing the cards on the table in the right order. (In Japanese
column2: hanabi is written as èŠ±ç«; these are the ideograms flower and fire
column3:
respectively.)

The card deck consists of five different colors of cards
column4: numbered 1–5 in each color. For each color
column5: the players try to place a row in the correct order from 1–5. Sounds easy
column6: right? Well
column7: not quite
column8: as in this game you hold your cards so that they're visible only to other players. To assist other players in playing a card
column9:
you must give them hints regarding the numbers or the colors of their cards. Players must act as a team to avoid errors and to finish the fireworks display before they run out of cards.

An extra suit of cards
column10: rainbow colored
column11:
is also provided for advanced or variant play.

Hanabi was originally published as part of Hanabi & Ikebana.

column1: 222@Quodd Heroes@Quodd Heroes is a fast-paced modular
column2: scenario-based adventure board game that plays like a combination of Super Smash Bros.
column3: Mario Kart and Legend of Zelda all wrapped into one. Whether it’s a simple point-to-point rally-style race
column4: capture the flag or a quest to uncover hidden secrets each game is filled with unexpected events
column5: lots of player interaction
column6:
ever-changing boards and a dash of mayhem.

The core mechanism in Quodd Heroes is something you’ve never seen before. Each player controls a different cube-shaped character miniature and player board.  You then assign a different movement skill to five of the six sides of your character (the sixth side has an ability unique to your character). When you begin the movement phase on your turn you “tumble” your character into an adjacent space and perform the movement skill associated with the face-up side of your character. Skills include: Tumble
column7: Jump
column8: Slide
column9: Diagonal Slide
column10:
and Dash.

While you work to complete the scenario’s objective(s)
column11: either on your own
column12: cooperatively
column13: or against other players
column14: game boards which are laid out in grids present obstacles like walls
column15: raging rivers
column16: chasms
column17: moving platforms
column18: rotating board sections
column19: trap doors
column20: tunnels
column21: teleporters and more. As you navigate the world you create new obstacles and shortcuts while battling your opponents by pushing them into pits
column22:
blocking their paths and fouling their plans.

As you explore the world you will find food
column23: runes
column24: items and pets in the form of cards. These cards enhance your abilities
column25:
slow your opponents and modify the world around you. If you use your movement skills and cards strategically you'll emerge as the greatest of the Quodd Heroes.

Player Turn Structure:

1. Play cards (power up): Play as many cards as you like from your hand. Power up and alter the board prior to movement.

2. Movement Phase: Perform your natural tumble by turning your hero miniature over into an adjacent space
column26: activate any board elements on that space
column27:
then activate the movement skill associated with the side of your character that is now facing up. Move up to your maximum distance with that skill in any direction you like.

3. Play card (recover phase): You many play any additional cards you like during this phase.

4. Exploration phase: draw cards from the lineup of cards or the top of the deck equal to your exploration value

At the end of each round an upkeep phase includes:

- moving board elements and animals
- play a world event card that effects all players
- Adjust round tracker (in timed scenarios)
- all heroes upgrade their hero by selecting an upgrade tile and placing it in their upgrade track.
- First player mark passes to the left

@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/r_ponwLZ3U8NeHPwAPTiww__original/img/bl_kxbLkdgVdlf-Dop3I2KFyCM8=/0x0/filters:format(jpeg)/pic3796365.jpg@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/r_ponwLZ3U8NeHPwAPTiww__thumb/img/0QoNFpmSRaxKeKpTNTV4X9aHxgQ=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic3796365.jpg@3.1714@90@1@6

column1: 223@Etherfields@Etherfields is a narrative
column2:
cooperative game for 1 - 4 (5 with the 5th player expansion). A series of unique Dreams await to be discovered through tense exploration and tactical encounters.

Learn about the Dreamers
column3: their forgotten past
column4: and their desperate mission. Uncover the surreal
column5:
sprawling dreamscapes. Just don't be surprised when---just like dreams often do---they become a little disturbing... Prepare to be challenged by escape-room like riddles. Spot a clue in the image. See a hidden link between several pieces of information. Use your instinct as much as your logic.

In the beginning
column6: you'll explore the Dreamworld
column7: trying to find out what this is all about and who you are – and you are there for a specific reason
column8: but
column9: at first
column10:
you can't remember too much. You'll have to restore your memories from scattered pieces.

The rules are pretty straightforward at the beginning
column11: but they will grow more and more complex during the campaign. New rules open new possibilities and
column12: sometimes
column13:
may turn everything upside down.

Deckbuilding in Etherfields applies to almost every deck in the game
column14: not only the players' ones. If you want to know more
column15: enter the Dreamworld. It may be dark here and there

column17: look around and ask yourself: what if we all live in a vast
column18:
