column11: players harvest crops and load riverboats
column12: with a dock needing to be filled with all the goods of a single type before it can be loaded. In phase four
column13: the boats are launched and players can take special actions

column1: 278@On Mars@Following the success of unmanned rover missions
column2: the United Nations established the Department of Operations and Mars Exploration (D.O.M.E.). The first settlers arrived on Mars in the year 2037 and in the decades after establishment Mars Base Camp
column3: private exploration companies began work on the creation of a self-sustaining colony. As chief astronaut for one of these enterprises
column4: you want to be a pioneer in the development of the biggest
column5:
most advanced colony on Mars by achieving both D.O.M.E. mission goals as well as your company’s private agenda.

In the beginning
column6: you will be dependent on supplies from Earth and will have to travel often between the Mars Space Station and the planet's surface. As the colony expands over time
column7: you will shift your activities to construct mines
column8: power generators
column9: water extractors
column10: greenhouses
column11: oxygen factories
column12: and shelters. Your goal is to develop a self-sustaining colony independent of any terrestrial organization. This will require understanding the importance of water
column13: air
column14: power
column15:
and food — the necessities for survival.

Do you dare take part in humankind’s biggest challenge?

On Mars is played over several rounds
column16:
each consisting of two phases - the Colonization Phase â€‹and the Shuttle Phaseâ€‹.

During the Colonization Phase
column17: each player takes a turn during which they take actions. The available actions depend on the side of the board they are on. If you are in orbit
column18: you can take blueprints
column19: buy and develop technologies
column20: and take supplies from the Warehouse. If you are on the surface of the planet
column21: you can construct buildings with your bots
column22: upgrade these buildings using blueprints
column23: take scientists and new contracts
column24: welcome new ships
column25: and explore the planet’s surface with your rover. In the Shuttle Phase
column26:
players may travel between the colony and the Space Station in orbit.

All buildings on Mars have a dependency on each other and some are required for the colony to grow. Building shelters for Colonists to live in requires oxygen; generating oxygen requires plants; growing plants requires water; extracting water from ice requires power; generating power requires mining minerals; and mining minerals requires Colonists. Upgrading the colony’s ability to provide each of these resources is vital. As the colony grows
column27:
more shelters are needed so that the Colonists can survive the inhospitable conditions on Mars.

During the game
column28: players are also trying to complete missions. Once a total of three missions have been completed
column29: the game ends. To win the game
column30:
players must contribute to the development of the first colony on Mars. This is represented during the game by players gaining Opportunity Points (OP). The player with the most OP at the end of the game is declared the winner.

column1: 286@The Search for Planet X@At the edge of our solar system

column20: as shown in the upper right corner of the character sheet

column1: 292@Caverna: The Cave Farmers@Following along the same lines as its predecessor (Agricola)

column9:

You can also play the solo variant of this game to familiarize yourself with the 48 different furnishing tiles for your cave.

Caverna: The Cave Farmers
column10: which has a playing time of roughly 30 minutes per player

column1: 293@Forbidden Island@Forbidden Island is a visually stunning cooperative board game. Instead of winning by competing with other players like most games

column3: which is built by arranging the many beautifully screen-printed tiles before play begins. As the game progresses
column4: more and more island tiles sink
column5: becoming unavailable

it gets more difficult- sacrifices must be made.

What causes this game to truly stand out among co-op and competitive games alike is the extreme detail that has been paid to the physical components of the game. It comes in a sturdy and organized tin of good shelf storage size. The plastic treasure pieces and wooden pawns are well crafted and they fit just right into the box. The cards are durable

column11:
each with a unique and pleasing image.

With multiple levels of difficulty

column17: oddly
column18:
Forbidden Island is a rare game of both quality and affordable price.
 For those who enjoy Forbidden Island

column1: 294@Bus@Prior to Essen 1999
column2: a group of students created Splotter Spellen to sell some of their own game designs.  This game is regarded as one of the highlights of that group.  The object of the game is to deliver as many people to their destinations as you can.  To accomplish this
column3: players place route markers on the board to connect passengers to their destinations.  However
column4: the destination types (work
column5: bar
column6: home) vary from turn to turn
column7:
so you can follow certain passengers as they make their way through the daily grind.

Players may buy more buses (they start off with one)
column8: build onto their bus route
column9: bring new passengers to the city (via the trains)
column10: expand the city by adding more buildings
column11: and run their buses. There is another option
column12: the clock
column13: but more on that later. The action board has one other clever feature. On some actions
column14: route expansion and building
column15:
the first player to choose that action actually gets to execute the action last! Which leads to some interesting games of chicken and some painful decisions.

Buying more buses allows a player to carry one more passenger every time they run their buses - hence scoring
column16: in the best case
column17: one more point. Depending on how the city gets built
column18: however
column19:
finding lots of passengers on the street can be tricky.

Bus routes extend from either end of a Settlers-style initial placement. Extensions are appended to either end. Routes may only run parallel if there are no empty streets at one of the ends or the line ends on the crossing as another player's end. All new passengers will arrive at one of two train stations so that is one concern when route building. One must also be careful to run by a nice mix of building types. And
column20: when building
column21: one must always have an eye towards spoiling other players' routes by placing a mix of building types at each of their intersection so that all of their passengers just walk! Finally
column22: when carrying passengers
column23:
one wants to be careful to set up to carry the same passenger next turn.

About the game:
Japan
column6: 1605 – Hidetada Tokugawa has succeeded his father as the new Shogun
column7: ruling from the great city of Edo (a.k.a. Yedo)
column8: the city known in present times as Tokyo. This marks the beginning of the golden age of the Tokugawa Shogunate and the so-called Edo Period that will last until 1868. Naturally
column9: the most powerful families in Edo immediately try to curry favor with the new Shogun – and this is the opportunity our clan has been looking for
column10:
our chance at power and glory. Our clan will prove ourselves to be indispensable to the new Shogun. We will work from the shadows to acquire information about our rival clans. We will kidnap those who might oppose our ascent and assassinate those who prove a threat. We will use cunning to prevent our adversaries from doing the same to us. We will find glory and honor in the eyes of this new Shogun – or failing that we will end his rule by any means necessary.

In the strategy game Yedo
column11: players assume the roles of Clan Elders in the city of Edo during the early years of the Tokugawa Shogunate. The object of the game is to amass Prestige Points

There are several ways to reach your goal. Will you try to complete as many missions as possible and hope that your efforts catch the Shogun's eye? Or will you choose a more subtle way of gaining power by trying to influence the Shogun during a private audience? You can also put your rivals to shame by buying lots of luxury goods from the European merchants. It's all up to you – but be careful to make the right choices

column1: 299@Unsettled@Lost amidst the surreal and bizarre unknowns of the far reaches of the cosmos

Unsettled is a 2-4 player cooperative survival adventure set in the wondrous and unnerving fringes of uncharted space. There are no enemies and no combat
column3: only an environment where every step
column4: every breath

column6: terrifying

column8:

column1: 303@Kanban: Driver's Edition@"Kanban" — or çœ‹æ¿
column2: the Japanese word for billboard — is a term for the visual cues that might be used in a lean
column3: efficient assembly line in order to expedite and smooth workflow. These signals get the workers what they need
column4: where they need it
column5:
when they need it to create a just-in-time (JIT) production system.

The setting for the game Kanban: Automotive Revolution is an assembly line. The players are ambitious managers who are trying to impress the board of directors in order to achieve as high a position as possible in the company and secure their careers. With promotions come advantages at the factory
column6: such as more space to store precious materials and greater prestige to accelerate your ascent. Through solid management
column7: you must strive to shine next to your peers. You need to manage suppliers and supplies
column8: improve automobile parts
column9: innovate — anything to stay on the cutting edge
column10: or getting your hands greasy on the assembly line in order to boost production. You must exercise wisdom in choosing which projects you should start
column11:
selecting only those that will give you the upper hand and shunning those that will bog you down or cause the unthinkable — failure — which would diminish you in the eyes of the board.

Over the course of the game
column12: you persuade the board and the factory tender to help you develop and improve automobile parts. You make shrewd use of the outside suppliers and the limited factory supplies in order to appropriate needed part when the suppliers come up short. Because the factory must run at optimum efficiency
column13:
production doesn't wait for you or for mistakes.

Like the process itself
column14:
Kanban: Automotive Revolution proves to be both innovative and rewarding. Game mechanisms tightly tied to the automobile manufacturing theme include:


    The factory manager is a game-driven non-player character with two modes of play ("nice" or "mean") to offer a friendly or more competitive gameplay environment.
    Two independent player-influenced game timers — the factory production cycle and work week clock — provide timing tension to the game
column15: trigger intermediate scoring phases
column16:
and factor into the game end conditions.
    A simulation of the factory assembly line with spatial point-to-point movement adds an element to the game that requires optimal timing.
    A design and innovation department
column17: leveraged to manipulate the value of the various car models and component upgrades produced within the factory
column18:
drives the economy of the game.
    Departmental training and certification tracks provide players a means to operate more efficiently.


If you want a seat on the board someday
column19: you need to show that you can keep a complex machine running smoothly
column20: efficiently
column21: with everything happening just at the right time. Kanban: Automotive Revolution is a pure Eurogame focused on economics and resource management that puts you in the driver's seat of an entire production facility
column22:
racing for the highest level of promotion.

column1: 309@Stick 'Em@In the trick-taking card game Stick 'Em
column2: first released as Sticheln
column3: players seek to gather points each hand by taking as many cards as possible of all but one color
column4:
while trying to avoid cards of one color of their choosing.

In more detail
column5: at the beginning of each hand
column6: each player simultaneously selects and reveals one card from their hand
column7: with the color of this card representing their "pain" color. At the end of the hand
column8:
each card of this color that they've collected (including their initial choice from their hand) is worth negative points equal to the card's face value. Each card of another color that this player has collected is worth 1 point.

To play out the hand
column9: the active player leads a card
column10: then each other player in clockwise order plays one card. If all cards are of the same color
column11: then whoever played the highest card collects these cards
column12: then leads the next trick; if all cards are not of the same color
column13: then whoever played the highest card of a color not initially led collects these cards
column14: then leads the next trick. (One exception: A zero card can never win a trick.) In effect
column15: each color played in a particular trick that doesn't match the color of the card led is considered a trump card
column16: and the highest trump wins. In the event of a tie
column17:
the earlier played card breaks the tie.

Play as many hands as the number of players in the game
column18:
summing each player's points over those hands to determine a winner.

Some versions of Sticheln allow for play with up to six players
column19: while the third and fourth German editions of the game include enough cards to allow for play with up to eight players. (These versions also allow players to play the game Hattrick by the same designer

with rules for this game included as a variant.)

column1: 315@Thunderbolt Apache Leader@Thunderbolt-Apache Leader puts you in the cockpits of the world’s best Close Air Support aircraft. In Thunderbolt-Apache Leader
column2:
you’ll zoom through canyons hunting enemy tanks and troops while dodging their AAA fire and SAMs.

Stuffing all this heavy metal in one box has allowed us to expand the normal Leader component set! This game comes with 168 cards and 5 counter sheets!

Thunderbolt-Apache Leader puts you down in the weeds in 8 campaigns spanning the globe. The game system creates immense replayability by pairing a Tactical Situation card with the Campaign card to create a unique environment for the campaign. This means that your campaign in North Korea might be part of a Holding Action
column3: Show of Force
column4: Rapid Deployment
column5:
or General War.

The game places you in command of the pilots and aircraft of a squadron of U.S. Close Air Support (CAS) aircraft in hostile campaigns around the world. The aircraft and weapons available for each campaign are historically accurate.

A major part of the game is mission planning. You decide how to arm your aircraft and which pilots are best for the mission. Pilots are rated for skill level. Deciding which pilots to fly each mission is a major consideration. Your pilots will become fatigued with every mission. If you fly a pilot too often
column6: his skills will degrade. Your pilots also gain experience with every mission flown. This makes for some great decision-making. Should you keep flying the top pilots and further fatigue them to get the job done
column7:
or fly the new guys to prep them for the tough missions ahead?

Missions are quickly resolved using an area movement system to display tactical combat over the target. Speed and realism take top priority in this game. Terrain cards randomly generate each battlefield. The cards include mountain ranges that block lines of sight from both you and the enemy forces. If you plan it right
column8: you get to fly nap of the earth through the canyons and come screaming over the ridge-line to rain fire down on the enemy before they can react. Beware! During each battle enemy air defenses will pop-up on the map to ruin your day
column9:
so watch were you’re flying!

You get to resolve every missile launched at enemy bandits
column10: and every air to ground attack against the enemy targets. Each enemy tank
column11: S.P. Artillery
column12: APC
column13: Infantry
column14: etc is represented by its own counter on the battlefield. You also get to resolve the enemy SAM
column15: AAA
column16:
and Bandit attacks against your aircraft.

While performing each mission
column17: you get to decide how your pilots engage the enemy Bandits
column18: SAMs
column19: and AAA Sites. This makes for some tough choices. Do you hit the high value targets first
column20:
or take out the enemy SAM and AAA assets?

Thunderbolt-Apache Leader aircraft are usually able to survive more than one attack. These aircraft are rugged and made to soak-up damage. This also factors into your decision-making. How long should you loiter over the target blowing-up enemy tanks before heading for home? If your aircraft is too shot-up
column21:
it won’t be able to fly the next day.

Thunderbolt-Apache Leader features an operation combat sheet that tracks the progress of enemy formations attempting to overrun your sector. You get to select the formation you want to engage each day and assign the air assets you think are best suited to the task.

If you’ve played Hornet Leader or Phantom Leader

column15: when the last Performance card is revealed

the game ends and the illusionist with the most Fame points wins.

The game offers 48 different Tricks to be learned from the Optical

and 40 Special Assignment cards that influence the actions taken at the various game locations. The base game can be expanded with two optional rule modules to add further strategic depth to the game.

The "Dark Alley" expansion included in the base game adds a new location to the game. It also comes with 48 new Special Assignment cards
column21: a new tier of Tricks
column22: and 27 Prophecy tokens that can alter certain game rules turn by turn

giving the game additional variety.

column1: 317@Shogun@Japan during the Sengoku or “Warring States” Period (approx. 1467-1573): each player assumes the role of a great Daimyo

leading their troops to conquer the provinces of the Japanese islands.

and castles means points when scores are tallied. Whichever Daimyo has the highest number of points at the end of the game becomes – SHOGUN!

Shogun is based on the Wallenstein game system. The game is an international edition with language-independent components and five language-dependent rule booklets.

column1: 318@Shards of Infinity@One-hundred years ago

column5:
and rebuild the Infinity Engine! Will you survive?

Shards of Infinity combines an unprecedented level of strategy and customization into one small box. Rather than competing for points

depending on what they are.

As you acquire new cards

column1: 319@Cryptid@You've studied the footage

but reveal too much and your name will be long forgotten!

column1: 320@Bausack@Players take turns choosing blocks and giving them to each other to place on their structure.  A player may pay a certain number of 'beans' to refuse a block and it gets passed to the next player.  When a player's structure falls
column2:
they are out of the game.  Last player standing wins.

Description of Bandu (1992
column3: Milton Bradley
column4:
2-6 players):
Bandu is based upon the game of Bausack. Each player is given a base block and a number of beans. During a turn
column5:
a player chooses a wood block from a common supply and either holds a Refuse or Use auction. All player bid with their beans and the winner/loser must place the piece on their tower. If your tower falls you are out of the game. The last tower standing wins.

Description of Sac Noir (Rio Grande Games
column6:
2-8 players):
There are five variations on how to play. The goal in all of them is to build a tower. The bag contains very different wooden pieces (i.e. an ashlar
column7: an egg
column8: a ring
column9: a fir tree etc.) as well as a sack of beans for the "auction variation" of the game. Depending on the variation you choose
column10:
either each player builds his own tower or all build one together. The "auction variations" are the most suspenseful and surprising. One might end up spending quite some beans to avoid building an especially difficult element. Gambling and bluffing abilities are needed just as much as a feeling for statics and construction skills. It's a game with almost endless building possibilities. It's a challenge for steady hands and shaky suspense for clever tacticians.

column1: 321@Unforgiven: The Lincoln Assassination Trial@"Passion governs
column2: and she never governs wisely." — Benjamin Franklin

one of America's Founding Fathers.

Ninety years later

is guilty...or innocent.

Unforgiven: The Lincoln Assassination Trial is a two-player game that takes place during the May 9 - June 28
column9: 1865 trial of the first woman

will Mary Surratt again face the hangman's noose of American justice — or can you stop the trap door from falling?

column1: 322@Claim@The King is dead! What happened? Nobody really knows

column1:
323@Village@Life in the village is hard – but life here also allows the inhabitants to grow and prosper as they please. One villager might want to become a friar. Another might feel ambitious and strive for a career in public office. A third one might want to seek his luck in distant lands.

however: Time will not stop for anyone and with time people will vanish. Those who will find themselves immortalized in the village chronicles will bring honor to their family and be one step closer to victory.

Village is a game full of tactical challenges. A smart and unique new action mechanism is responsible for keeping turns short and yet still tactically rich and full of difficult decisions. Also unique is the way this game deals with the delicate subject of death; as a natural and perpetual part of life in the village

thoughts of death will keep you focused on smart time-management.

column1: 325@Escape from the Hidden Castle@Although billed as a children's game

one guest per space; this initial placement is a large part of a player's strategy.

The Phantom (or "Hugo the ghost" in earlier versions) starts in the cellar

Once the Phantom has reached the gallery

with those caught later in the round earning less and less.

column1: 329@Egizia@The players are builders in Ancient Egypt
column2: competing to get the most fame building different monuments requested by the Pharaoh (the Sphinx
column3: the Obelisk
column4: the Temple
column5:
and the Pyramid).

The game lasts 5 turns. In each turn
column6: the players place their pawns on the board
column7: along the banks of the Nile
column8: getting the advantages shown on each square. On the right bank there are fixed squares where the players may get workers
column9: improve their mercantile capabilities
column10: influence the floods (and thus the fertility of the fields) and reserve the right to build the monuments (that are built only after all the placements are done). On the left bank the players may take cards that are deployed randomly on the 10 squares at the start of each turn; some of these cards are kept until the end of the game (cultivable fields
column11: stone quarries
column12: deities granting special advantages)
column13:
while others are discarded after the use and offer multiple immediate advantages.

In Egizia
column14: the twist on the worker placement mechanic is that the players must place their pawns following the course of the Nile
column15: moving northwards (from the top to the bottom of the board
column16: that is seen from the Mediterranean Sea). In this way
column17: each placement not only blocks the opponents from choosing the same square (except monuments
column18: where multiple players are always allowed)
column19: but also forces the player to place his remaining pawns only on the squares below the one he just occupied (note that "pawns" are placed
column20: since "workers" are one of the resources of the game
column21:
like grain and stones).

When the placement phase is over
column22: the workers of the players must be fed with the grain produced in the fields. The production of each field is based on the floods of the Nile
column23: so some fields may not give grain each turn. If a player has not enough grain for all his workers
column24: he has to buy it with Victory Points (the ratio is better for players with improved mercantile capabilities
column25:
recorded on a specific track on the board).

After that
column26:
stones are received from the owned quarries and used to build the monuments (if the right to do was reserved earlier) along with the workers.

When the game ends
column27:
the points scored during the game (mainly building the monuments) are added to the bonuses obtained fulfilling certain conditions on the Sphinx cards. Whoever has the highest total is the winner.

column13: lizard
column14: turtle
column15: eagle
column16: meerkat
column17: scorpio
column18: hog
column19: catfish
column20: rhino
column21: etc.
column22:
each with its own landscape requirements — 68 different animals in total.

Each player starts their individual park with an entrance tile
column23: and they are each represented in the marketplace of animal tiles by a ceramic figure (or a wooden ranger meeple in some editions). On a turn
column24: a player takes the tile to their left
column25:
right or front; moves their figure to the space just vacated; then draws a tile to place where their figure started the turn.

When adding an animal tile in your park
column26: you add its main landscape — the base space for the animal — to your park
column27: too. While placing this new animal
column28: its own piece of landscape can help to fulfill the requirements of your other animals' requirements
column29: e.g.
column30: the water on a hippo tile fulfilling the adjacent otter's need for water. Thus
column31:
fulfilling every animal's desire for land becomes a more and more difficult task with each tile you add.

Aside from expanding your park with different landscape types
column32: flora and animals
column33: you can improve its profitability by building extra entrance roads
column36: with each season giving each player 6-9 new tiles for their parks. Whoever has best met the goal of the season receives bonus points
column37: with a smaller number of points for second and third place. At the end of the game
column38:
each player scores for each tile in their park based on whether that tile's requirements are satisfied. Whoever scores the most points wins!

NOTE: BoardGameTables edition contains both XL Expansion and Double Expansion and is entirely replacing the previous editions.

column1: 334@A Few Acres of Snow@A Few Acres of Snow is a two-player

each card will have multiple uses like card-driven games. The players have to choose only one aspect of the card to use when it is played. Each space captured by a player will add another card to the capturing player's deck.

column5: unpredictable American tribes
column6: and formidable distances. Despite these obstacles they were able to engage in bitter warfare
column7:
with the British ultimately taking the prize of Quebec. A Few Acres of Snow is a two-player game that allows you to recreate this contest. You can change the course of history by your decisions.

A Few Acres of Snow takes an innovative approach to the subject
column8: using cards to represent locations and manpower. As the game progresses you add to your selection of cards
column9: increasing the range of actions available to you. There are many strategies to be explored. How quickly should you build up your forces
column10: do you employ Native Americans
column11:
what energy should be expended on your economy?

The game is about more than just fighting – you must successfully colonize the land to have a chance.

column1: 337@13 Days: The Cuban Missile Crisis
column2:
1962@Experience the dense Cold War suspense and scratch that Twilight Struggle itch in only 45 minutes.

13 Days: The Cuban Missile Crisis is a nail-biting
column3: theme saturated two-player strategy game about the Cuban Missile Crisis. Your fate is determined by how well you deal with the inherent dilemmas of the game
column4:
and the conflict.

1) Will you push to gain prestige at the risk of escalating the crisis to global nuclear war?
2) How do you best manage your hand of cards to further your own plans while depriving your opponent of options?

Work out these dilemmas in order to emerge as victor of the Cuban Missile Crisis after thirteen suspenseful days.

13 Days: The Cuban Missile Crisis is a meaty filler utilizing the card-driven game mechanisms. Rich with history
column5:
yet accessible to gamers with no prior knowledge of the crisis. It is targeted specifically at catering to two groups of gamers: the enthusiasts that just don't have the time they used to and the curious newcomers that are scared off by the heavy commitment and long play times of the classics in the genre.

column1: 339@Arboretum@Arboretum is a strategy card game for 2-4 players
column2: aged 10 and up
column3: that combines set collection
column4:
tile-laying and hand management while playing in about 25 minutes. Players try to have the most points at the end of the game by creating beautiful garden paths for their visitors.

The deck has 80 cards in ten different colors
column5: with each color featuring a different species of tree; each color has cards numbered 1 through 8
column6: and the number of colors used depends on the number of players. Players start with a hand of seven cards. On each turn
column7: a player draws two cards (from the deck or one or more of the discard piles)
column8: lays a card on the table as part of her arboretum
column9:
then discards a card to her personal discard pile.

When the deck is exhausted
column10: players compare the cards that remain in their hands to determine who can score each color. For each color
column11: the player(s) with the highest value of cards in hand of that color scores for a path of trees in her arboretum that begins and ends with that color; a path is a orthogonally adjacent chain of cards with increasing values. For each card in a path that scores
column12: the player earns one point; if the path consists solely of trees of the color being scored
column13: the player scores two points per card. If a player doesn't have the most value for a color
column14:
she scores zero points for a path that begins and ends with that color. Whoever has the most points wins.

column1: 341@Android@From the publisher: Android is a board game of murder and conspiracy set in a dystopian future. Detectives travel between the city of New Angeles and moon colony Heinlein chasing down leads
column2: calling in favors
column3: and uncovering the sinister conspiracy beneath it all. The detectives must balance their pursuit of the murderer against their personal lives and their inner demons. Android’s innovative mechanics ensure that no two detectives play alike. Will you play as Louis Blaine
column4: the crooked cop tormented by guilt and loss? Or will you take the role of Caprice Nisei
column5: the psychic clone who struggles to retain her sanity while proving that she’s as human as anyone else? Whoever you choose to play
column6: you’ve got just two weeks to solve the murder
column7: uncover the conspiracy
column8:
and face your personal demons.

During a round
column9: the players get action points to spend on various actions
column10: like moving their detectives
column11: following leads that appear on locations
column12: solving their personal demons
column13: or doing a location-specific action. In this way
column14: the detectives try to advance on three different sectors: solving the murder
column15: uncovering the conspiracy behind the murder
column16: and finding their inner peace. To solve the murder
column17: the detectives follow leads that appear on New Angeles and Heinlein
column18: and find evidence that they plant on the suspect of their choice. The conspiracy puzzle is also solved by following leads
column19: and may alter the way victory points are distributed at the end of the game. Finally
column20: each detective has his/her own personal plots that are resolved gradually throughout the game. If the detective invests enough time in the plot
column21: he/she will be awarded victory points; otherwise
column22:
he will suffer penalties.

The game ends when two in-game weeks (12 rounds) have passed. At that point
column23:
victory points are awarded based on the aforementioned sectors. The player with the most victory points is the winner.

342@Epic Spell Wars of the Battle Wizards: Duel at Mt. Skullzfyre@Game description from the publisher:

Did you know that magical wizards are battling to the death ... and beyond ... right now!? "Why battle?" you might ask. "What have I got to prove

column1: 343@Anomia@Anomia plays off the fact that our minds are positively brimming with all sorts of random information: things to eat
column2: pop songs
column3: websites
column4: etc... Sure
column5: under normal circumstances
column6: it's easy to give an example of a frozen food or a dog breed
column7:
but you'll find that your brain works a little differently under pressure!

To play
column8: draw and reveal a card from the center pile. Does the symbol on your card match one on another player's card? If so
column9: you must quickly face-off with the other player by giving an example of the person
column10: place
column11: or thing on their card before they can do the same for yours. If you blurt out a correct answer first
column12:
you win their card and the drawing continues.

Sounds simple
column13: right? Wrong! Wild cards allow non-matching symbols to match
column14: increasing the number of things to which you must pay attention. Cascading face-offs can occur when you hand over a lost card
column15:
thereby revealing a new top card on your play pile.

column1: 345@Container@Container is a game about big ships and big production.  Each player will play both as a producer and shipper of goods.  Players will decide which products they want to produce

column1: 347@Smartphone Inc.@In Smartphone Inc.
column2: you become a CEO of one of the largest smartphone-producing companies in the time when smartphones were only beginning to conquer the world. Research technologies
column3: develop your factory
column4: build your worldwide office network
column5:
and outprice your competitors to become the most profitable and successful smartphone company in the world.

Smartphone Inc. is an economic simulation Eurogame. Over five rounds
column6: players program their decisions about price
column7: production
column8: research
column9: and expansion. The game features a unique mechanism of planning
column10: which combines patching mechanisms with bidding and action selection. Each of the rounds consists of eight simple phases: planning
column11: pricing
column12: production
column13: development
column14: research
column15: expansion
column16: selling
column17:
and profits.

In the planning phase
column18:
all players simultaneously make decisions for the next year by overlaying ("patching") their two plan cards and all of their development tiles. The actions they plan on their cards and tiles in this phase will determine what actions they can perform during all of the later phases.

In the pricing phase
column19: players change the price they charge for their smartphones based on their plan. A lower price helps to go earlier and sell more smartphones on the market
column20: but a higher price
column21: while risky
column22:
helps players to earn more money.

In production
column23:
all players produce smartphones.

In development
column24: players take development tiles
column25:
which expand their planning possibilities in future rounds.

In research
column26: players discover new technologies. Each technology not only expands players' ability to sell smartphones to customers
column27:
but also gives them special powers they can use during the game.

In the expansion phase
column28: players open offices in neighbor regions
column29:
which allow them to sell in that region and develop their network of offices to more regions in further turns.

In the sale phase
column30: players sell the phones they produced in regions where they have offices. But there is limited space in each region - and if your price is too high
column31:
cheaper rivals can block you from selling.

In the profit phase
column32: players get income for their sales. Players gain the sale prices for all of their sold smartphones
column33:
and the player who sold the most phones in each region gains a bonus for controlling the accessory market. At the end of this phase all sold smartphones are discarded from the map - and a new round begins.

After five rounds

column1: 349@After The Virus@The zombie apocalypse is here! After The Virus is a cooperative deck builder in which you and your friends band together to survive and complete different missions. The 15 included missions form a storyline if played in sequence

column1: 350@Evolution@In Evolution
column2: players adapt their species in a dynamic ecosystem where food is scarce and predators lurk.  Traits like Hard Shell and Horns will protect your species from Carnivores
column3: while a Long Neck will help them get food that others cannot reach. With over 4
column4: 000 ways to evolve your species
column5:
every game becomes a different adventure.

Evolution packs a surprising amount of variety for a game with simple rules.  The variety comes from the synergies between the trait cards and from the different personalities at the table.  Some players thrive on creating Carnivores to wreak havoc on their fellow players.  Others prefer to stay protected and mind their own business.  Evolution encourages both play styles by giving each of them multiple paths to victory.  And it is the mix of play styles at the table that ultimately determines the ecosystem in which the players are adapting.  So gather your friends and see who can best adapt to the changing world around them.

"The theme of evolution is not just tacked on: it drives play." - Nature (the world's most prestigious scientific journal)  
Evolution was covered in the journal Nature.  The article was written by Stuart West
column6:
a Professor of Evolutionary Biology at the University of Oxford who has used Evolution in his undergraduate class.

column1: 352@In the Hall of the Mountain King@Play as trolls rebuilding your abandoned kingdom under the mountain in In the Hall of the Mountain King. With muscle and magic

and you'll spend carts to move them through the tunnels to prime scoring locations near the heart of the mountain.

A major aspect of the game is the cascading production. You begin with a line of four trolls

column10: stone

column13: carts
column14: runes
column15: and hammers — that it produces. When a new troll is hired

column1: 354@Tekhenu: Obelisk of the Sun@Four millennia ago on the eastern bank of the Nile river was laid the foundation of the Temple of Amun-Ra. Over the course of two thousand years

as you must balance your Pure and Tainted actions if you want to have a more favorable position in turn order.

column1: 359@Glory to Rome@In 64 A.D.
column2: a great fire originating from the slums of Rome quickly spreads to destroy much of the city
column3: including the imperial palace. Upon hearing news of the fire
column4: Emperor Nero Caesar races back to Rome from his private estate in Antium and sets up shelters for the displaced population.  Reporting directly to Nero
column5:
you are responsible for rebuilding the structures lost in the fire and restoring Glory to Rome.

Glory to Rome is a card-based city building and resource management game with a novel mechanism. Each card may act as a building
column6: a client
column7: a raw material
column8: or a valuable resource
column9: frequently forcing players into difficult decisions regarding how each card should be used. In addition
column10: much of the game is played from the discard pool
column11: giving players some control over what cards are accessible to opponents.  Actions are triggered by a form of card-driven role selection -- the active player leads a role
column12: and other players may follow if they discard a matching card from hand (to the pool).  Players who don't follow may 'think' to draw more cards.  There are thus strong interactions between the different uses of cards.  Scoring is a combination of completing buildings and storing resources
column13: with end-of-game bonuses for storing a diverse assortment. Game length is player-controlled
column14:
and is triggered in a few different ways.

and both have been the source of great controversy.  Many of the non-English editions use more conventional artwork.

column1: 361@Lewis & Clark: The Expedition@On November 30
column3:
the United States purchased Louisiana from Napoleon. U.S. President Thomas Jefferson decided to send two explorers – Meriwether Lewis and William Clark – to discover this huge terra incognita.

Lewis & Clark is a board game in which each player manages an expedition intended to cross the North American continent. Their goal is to be the first to reach the Pacific. Each one has his own Corps of Discovery that will be completed by the Native Americans and the trappers met during the journey. He has to cleverly manage his characters and also the resources he finds along the way. Beware
column4:
sometimes frugality is better than abundance.

Lewis & Clark features dual use cards. To be activated
column5: one card must be combined with another one
column6: which becomes unavailable for a while. Thus
column7: players are faced with a constant dilemma: play a card or sacrifice it. During the game
column8: each player acquires character cards that enlarge his hand
column9:
building a crew that gives him more options but it needs to be optimized as he will recycle his cards more slowly. This new "handbuilding" mechanism fits strongly with the historical background.

Since the aim of the game is to be the first on the Pacific coast
column10:
the timing and the opportunistic use of the other players' positions are crucial.

@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/IiJ1JK6AjlSCKsC8U_DqMw__original/img/4W8ffc5xOvC6sl660XMGCBqkzJ8=/0x0/filters:format(jpeg)/pic5375937.jpg@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/IiJ1JK6AjlSCKsC8U_DqMw__thumb/img/sRsfWxhyB9hPjkFVSE1y_W_AiP8=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic5375937.jpg@3.3352@120@1@5

column1: 362@Council of 4@The Empire
column2: formed by three Kingdoms
column3:
lives in an era of wealth and prosperity. Each Kingdom is governed by a council of four nobles. The members of six influential families sit around in the councils and lead the Kingdoms.

The players hold the roles of rich merchants who seek to obtain permits to build their own Emporium inside the cities of the three Kingdoms. Whoever takes more permits
column4: while also opening their Emporium in the best place
column5:
will be the most famous merchant and will win the game. But pay attention to the Emperor! He can be your ally and allow you to build without permits!

On a turn
column6:
a player can perform different actions:

- The main action is to corrupt a council
column7: which is represented by a slide with four pawns representing four nobles. By corrupting the three councilors of the three Kingdoms
column8: the player gets permit cards that give various instant and endgame benefits
column9:
and the possibility to build an Emporium in a specific city.

- Another action is to play a permission card to build an Emporium. Each Emporium earns the player the special benefits of the space where it's built
column10:
but also activates all connected emporiums in a chain effect.

- Corrupt the Emperor’s council to allow a player to build Emporiums without permission cards.

- Players can change the composition of a council.
There are many different ways to earn points:

- Build a connected Emporium in the cities that award points.

- Build your emporium in all the cities of an area of the board: the faster you complete the area
column11:
the more points you earn.

- Move up on the nobility’s track.

Obtain permits that give points.
Moreover
column12:
the board is modular and has eight possible combinations.

@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/1PVwotn_MXzaG8aRWJBwLw__original/img/FS68rLI2D1N9rWwC-L8Iijx_6Ck=/0x0/filters:format(png)/pic3252438.png@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/1PVwotn_MXzaG8aRWJBwLw__thumb/img/F8oR7WY_sXDfNAJKVmenGWQweQs=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic3252438.png@2.5909@75@2@4

column1: 363@Samurai@Samurai is set in medieval Japan. Players compete to gain the favor of three factions: samurai
column2: peasants
column3: and priests
column4: which are represented by helmet
column5: rice paddy
column6: and Buddha figures scattered about the board
column7: which features the islands of Japan. The competition is waged through the use of hexagonal tiles
column8: each of which help curry favor of one of the three factions — or all three at once! Players can make lightning-quick strikes with horseback ronin and ships or approach their conquests more methodically. As each figure (helmets
column9: rice paddies
column10: and Buddhas) is surrounded
column11:
it is awarded to the player who has gained the most favor with the corresponding group.

Gameplay continues until all the symbols of one type have been removed from the board or four figures have been removed from play due to a tie for influence.

At the end of the game
column12: players compare captured symbols of each type
column13: competing for majorities in each of the three types. Ties are not uncommon and are broken based on the number of other
column14:
"non-majority" symbols each player has collected.

The game is part of what is sometimes called the Knizia tile-laying trilogy.

@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/o9-sNXmFS_TLAb7ZlZ4dRA__original/img/TPKZgpNxB_C73RNbhKyP6UR76X0=/0x0/filters:format(jpeg)/pic3211873.jpg@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/o9-sNXmFS_TLAb7ZlZ4dRA__thumb/img/22MSUC0-ZWgwzhi_VKIbENJik1w=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic3211873.jpg@2.4813@60@2@4

column1: 364@Tiny Towns@You are the mayor of a tiny town in the forest in which the smaller creatures of the woods have created a civilization hidden away from predators. This new land is small and the resources are scarce
column2: so you take what you can get and never say no to building materials. Cleverly plan and construct a thriving town
column3:
and don't let it fill up with wasted resources! Whoever builds the most prosperous tiny town wins!

In Tiny Towns
column4: your town is represented by a 4x4 grid on which you will place resource cubes in specific layouts to construct buildings. Each building scores victory points (VPs) in a unique way. When no player can place any more resources or construct any buildings
column5: the game ends
column6:
and any squares without a building are worth -1 VP. The player with the most VP wins!

-description from publisher

@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/aE1EoOzr530gQin8bj8QDA__original/img/-GDAsvmQ3wkuHaZ8h9G5Gk_nvVA=/0x0/filters:format(jpeg)/pic4460401.jpg@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/aE1EoOzr530gQin8bj8QDA__thumb/img/AI-Ro3wLJtpyZLmCMNywOlpz0S8=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic4460401.jpg@2.045@60@1@6

column1: 365@Medina (Second Edition)@The year is 1822. After years of decay
column2: it is time to rebuild the medina
column3: located at the foot of the Atlas mountains. The architects and engineers of the city work to erect large and beautiful palaces and to renovate the damaged city wall. As the reconstruction of the old city progresses
column4: the city's inhabitants flock through the alleys
column5:
and the contours of the new city gradually reappear!

Each turn
column6: players must place two pieces on the board (except when allowed to skip this with a tea tile)
column7: either augmenting an existing building (or starting a new building if the current building of that color is finished)
column8: or expanding one of the other features of the city
column9: like the market or the walls. Each player will claim one building of each of the four colors by the end of the game
column10:
giving one point per wooden piece attached to the building.

Also
column11: if you own the largest building of a particular color you get a bonus for that color. Finally
column12: there are bonuses for palaces around the well
column13: as well as for the player who most recently connected one of their buildings to the walls
column14:
which grow from the four corners of the city.

Medina is a tense game by the great designer Stefan Dorra. This latest edition of the game features a double-sided game board (enabling a two-player game)
column15: almost 200 detailed wooden pieces
column16: and updated gameplay
column17:
as well as rules and components never before published for this game!

See Medina for the original edition of this game.

column1: 366@Penguin Party@After a long dark winter
column2: the sun is shining and it's party time for the penguins
column3: who celebrate by fishing. To look over the waters more easily
column4: the penguins build high pyramids. The more penguins you can fit in the pyramid
column5:
the better — but it's not that easy.

In Penguin Party
column6: players collectively build a pyramid of penguins
column7: trying to empty their hands of cards along the way. The deck consists of 36 penguin cards: 8 green and 7 each of red
column8: blue
column9: yellow
column10: and purple. Deal the deck out as evenly as possible
column11:
with the final card in a five-player game starting as the first card in the base of the pyramid.

On a turn
column12: you either play a card to the left or right of the base of the pyramid
column13: which can be at most eight cards wide
column14: or play a card on a higher level of the pyramid so long as it's supported by two penguins
column15: at least one of which is the same color as the card being played. If you cannot play a card
column16: discard your hand face down and take as many penalty markers as the number of cards you didn't play. If you empty your hand
column17:
you can return two penalty markers previously collected to the supply.

Play as many rounds as the number of players
column18: with each player starting one of the rounds. Whoever has the fewest penalty markers at the end of the game wins. (With two players
column19: deal each player 14 cards
column20: remove the other cards from play without looking at them
column21:
and build a pyramid with a base only seven cards wide.)

Admin note: This game looks very similar to Penguin
column22: but differs not only in components (being a card game while Penguin has 3D penguin tokens)
column23: but also in the number of colors and distribution. Penguin has four colors with nine pieces each
column24:
while this game has five colors with a distribution of 4x7 + 1x8.

@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/kZFrnOtLbeIztlI1RrD51w__original/img/F5Je4dOjkf_8rlE4Q98-fF146Uk=/0x0/filters:format(png)/pic7078447.png@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/kZFrnOtLbeIztlI1RrD51w__thumb/img/xfKHgZT98Sdqfd7YWNSWIpjUAg8=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic7078447.png@1.1375@15@2@6

column1: 367@Carpe Diem@The players slip into the role of rich patricians in ancient Rome. Everyone is trying to build a lucrative city district to score as many prestige points as possible. The novel way to get to the individual buildings of a district combined with a large variety of score cards make for an unusual game with a large number of strategies. From the successful designer
column2:
Stefan Feld.

@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/fsjopscDFCVArzU7fzhVxA__original/img/JJXwLsCeWj_8FOurLToKpdQuvpc=/0x0/filters:format(jpeg)/pic6183704.jpg@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/fsjopscDFCVArzU7fzhVxA__thumb/img/6Yu-lVdkDTrICD1y5ZqNmzHZEsc=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic6183704.jpg@2.524@75@2@4

column1: 368@Tokyo Highway@Note: This is for the 4-player version of Tokyo Highway. For the two player version
column2:
please go here: Tokyo Highway

In Tokyo Highway
column3:
players compete to place all of their cars on the road first — but to do that they have to build the roadways so that they have somewhere for their cars to go!

Over the course of the game
column4: players construct columns of varying heights by using the 88 squat gray and yellow pillars in the box
column5: then connect those columns with sticks that serve as roadways
column6: with the column you create usually not being the same height as the one it's connected to. When you place a highway that passes under or over an existing highway
column7: you get to (carefully!) place a car on that highway. Place a highway that both goes over and under other highways
column8:
and you can place two cars!

The yellow cylinders allow you to create a column the same height as another while also allowing you to fork the roadway to create more twists and turns.

The first player to place all ten of their cars — with or without using tweezers — wins!

This version of Tokyo Highway includes both the original base game and the expansion that allows for games with up to four players — not to mention four buildings that give additional obstacles while trying to lay down the concrete.

column1: 369@Railways of the World@Railways of the World (2009) is the new edition of the base game for Eagle Games' popular Railways of the World series
column2:
first published as Railroad Tycoon in 2005.  It reimplements the original game with several improvements.

Revisit the early days of the Age of Steam as you begin with a locomotive (the venerable John Bull
column3: the first locomotive to run in North America) and a vision (your Tycoon "mission" card). From there
column4: build your budding railroad network into a vast empire. Connect New York to Chicago
column5: earn the most money
column6:
develop bigger and faster locomotives and maybe even span North America and build the Transcontinental Railway!

Multiple expansions featuring different maps are available.  Railways of the World is the new base game for the system and includes the engine placards
column7: railroad tiles
column8: train tokens
column9: money
column10: bonds
column11: and other items that are needed in almost all the Railways of the World series. A gameboard depicting the eastern half of the United States is included in the base game
column12:
as well as a mounted map of Mexico.

This game is preceded by the designer's other Winsome train games: Age of Steam
column13: Australian Railways
column14: Volldampf
column15: New England Railways
column16: Veld Spoorweg
column17: Lancashire Railways
column18: and Ferrocarriles Pampas.  Railroad Tycoon was the result of a collaboration with Glenn Drover
column19: in which the mechanics and game-play of Martin Wallace's Age of Steam were simplified and streamlined and attractive over-produced components were added
column20:
in order to make Railroad Tycoon more appealing to less hardcore gamers and more accessible to a wider audience.

A revised reprint was published at the end of 2010 which made some component improvements
column21:
such as the addition of Railroad Operation cards for the Mexico map.

Complete series overview - The Railways of the World Series: Introducing the family members of the ideal medium-weight train game

Note: The RailRoad Tycoon board itself is gigantic (about 36x45 inches
column22:
91x114 cm) and requires a huge table or playing on the floor.

Similar to:

     Steam


@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/Sz0wLg3TgycpzSvSMdzRJA__original/img/vi7OckGr7HWbTGOkEyxgcCUIfiU=/0x0/filters:format(jpeg)/pic3869603.jpg@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/Sz0wLg3TgycpzSvSMdzRJA__thumb/img/lfoHFV0OafSO8boxKEX8V3Tq5TM=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic3869603.jpg@3.0183@120@2@6

column1: 370@Unearth@Long ago
column2: your ancestors built great cities across the world. Now your tribe must explore forests
column3: deserts
column4: islands
column5: mountains
column6: and caverns to find these lost cities. Claim the ruins
column7: build places of power
column8:
and restore the glory of a bygone age.

Unearth is a bend-your-luck game of dice placement and set collection. Designed by Jason Harner and Matthew Ransom
column9: it plays in under an hour with 2-4 players. Each player leads a tribe of Delvers
column10: represented by five dice (3 six-sided
column11: 1 four-sided
column12:
and 1 eight-sided). Players take turns rolling and placing dice in an attempt to claim Ruins.

The game's elegant core mechanic is accessible to players of all skill levels. High rolls help players claim Ruins
column13: while low rolls help players collect Stones. This opens two paths to victory: claiming sets of Ruins or using Stones to build Wonders. Delver cards help you affect your dice rolls or dice in play
column14:
and Wonders can grant abilities that impact the late game.

@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/0olGvNCDk-VmFW2LDOnI_Q__original/img/sugvsPhhLdQrUxD5SH970FN-Fuc=/0x0/filters:format(jpeg)/pic3579391.jpg@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/0olGvNCDk-VmFW2LDOnI_Q__thumb/img/3J2ogaftEzBzwUO3kyJ7DXH-3HE=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic3579391.jpg@1.9474@60@2@4

column1: 371@Sekigahara: The Unification of Japan@The battle of Sekigahara
column2: fought in 1600 at a crossroads in Japan
column3:
unified that nation under the Tokugawa family for more than 250 years.

Sekigahara allows you to re-contest that war as Ishida Mitsunari
column4: defender of a child heir
column5: or Tokugawa Ieyasu
column6:
Japan's most powerful daimyo (feudal lord).

The campaign lasted only 7 weeks
column7:
during which each side improvised an army and a strategy with what forces their allies could provide. Each leader harbored deep doubts as to the loyalty of his units - for good reason. Several daimyo refused to fight; some even turned sides in the midst of battle.

To conquer Japan you must do more than field an army - you must be sure it will follow you into combat. Cultivate the loyalty of your allies and deploy them only when you are confident of their allegiance. Win a battle by gaining a defection from the ranks of your opponent.

Sekigahara is replete with unusual mechanics:

        No dice are used
        Cards represent loyalty and motivation. Without a matching card
column8:
an army will not enter battle.
        Allegiance is represented by hand size
column9:
which fluctuates each turn.
        Battles are a series of deployments
column10: from hidden unit stacks
column11:
based on hidden loyalty factors. Loyalty Challenge cards create potential defection events.




Sekigahara is a 3-hour block game based on the Japanese campaign waged in 1600. The 7-week war
column12: fought along Japan's two major highways and in scattered sieges and backcountry skirmishes
column13:
elevated Tokugawa Ieyasu to Shogun and unified Japan for 265 years.

Sekigahara is designed to offer an historically authentic experience within an intuitive game mechanic that can be played in one sitting. Great effort has been taken to preserve a clean game mechanism. (Despite a healthy amount of historical detail
column14:
the ruleset is a brief 6 pages.) Chance takes the form of uncertainty and not luck.

No dice are used; combat is decided with cards. Blocks = armies and cards = motivation. The combination of army and motivation produces impact on the battlefield. Armies without matching cards don't fight. Battles resolve quickly
column15: but with suspense
column16: tactical participation
column17:
and a wide range of possible outcomes.

Legitimacy is represented by hand size
column18: which fluctuates each week according to the number of castles a player holds. Certain events deplete legitimacy
column19: like force marches and lost battles. Recruitment
column20: meanwhile
column21: is a function of a daimyo's control over key production areas. Objectives (enemy units
column22: castles
column23:
resources) exist all over the map.

The initial setup is variable
column24:
so the situation is always fresh. Concealed information (blocks and cards) lends additional uncertainty. In this way the game feels like the actual campaign.

Blocks are large and stackable. Every unit on the board is visible at once
column25: and the strategic situation is comprehensible at a glance. Components use authentic clan designations and colors
column26:
and have a Japanese feel.

True to history
column27: the objectives (castles and economic centers) and forces (armies of allied daimyo) are dispersed. Support for one front means neglect for another. The player is pulled between competing priorities. Each side wonders where his opponent wants to fight
column28:
and where he is unready. There is a great deal of bluff in the game.

Each player must rally the several daimyo of his coalition
column29: managing the morale and motivation of each clan. The forces are dispersed
column30: and while there are reasons to unify them
column32: and the timeframe compact
column33:
so skirmishing will occur all over the island.

TIME SCALE     1 week per 2-player turns
MAP SCALE     Point to point
UNIT SCALE     One block = 5000 soldiers
NUMBER OF PLAYERS     2

COMPONENTS
    Mounted Map
    119 wooden pieces
    1 and 1/2 sticker sheets
    110 cards
    Rulebook
    Two player aid cards

DESIGNER: Matthew Calkins
MAP

column1: 372@Pipeline@The refinement of oil has long been part of the government-controlled energy sector. Amassed with an incredibly complex and inefficient system of refineries
column2: the government has felt the severe pressures of worldwide demand and the ever-increasing global standards for refinement. Unable to keep up with demand
column3:
the government has only one option: privatizing the oil industry.

This is where you come in. Seeking to capitalize on this new opportunity
column4: in Pipeline you start a company in the oil business. You will focus on building a much more efficient pipeline network in your refinery
column5: hiring experts that provide valuable benefits over your competitors
column6:
and managing the logistics of purchasing and selling your refined oil in the various markets. You will need more than strong economic skills – carefully crafting an interweaving network of pipelines just might ensure your victory!

@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/x39hXnP-GkLN1CDEq932oA__original/img/dns582_OrWD9ZbABtUmXcQOxguQ=/0x0/filters:format(jpeg)/pic4227162.jpg@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/x39hXnP-GkLN1CDEq932oA__thumb/img/xxiGCk0hEUpP3hOtItpKI3sKZfo=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic4227162.jpg@3.887@120@2@4

column1:
373@Mandala@The Mandala: the symbol of an ancient and sacred ritual. Colored sand is laid to create a symbolic map of the world before the pattern is ceremonially destroyed and the sand cast into the river.

In the two-player game Mandala
column2: you are trying to score more than your opponent by collecting valuable cards — but you won't know which cards are valuable until well into the game! Over the course of the game
column3: players play their colored cards into the two mandalas
column4: building the central shared mountains and laying cards into their own fields. As soon as a mandala has all six colors
column5: the players take turns choosing the colors in the mountain and adding those cards to their "river" and "cup". At the end of the game
column6:
the cards in your cup are worth points based on the position of their colors in that player's river. The player whose cup is worth more points wins.

The linen playmat shows two circular mandalas
column7:
with each being divided by a horizontal space (the mountain) to create one "field" for each player. The playmat has seven spaces in front of each player to hold their river of single face-up cards and their cup: the stack of face-down cards which they score at the end of the game.

To begin
column8: each player receives a hand of six cards. Each player receives two random cards face down in their cup
column9:
then two random cards are dealt face up into the central mountain strip of each mandala.

On your turn
column10: you may play either a single card into one of mountains
column11: or one or more matching cards into one of your fields. All cards played into a mandala must follow the "Rule of Color": Once a color has been played into one of the three areas of a mandala
column12: then later cards of the same color can be played only into that same area. Thus
column13: once your opponent has played red cards into their field
column14: then you can't play red cards in your field
column15: and neither you nor your opponent can play red cards into the central mountain. If you played a card into a mountain
column16: draw three new cards from the deck at the end of your turn; if you played cards into one of your fields
column17:
do not draw new cards.

A mandala is completed once it contains all six colors of cards. When this happens
column18: the players "destroy" the mandala
column19: taking turns to choose a color present in the mountain and claim all cards of that color. Whoever played more cards in their field chooses first; if tied
column20: the player who did not complete the mandala chooses first. The first time you claim cards of a specific color
column21: lay one of these cards in the lowest-valued empty space in your river
column22: then place the rest into your cup. The spaces in your river are valued 1-6 in order
column23: so cards of the first color you claim will be worth 1 point each
column24: cards of the second color you claim worth 2 points each
column25:
and so on.

Once a mandala has been destroyed and all the colors in the mountain claimed
column26: cards played in the fields are discarded
column27: two new cards are dealt face up into the mountain
column28:
and the game continues.

The end of the game is triggered either when the deck is exhausted or when one player adds a sixth color to their river. Both players then tally the value of all the cards in their cup
column29: based on the position of the colors in their river
column30:
and whoever has the higher score wins!

Contents:

     1 linen playmat
     108 mandala cards (18 in each of 6 colours)
     2 reference cards


@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/FZUJ_Ieaw83mpz1eL-dY_g__original/img/FvjnGQH9SpkJ9_FB4frouPOe064=/0x0/filters:format(jpeg)/pic5056121.jpg@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/FZUJ_Ieaw83mpz1eL-dY_g__thumb/img/o8B080rjfGtNloX7wMa_IRthuXo=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic5056121.jpg@1.8105@20@2@2

column1: 374@The Princes of Florence@In The Princes of Florence
column2:
players attract artists and scholars to their palace while trying to become the most prestigious family in Florence.

Over seven rounds
column3: players attempt to score points in various ways
column4: with most points being earned by playing profession cards to generate "work points"
column5: which can be exchanged for money or victory points. The game includes a variety of professions
column6: such astronomers
column7: organists
column8: and architects; each profession is attracted to a particular combination of building
column9: landscape feature
column10: and social freedom
column11: and players acquire these items via auctions. The more that a player can match these preferences
column12: the more work points they earn — but the minimum requirement of work points increases each round
column13:
and you must meet that threshold in order to convert the work points.

column1: 375@Palm Island@Palm Island is a portable game that you can take with you anywhere. Sitting
column2: standing
column3: waiting
column4: riding
column5: flying
column6: relaxing
column7: alone
column8:
or together you can play Palm Island no table required.

Using a deck transforming mechanic a player uses just 17 cards over 8 rounds to shape their island and overcome its unique challenges. Store resources to pay for upgrades and upgrade buildings to access new abilities. Each decision you make will alter your village from round to round. At the end of 8 rounds calculate your victory points.

PLAY SOLO working to gain achievements and unlock new abilities to help your village reach even greater heights. PLAY COOPERATIVELY by working together to successfully prepare your village before natural disasters strike. PLAY COMPETITIVELY by racing to purchase bonuses
column9:
or in casual mode by meeting specific criteria before your opponent.

Add villagers to any game mode that you may recruit to your village and use their abilities to score more points than your opponent.
The game comes with 2 player decks
column10: competitive cards
column11:
cooperative cards and solo feat cards. Multiple games can be combined to add even more players.

column1:
376@Adventure Tactics: Domianne's Tower@SHARPEN YOUR SWORDS. READY YOUR SPELLS. GATHER YOUR ALLIES.

The ruthless Queen Domianne rules the kingdom of Astelia with an iron fist
column2: but an ancient prophecy has emerged which threatens her reign. The adventure starts in your humble village and eventually leads to the seat of Domianne's power
column3:
the peerless and ancient Tower of Greylock.

Adventure Tactics: Domianne's Tower is an encounter-based
column4: campaign-driven
column5: cooperative tactical combat game. Begin your journey as one of 5 Basic Classes and battle your way through a branching campaign where you choose your own path in an attempt to overthrow the evil Queen Domianne. With each encounter
column6: you will level up and unlock over 15 Elite Classes
column7: adding new actions
column8: equipment
column9:
and abilities.

Will your team find the right combination of Classes and powers in time to stop Queen Domianne? Let the adventure begin!

column1: 377@Tragedy Looper@Tragedy Looper is a scenario-based deduction game for two to four players: one mastermind and one to three protagonists. The game consists of four location boards and a number of character cards. Each scenario features a number of characters
column2: hidden roles for these characters (serial killer
column3: conspiracy theorist
column4: friend)
column5: and some pre-set tragedies (murder
column6:
suicide).

Each "day" (turn)
column7: players and the mastermind play three face-down cards onto the characters
column8: then reveal them to move the characters around or affect their paranoia or goodwill stats. At the end of each day (turn)
column9: if the scenario has a tragedy set for that day
column10: it happens if the conditions are met
column11: i.e.
column12: certain characters have certain stats or are in a certain location together (or not together) with others. As tragedies happen
column13: players loop back in time
column14:
restarting the scenario from the beginning and trying to deduce who the culprit was and why the tragedy occurred.

The players win if they manage to maintain status quo — that is
column15: if no tragedies occur to the key individuals — for a set number of days
column16: within a set number of loops. If not
column17:
the mastermind wins.

Tragedy Looper was originally released in Japan as æƒ¨åŠ‡RoopeR in 2011; the first english version of the game was released in 2014.

column1: 378@City of the Big Shoulders@After the great Chicago Fire of 1871
column2: the brave men and women of Chicago sought to rebuild their once-great city
column3: and rebuild it they did. Over the next 60 years Chicago experienced an economic golden age
column4: making such great progress that it hosted The World's Columbian Exposition in 1893
column5:
followed not long after by a celebration of its Century of Progress at The World's Fair in 1933.

Many of the household brands we've come to know and love today had their start in Chicago during this time period; Oscar Mayer
column6: Kraft
column7: Quaker Oats
column8: Nabisco
column9: Swift & Co
column10: Armour & Co
column11: Schwinn Bicycles
column12: Charles Schwab
column13: and many others made a home here in this tall
column14:
bold slugger.

In City of the Big Shoulders players take on the roles of entrepreneurs and investors seeking to rebuild Chicago into a city fit for the world stage. In this unique merger of 18xx-style stock manipulation mechanics with euro-style gameplay
column15: players start companies
column16: trade in shares
column17: hire employees
column18: equip their factories
column19:
produce goods and sell them to be delivered to homes across the midwest.

Although City of the Big Shoulders features a large amount of strategic depth and rewarding gameplay
column20: it does so in a shorter timeline than is typical of most heavy economic games. Players play just five rounds (also known as decades) in about two and a half hours. Each decade consists of five unique phases: A stock phase where players can buy and sell stock; a building phase where players rebuild the city of Chicago
column21: placing action spaces on the board; an action phase where companies send their partners to make deals across Chicago; an Operating Phase where companies buy resources
column22: produce goods
column23: and ship them out of Chicago; and finally a cleanup phase where the board is set up for the following decade. At the end of the fifth decade
column24: the game ends. Players then exchange shares that they have purchased over the course of the game for cash
column25: are rewarded for any of the public goals they have accomplished over the five decades of play
column26:
and tally their money to determine who is Chicago's greatest resident.

—description from the publisher

column1: 379@Dinosaur World@The triumph of science that led to dinosaurs returning to the world once more has become public knowledge. New parks spring up regularly
column2: often beginning operations even before everything has been finalized. There is no shortage of patrons eager to be entertained by these returned species in new and exciting ways. However
column3: as with any form of entertainment
column4:
elements of triumph are often accompanied by elements of tragedy. This means it is of the utmost importance that you take every precaution by ensuring each visitor signs the safety waiver before enjoying the wonders of Dinosaur World!

Each round in Dinosaur World
column5: you draft a new résumé card to acquire new workers; spend workers to take public actions building your park and acquiring DNA; spend further workers to take private actions improving that park; then drive your jeep around experiencing the wonder and excitement of what you have built! Throughout the game you acquire victory points through a variety of means — and possibly a few visitor deaths as a natural consequence of overly enthusiastic dinosaur encounters. At the end of the game
column6: you lose points if you accumulated too many deaths
column7:
then the player with the most points wins!

column1: 380@Wrfel Bohnanza@Würfel Bohnanza is
column2: as you might suspect
column3: a dice game in the Bohnanza family. Instead of cards
column4: dice give you the beans that you must use to satisfy orders and (eventually) collect "Bohnentalers" (i.e.
column5: dollars
column6: bucks
column7:
dinero...). The first player to collect thirteen Bohnentalers wins.

At the start of the game
column8: each player receives two order cards
column9: each of which shows six orders; the player tries to complete orders on one card while using the other to cover completed orders. The easiest orders to complete – say
column10: two specific bean types or three beans in any combination of two types – are at the bottom of the card
column11: and the hardest ones – requiring
column12: say
column13:
a four-of-a-kind or seven beans with no blue ones – are at the top. Orders must be completed from bottom to top.

On a turn
column14: the active player starts by rolling the seven bean dice
column15: three of which have one combination of beans and four of which have another combination. This player must set aside at least one bean
column16: then she rerolls any remaining dice
column17: setting at least one aside
column18: etc. After at most seven rolls
column19: she completes as many orders as she can
column20: reusing the dice as needed to complete orders. Once a player completes three orders
column21: she can "harvest" the card for one coin. Each additional completed order is worth a coin
column22: up to a maximum of four. When a player harvests the order card
column23:
she draws a new card and uses that to record completed orders (possibly on the same turn) on the order card she already had.

In the Bohnanza card game
column24: players trade cards to improve the standing of both parties involved in the trade. In Würfel Bohnanza
column25: the active player doesn't trade dice
column26: but opponents do get to benefit from that player's rolls. After each roll by the active player
column27: all other players can use the dice just rolled – and not dice already set aside – to complete orders on their own cards. Thus
column28:
the active player has some incentive not to dawdle too much with her rolls as her opponents might benefit from her turn more than she does.

The game ends as soon as one or more players have collected thirteen Bohnentalers. The player with the most Bohnentalers wins!

column1: 381@Ogre@OGRE and its sequel G.E.V. are tactical ground combat games set in the not-so-distant future. In 2085 A.D.

column3:

The basic OGRE game gives one player a force of infantry and armor
column4: and a command post he must defend. The other player has only one unit - but it's an OGRE. It's an even match. Advanced games allow solitaire or multi-player action
column5:
with OGREs on both sides.

Microgame #1 in the Metagaming Microgames series
column6:
and the original release of Ogre.  Origin of the Game: Ogre / G.E.V..


This is an entry on RPGG: 
GURPS Ogre  includes character and vehicle descriptions

a quick way to resolve battles involving player characters and get back to the roleplaying!
