column1: 382@Cinque Terre@The Cinque Terre are five coastal villages in the Liguria region of Italy known for their beauty
column2: culture
column3: food
column4:
and proximity to one another. Produce carts are commonly found in each village marketplace.

In Cinque Terre
column5: a game of strategy
column6: players compete to sell the most valuable produce in the five villages. Players act as farmers and operate a cart in which they will harvest produce and deliver them to the five villages to sell. Additionally
column7: players will compete for Produce Order cards
column8: which reward Lira points for selling desirable produce in specific villages. Players track sold produce in each village using their Fulfillment Cards. The winner is the player who gains the most Lire by selling valuable produce
column9: gaining popularity in the villages
column10:
and fulfilling Produce Orders.

				
				
					Game Set Up and Play

During setup in Cinque Terre
column11: colored dice are randomly pulled from a cloth bag and rolled to establish the prices each village will pay for select produce. Each player also begins play with a private order only she can fulfill. Five public orders are turned up that all players can work on
column12: though only the first player to fulfill each public order will score points for it. The Most Popular Vendor cards (1 for each village) are placed face up along one side of the board. The first player to fill an entire row with produce cubes for a particular village earns the Most Popular Vendor card for that village
column13:
which provides bonus points. Four Produce cards are turned face up and each player receives 4 to begin with along with a Fulfillment board and Produce Truck in their color.

On your turn
column14:
you can perform 3 actions in any order or combination you choose:


     Take a Produce Card - either a faceup card or one from the deck.
     Move your Produce Cart up four spaces clockwise around the board.
     Harvest produce from the location your cart is currently at. Each produce cube you wish to harvest requires a matching card. Two identical cards can be used in place of any one other card. Your cart can hold up to 4 produce cubes at a time.
     Deliver produce to a village. Unload the produce cubes you wish to deliver and place them in the appropriate spaces for that village on your fulfillment card.


At the end of your turn
column15: if you complete a public order or achieve Most Popular Vendor
column16: take the appropriate card
column17: scoring the points indicated. You can only complete one public order per turn. When you complete a public order
column18: you must draw a new card from the Order Deck. If you would like to keep that card as a private order
column19: add it to your hand and draw another and place it face up to replace the public order just completed. If you do not wish to keep the card you drew as a private order
column20:
place it face up instead. Any private orders not fultilled by game end count as negative points against you.

Players take turns taking their 3 actions until one player has completed 5 public orders (Most Popular Vendor Cards also count as public orders for determining game end)
column21: then everyone gets one more turn
column22:
including the player who caused the game to end.

column1: 383@Macao@At the end of the 17th century
column2: Macao – the mysterious port city on the southern coast of China – is a Portuguese trading post in the Far East. The players take on the role of energetic and daring adventurers. Many exciting tasks and challenges await the players
column3: whether they are a captain
column4: governor
column5: craftsman
column6:
or scholar. Those who chose the wisest course of action and have the best overall strategy will earn the most prestige at the end.

Macao lasts twelve rounds
column7: and in each round players select one new card from a display specific to that round
column8: two of which were revealed at the start of the game and others that were revealed only at the start of the round. The deck of 96 cards includes all sorts of special abilities
column9:
with the more powerful actions costing more resources to put into play.

One player rolls six different-colored dice
column10: then each player selects two of those dice (possibly the same ones chosen by opponents)
column11: then places cubes equal to the number and color of the two dice on a personalized "ship's wheel." For example
column12: if a player chooses the blue die that shows a 5
column13:
he places five blue cubes on the ship's wheel position five spots away from the current round. (A player can never claim more cubes than the number of remaining rounds).

Players rotate their ship's wheels each round
column14: then use the cubes available to them in that round to perform various actions: activating cards selected in that round or earlier rounds
column15: buying city quarters and collecting the goods located there
column16: moving that player's ship around Europe to deliver those goods
column17: acquiring gold coins
column18: taking special actions with card previously activated
column19:
and advancing on a turn order track.

Players score points by delivering goods
column20: paying gold coins
column21: using the powers on their cards
column22:
and building in Macao. Whoever has the most points at the end of twelve rounds wins.

Macao is number 13 in the alea big box series
column23:
with an estimated difficulty on the alea scale of 6/10.

column1: 386@Vindication@Vindication (formerly Epoch: The Awakening) is a highly strategic

column4: area control tactics

and Elementals.

column18:
and assassinate enemy troops.

and whoever ends the game with the most points wins.

column1: 390@Coffee Game@Coffee Game is a paper and pencil game where there will be all winners and one loser. The loser have to pay a coffee or whatever you want. ;-) A random player
column2: called the writer
column3:
write an hidden number from 1 to 999. The player on his left start the game calling a number from 1 to 999 trying to not guess the written number. The writer tell if the number is higher or lower to the written number. The next player have to call a number in the remain range trying to not guess the written number. The writer tell if the called number is higher or lower to the written number. The range will always be lower. If the turn come back to the writer he have to call a -2 or +2 from the last called number. Calls continue in clockwise order until a player guess the number. Who guess the number lost the game.
Example of play. 4 player A
column4: B
column5: C and D. A is the writer. A write 334 hidden. B have to call a number from 1 to 999. B call 562. Higher. C have to call a number from 1 to 562. C call 275. Lower. D have to call a number from 275 to 562. D call 499. Higher. A
column6: the writer
column7: have to call a -2 number from the last call (499). A call 497. Higher. B have to call a number from 275 to 497. B call 330. Lower. C have to call a number from 330 to 497. C call 399. Higher. D have to call a number from 330 to 399. D call 331. Lower. A
column8: the writer
column9:
have to call a +2 number from last called 331. A call 333. Lower. B have to call a number from 333 to 399. B call 340. Higher. C have to call a number from 333 to 340. C call 334. Guessed. C lost the game and have to pay a coffee.

column1: 392@Britannia@"Britannia" is a historical Strategic board-wargame that broadly depicts the millennia-long struggle for control of England
column2: Scotland
column3: and Wales. The game begins with the Roman invasion of 43 A.D.
column4: continues through the many struggles between Angles
column5: Saxons
column6: Picts
column7: Norsemen
column8: Scots
column9: Irish
column10: and other tribes
column11:
and ends with the Norman invasion of 1066.

Britannia allows players to re-create this epic history
column12: re-enacting important battles in some cases
column13: altering the course of history in others. The game rules discourage players from making historically unrealistic moves
column14: but also give players the freedom to alter Great Britain’s history in important ways
column15:
creating countless interesting “what if?” scenarios. What if Boudicca’s Revolt against the Romans had been more successful? What if the Romans and the Romano-British had repelled the Saxon invasions of the 5th and 6th centuries? What if William the Conqueror had died during the Norman invasion of 1066?

In Britannia
column16:
the players will determine the destiny of a kingdom.

column1: 393@Nations: The Dice Game@From the humble beginnings of civilization through the historical ages of progress
column2: mankind has lived
column3: fought and built together in nations. Great nations protect and provide for their own
column4: while fighting and competing against both other nations and nature itself. Nations must provide food as the population increases
column5: build a productive economy
column6:
and amaze the world with their great achievements to build up their heritage as the greatest nations in the history of mankind!

Nations: The Dice Game is a game for 1-4 players that takes 10-15 minutes per player and shares many concepts with the civilization-building game Nations while still offering its own challenges. The game is played over four ages (four rounds). During each round
column7:
players take turns until all have passed. The available actions are:


     Buy a tile
     Build a wonder
     Reroll some or all your dice


Buildings and military provide dice. Colonies and wonders provide resources and victory points. Advisors provide rerolls. New tiles provide benefits immediately
column8:
so you can roll new dice at once.

At the end of each round
column9: War and Famine drawn at the start of the round is checked for each player
column10: giving you victory points if you match or beat the values. Books are accumulated and scored. Player order is checked
column11: with high military strength going first in the next round. At the end of the game
column12:
whoever has the most victory points wins.

column1:
394@Poisson d'Avril@Don't Panic

East German game of Wizardry and Magic. Uses simultaneous action
column2: dynamic tension
column3: spells
column4: special powers
column5: line-of-sight and hidden identities in a peculiar mix that defies description but inspires awe in those who've experienced it. Feige Spiele's warehouse burnt down in early 1983
column6:
just before distribution of Willi Sonderling's masterpiece was to be shipped. Only a handful of reviewer copies survived.

Shortly thereafter there was a very small print run (fewer than a couple hundred) of the German version
column7: das Verschwinden.  In the mid to late 80s
column8:
the Starducks promotional version was released in certain regions of the United States.  (The Starducks version was released in two parts - a base game and expansion - but both parts are really needed to play the game.)

column1: 395@Steampunk Rally@Steampunk Rally is a strategy game that incorporates steampunk as more than just a bit of chrome. Using a unique dice-placement mechanism
column2: players take on the roles of famous inventors from the turn of the last century like Nikola Tesla and Marie Curie
column3: constructing fantastical contraptions that make use of steam
column4:
heat and electricity in an attempt to win a no-holds-barred race through the Swiss alps.

Each round starts with a card draft in which players carefully select machine parts to add to their invention and one-shot boost cards to aid them or hinder opponents. Players also have the option of discarding drafted cards for dice or cogs to power their invention
column5:
but they must make this tricky choice when each card is drafted.

Then
column6: after venting dice to revitalize their machines
column7: players roll their dice and use them to activate machine parts which provide things like movement
column8: shielding
column9: and additional dice with which to activate more parts. Driving through terrain causes damage
column10: and if a player's damage gauge ends up in the red at the end of the turn
column11: they must lose parts from their invention. These will need to be replaced in the draft phase
column12:
constantly forcing players to discover new synergies.

column1: 396@Mice and Mystics@In Mice and Mystics
column2: players take on the roles of those still loyal to the king – but to escape the clutches of Vanestra
column3: they have been turned into mice! Play as cunning field mice who must race through a castle now twenty times larger than before. The castle would be a dangerous place with Vanestra's minions in control
column4: but now countless other terrors also await heroes who are but the size of figs. Play as nimble Prince Collin and fence your way past your foes
column5: or try Nez Bellows
column6: the burly smith. Confound your foes as the wizened old mouse Maginos
column7: or protect your companions as Tilda
column8: the castle's former healer. Every player will have a vital role in the quest to warn the king
column9:
and it will take careful planning to find Vanestra's weakness and defeat her.

Mice and Mystics is a cooperative adventure game in which the players work together to save an imperiled kingdom. They will face countless adversaries such as rats
column10: cockroaches
column11: and spiders
column12: and of course the greatest of all horrors: the castle's housecat
column13: Brodie. Mice and Mystics is a boldly innovative game that thrusts players into an ever-changing
column14: interactive environment
column15: and features a rich storyline that the players help create as they play the game. The Cheese System allows players to hoard the crumbs of precious cheese they find on their journey
column16:
and use it to bolster their mice with grandiose new abilities and overcome seemingly insurmountable odds.

Mice and Mystics will provide any group of friends with an unforgettable adventure they will be talking about for years to come – assuming they can all squeak by...



Expansion advice:

        Heart of Glorm

and you must rely on others to take your romantic letters to her. Will yours reach her first?

Love Letter is a game of risk
column4: deduction
column5: and luck for 2–4 players. Your goal is to get your love letter into Princess Annette's hands while deflecting the letters from competing suitors. From a deck with only sixteen cards
column6: each player starts with only one card in hand; one card is removed from play. On a turn
column7: you draw one card
column8: and play one card

column1:
399@Dixit@2010 Spiel des Jahres Winner

One player is the storyteller for the turn and looks at the images on the 6 cards in her hand. From one of these
column2:
she makes up a sentence and says it out loud (without showing the card to the other players).

Each other player selects the card in their hands which best matches the sentence and gives the selected card to the storyteller
column3:
without showing it to the others.

The storyteller shuffles her card with all the received cards. All pictures are shown face up and every player has to bet upon which picture was the storyteller's.

If nobody or everybody finds the correct card
column4: the storyteller scores 0
column5:
and each of the other players scores 2. Otherwise the storyteller and whoever found the correct answer score 3. Players score 1 point for every vote for their own card.

The game ends when the deck is empty or if a player scores 30 points. In either case
column6:
the player with the most points wins the game.

The base game and all expansions have 84 cards each.

column1: 400@Friday@Friday

your peaceful times are disturbed. You must help Robinson to survive the island and prepare him to defeat the pirates that are coming for the island.

Friday is a solitaire deck-building game in which you optimize your deck of fight cards in order to defeat the hazards of the island. During a turn the player will attempt to defeat hazard cards by playing fight cards from their deck. If defeated
column6: a hazard card will become a fight card and is added to the player's deck. If failed
column7: the player will lose life points but also get the opportunity to remove unwanted cards from their fight deck. In the end
column8: the player will use their optimized fight deck to defeat the two pirate ships coming for the island
column9:
allowing Robinson Crusoe to escape the island and allowing you to finally have your peace back!

column1:
401@7 Wonders Duel@In many ways 7 Wonders Duel resembles its parent game 7 Wonders as over three ages players acquire cards that provide resources or advance their military or scientific development in order to develop a civilization and complete wonders.

What's different about 7 Wonders Duel is that
column2: as the title suggests
column3: the game is solely for two players
column4: with the players not drafting cards simultaneously from hands of cards
column5: but from a display of face-down and face-up cards arranged at the start of a round. A player can take a card only if it's not covered by any others
column6: so timing comes into play as well as bonus moves that allow you to take a second card immediately. As in the original game
column7: each card that you acquire can be built
column8: discarded for coins
column9:
or used to construct a wonder.

Each player starts with four wonder cards
column10: and the construction of a wonder provides its owner with a special ability. Only seven wonders can be built
column11: though
column12:
so one player will end up short.

Players can purchase resources at any time from the bank
column13: or they can gain cards during the game that provide them with resources for future building; as you acquire resources
column14: the cost for those particular resources increases for your opponent
column15:
representing your dominance in this area.

A player can win 7 Wonders Duel in one of three ways: each time you acquire a military card
column16: you advance the military marker toward your opponent's capital
column17: giving you a bonus at certain positions; if you reach the opponent's capital
column18: you win the game immediately; similarly
column19: if you acquire any six of seven different scientific symbols
column20: you achieve scientific dominance and win immediately; if none of these situations occurs
column21:
then the player with the most points at the end of the game wins.

column1: 402@Wingspan@Wingspan is a competitive
column2: medium-weight
column3: card-driven

column5: Natalia Rojas
column6:
and Ana Maria Martinez.

You are bird enthusiasts—researchers
column7: bird watchers
column8: ornithologists
column9:
and collectors—seeking to discover and attract the best birds to your network of wildlife preserves. Each bird extends a chain of powerful combinations in one of your habitats (actions). These habitats  focus on several key aspects of growth:

we think this game will take flight at your table.

column1: 403@Pandemic@In Pandemic
column2:
several virulent diseases have broken out simultaneously all over the world! The players are disease-fighting specialists whose mission is to treat disease hotspots while researching cures for each of four plagues before they get out of hand.

The game board depicts several major population centers on Earth. On each turn
column3: a player can use up to four actions to travel between cities
column4: treat infected populaces
column5: discover a cure
column6: or build a research station. A deck of cards provides the players with these abilities
column7: but sprinkled throughout this deck are Epidemic! cards that accelerate and intensify the diseases' activity. A second
column8:
separate deck of cards controls the "normal" spread of the infections.

Taking a unique role within the team
column9: players must plan their strategy to mesh with their specialists' strengths in order to conquer the diseases. For example
column10: the Operations Expert can build research stations which are needed to find cures for the diseases and which allow for greater mobility between cities; the Scientist needs only four cards of a particular disease to cure it instead of the normal five—but the diseases are spreading quickly and time is running out. If one or more diseases spreads beyond recovery or if too much time elapses
column11: the players all lose. If they cure the four diseases
column12:
they all win!

The 2013 edition of Pandemic includes two new characters—the Contingency Planner and the Quarantine Specialist—not available in earlier editions of the game.

Pandemic is the first game in the Pandemic series.

column1:
404@Shadows over Camelot@Shadows over Camelot is a cooperative/semi-cooperative hand-management and deduction-based board game for 3–7 players.

Each player represents a knight of the Round Table and they must collaborate to overcome a number of quests
column2:
ranging from defeating the Black Knight to the search for the Holy Grail. Completed quests place white swords on the Round Table; failed quests add black swords and/or siege engines around Camelot. The knights are trying to build a majority of white swords on the Table before Camelot falls.

On each knight's turn
column3: the knight takes a "heroic action"
column4: such as moving to a new quest
column5: building his hand
column6: or playing cards to advance the forces of good. However
column7: he must also choose one of three evil actions
column8:
each of which will bring Camelot closer to defeat.

Moreover
column9: one of the knights may be a traitor
column10: pretending to be a loyal member of the party but secretly hindering his fellow knights in subtle ways
column11: biding his time
column12:
waiting to strike at the worst possible moment...

But enough words... don your cloak
column13: climb astride your warhorse
column14:
and gallop into the Shadows to join us in Camelot!

@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/JYqwG_v1B3RhpB7NcmeDOA__original/img/_eAaG7PMaTcj1DpHbmUaOBTisoY=/0x0/filters:format(jpeg)/pic70547.jpg@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/JYqwG_v1B3RhpB7NcmeDOA__thumb/img/QOG1zO0uvqxGTDF9V_OewVPMvNE=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic70547.jpg@2.5668@80@3@7

column1: 405@Terraforming Mars@In the 2400s
column2: mankind begins to terraform the planet Mars. Giant corporations
column3: sponsored by the World Government on Earth
column4: initiate huge projects to raise the temperature
column5: the oxygen level
column6: and the ocean coverage until the environment is habitable. In Terraforming Mars
column7: you play one of those corporations and work together in the terraforming process
column8: but compete for getting victory points that are awarded not only for your contribution to the terraforming
column9: but also for advancing human infrastructure throughout the solar system
column10:
and doing other commendable things.

The players acquire unique project cards (from over two hundred different ones) by buying them to their hand. The projects (cards) can represent anything from introducing plant life or animals
column11: hurling asteroids at the surface
column12: building cities
column13: to mining the moons of Jupiter and establishing greenhouse gas industries to heat up the atmosphere. The cards can give you immediate bonuses
column14: as well as increasing your production of different resources. Many cards also have requirements and they become playable when the temperature
column15: oxygen
column16: or ocean coverage increases enough. Buying cards is costly
column17: so there is a balance between buying cards (3 megacredits per card) and actually playing them (which can cost anything between 0 to 41 megacredits
column18:
depending on the project). Standard Projects are always available to complement your cards.

Your basic income
column19: as well as your basic score
column20: is based on your Terraform Rating (starting at 20)
column21: which increases every time you raise one of the three global parameters. However
column22: your income is complemented with your production
column23:
and you also get VPs from many other sources.

Each player keeps track of their production and resources on their player boards
column24: and the game uses six types of resources: MegaCredits
column25: Steel
column26: Titanium
column27: Plants
column28: Energy
column29: and Heat. On the game board
column30: you compete for the best places for your city tiles
column32:
and greenery tiles. You also compete for different Milestones and Awards worth many VPs. Each round is called a generation (guess why) and consists of the following phases:

1) Player order shifts clockwise.
2) Research phase: All players buy cards from four privately drawn.
3) Action phase: Players take turns doing 1-2 actions from these options: Playing a card
column33: claiming a Milestone
column36: converting plant into greenery tiles (and raising oxygen)
column37: converting heat into a temperature raise
column38:
and using the action of a card in play. The turn continues around the table (sometimes several laps) until all players have passed.
4) Production phase: Players get resources according to their terraform rating and production parameters.

When the three global parameters (temperature
column40: ocean) have all reached their goal
column42:
and the game ends after that generation. Count your Terraform Rating and other VPs to determine the winning corporation!

column1: 406@Pandemic Legacy: Season 1@Pandemic Legacy is a co-operative campaign game
column2: with an overarching story-arc played through 12-24 sessions
column3: depending on how well your group does at the game. At the beginning
column4: the game starts very similar to basic Pandemic
column5: in which your team of disease-fighting specialists races against the clock to travel around the world
column6:
treating disease hotspots while researching cures for each of four plagues before they get out of hand.

During a player's turn
column7: they have four actions available
column8: with which they may travel around in the world in various ways (sometimes needing to discard a card)
column9: build structures like research stations
column10: treat diseases (removing one cube from the board; if all cubes of a color have been removed
column11: the disease has been eradicated)
column12: trade cards with other players
column13:
or find a cure for a disease (requiring five cards of the same color to be discarded while at a research station). Each player has a unique role with special abilities to help them at these actions.

After a player has taken their actions
column14: they draw two cards. These cards can include epidemic cards
column15: which will place new disease cubes on the board
column16: and can lead to an outbreak
column17: spreading disease cubes even further. Outbreaks additionally increase the panic level of a city
column18:
making that city more expensive to travel to.

Each month in the game
column19: you have two chances to achieve that month's objectives. If you succeed
column20: you win and immediately move on to the next month. If you fail
column21: you have a second chance
column22:
with more funding for beneficial event cards.

During the campaign
column23: new rules and components will be introduced. These will sometimes require you to permanently alter the components of the game; this includes writing on cards
column24: ripping up cards
column25: and placing permanent stickers on components. Your characters can gain new skills
column26: or detrimental effects. A character can even be lost entirely
column27:
at which point it's no longer available for play.

Part of the Pandemic series

@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/-Qer2BBPG7qGGDu6KcVDIw__original/img/PlzAH7swN1nsFxOXbfUvE3TkE5w=/0x0/filters:format(png)/pic2452831.png@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/-Qer2BBPG7qGGDu6KcVDIw__thumb/img/NQQcjS31TO0DE246N9rpt0hd9eo=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic2452831.png@2.8311@60@2@4

column1: 407@Twilight Struggle@"Now the trumpet summons us again
column2: not as a call to bear arms
column3: though arms we need; not as a call to battle
column4:
though embattled we are – but a call to bear the burden of a long twilight struggle..."
– John F. Kennedy

In 1945
column5: unlikely allies toppled Hitler's war machine
column6: while humanity's most devastating weapons forced the Japanese Empire to its knees in a storm of fire. Where once there stood many great powers
column7: there then stood only two. The world had scant months to sigh its collective relief before a new conflict threatened. Unlike the titanic struggles of the preceding decades
column8: this conflict would be waged not primarily by soldiers and tanks
column9: but by spies and politicians
column10: scientists and intellectuals
column11: artists and traitors. Twilight Struggle is a two-player game simulating the forty-five year  dance of intrigue
column12: prestige
column13: and occasional flares of warfare between the Soviet Union and the United States. The entire world is the stage on which these two titans fight to make the world safe for their own ideologies and ways of life. The game begins amidst the ruins of Europe as the two new "superpowers" scramble over the wreckage of the Second World War
column14: and ends in 1989
column15:
when only the United States remained standing.

Twilight Struggle inherits its fundamental systems from the card-driven classics We the People and Hannibal: Rome vs. Carthage. It is a quick-playing
column16: low-complexity game in that tradition. The game map is a world map of the period
column17: whereon players move units and exert influence in attempts to gain allies and control for their superpower. As with GMT's other card-driven games
column18:
decision-making is a challenge; how to best use one's cards and units given consistently limited resources?

Twilight Struggle's Event cards add detail and flavor to the game. They cover a vast array of historical happenings
column19: from the Arab-Israeli conflicts of 1948 and 1967
column20: to Vietnam and the U.S. peace movement
column21: to the Cuban Missile Crisis and other such incidents that brought the world to the brink of nuclear annihilation. Subsystems capture the prestige-laden Space Race as well as nuclear tensions
column22:
with the possibility of game-ending nuclear war.

Components (original edition):


     228 full colour counters 
     22"x34" full colour map 
     103 event cards 
     2 six-sided dice
     1 24-page rulebook
     2 full colour player aid cards


Components (2009 Deluxe edition and after)

     260 full colour counters 
     22"x34" mounted map with revised graphics
     110 event cards
     2 six-sided dice
     1 24-page rulebook
     2 full colour player aid cards


TIME SCALE:     approx. 3-5 years per turn
MAP SCALE:     Point-to-point system
UNIT SCALE:     Influence markers
NUMBER OF PLAYERS:     2

DESIGNER: Ananda Gupta & Jason Matthews
MAP
column23: CARD
column24:
& COUNTER ART: Mark Simonitch


A deluxe edition
column25:
published in 2009 includes the following changes from the basic game:

     Mounted map with revised graphics
     Two double-thick counter sheets with 260 counters
     Deck of 110 event cards (increased from 103)
     Revised rules and player aid cards
     Revised at start setup and text change for card #98 Aldrich Ames


Upgrade kit for the owners of the previous version includes the following:

     Mounted Map with revised graphics
     New card decks
     Updated Rules & Charts

column1:
408@A Game of Thrones: The Board Game (Second Edition)@Game description from the publisher:

King Robert Baratheon is dead
column2:
and the lands of Westeros brace for battle.

In the second edition of A Game of Thrones: The Board Game
column3: three to six players take on the roles of the great Houses of the Seven Kingdoms of Westeros
column4: as they vie for control of the Iron Throne through the use of diplomacy and warfare. Based on the best-selling A Song of Ice and Fire series of fantasy novels by George R.R. Martin
column5: A Game of Thrones is an epic board game in which it will take more than military might to win. Will you take power through force
column6: use honeyed words to coerce your way onto the throne
column7: or rally the townsfolk to your side? Through strategic planning
column8: masterful diplomacy
column9: and clever card play
column10:
spread your influence over Westeros!

To begin the game
column11: each player receives an army of Footman
column12: Knight
column13: Siege Engine
column14: and Ship units
column15: as well as a set of Order tokens and other necessary components. Each player also receives a deck of unique House Cards
column16:
which are used as leaders in battles against rival Houses.

Each round in the game is made up of three phases: the Westeros Phase
column17: the Planning Phase
column18: and the Action Phase. The Westeros Phase represents special events and day-to-day activities in Westeros. There are three different Westeros Decks
column19: and each denotes a different global action
column20:
potentially affecting all players.

The Planning Phase is perhaps the most important. Here you secretly assign orders to all of your units by placing one order token face down on each area you control that contains at least one unit (Knight
column21: Footman
column22: Ship
column23: or Siege Engine). This portion of the game emphasizes diplomacy and deduction. Can you trust the alliance that you made? Will you betray your ally and march upon him? Players may make promises to each other (for aid or peace
column24: for example)
column25: but these promises are never binding. The result is tense and compelling negotiations
column26:
often ending in backstabbing worthy of Westeros!

During the Action Phase
column27: the orders are resolved and battle is entered! When armies meet in combat
column28: they secretly choose one of their House cards to add strength to the battle. Finally
column29:
the Houses can consolidate their power in the areas they control and use that power in future turns to influence their position in the court of the Iron Throne and to stand against the wildling Hordes.

In addition to featuring updated graphics and a clarified ruleset
column30: this second edition of A Game of Thrones includes elements from the A Clash of Kings and A Storm of Swords expansions
column32: garrisons
column33: Wildling cards
column35:
while introducing welcome new innovations like player screens and Tides of Battle cards.

Tides of Battle cards are an optional mechanism that brings an element of unpredictability to combat
column36: representing erratic shifts in the momentum of war due to factors such as weather
column38: and tactical opportunity. During each combat
column39: both players draw one Tides of Battle card from a communal deck
column40: and its value modifies the strength of his chosen House card. What's more
column41:
such a card may also contain icons that can affect the outcome of the battle...all of which delivers a new level of intensity to your military engagements.

Expanded by:

     A Game of Thrones: The Board Game (Second Edition) â€“ A Dance with Dragons (2012)
     A Game of Thrones: The Board Game (Second Edition) â€“ A Feast for Crows (2013)
     A Game of Thrones: The Board Game (Second Edition) â€“ Mother of Dragons (2018)


Reimplements:

     A Game of Thrones (2003)
     A Game of Thrones: A Clash of Kings Expansion (2004)
     A Game of Thrones: A Storm of Swords Expansion (2006)

column1: 409@Through the Ages: A New Story of Civilization@Through the Ages: A New Story of Civilization is the new edition of Through the Ages: A Story of Civilization
column2:
with many changes small and large to the game's cards over its three ages and extensive changes to how military works.

Through the Ages is a civilization building game. Each player attempts to build the best civilization through careful resource management
column3: discovering new technologies
column4: electing the right leaders
column5:
building wonders and maintaining a strong military. Weakness in any area can be exploited by your opponents. The game takes place throughout the ages beginning in the age of antiquity and ending in the modern age.

One of the primary mechanisms in TTA is card drafting. Technologies
column6: wonders
column7: and leaders come into play and become easier to draft the longer they are in play. In order to use a technology you will need enough science to discover it
column8: enough food to create a population to man it and enough resources (ore) to build the building to use it. While balancing the resources needed to advance your technology you also need to build a military. Military is built in the same way as civilian buildings. Players that have a weak military will be preyed upon by other players. There is no map in the game so you cannot lose territory
column9: but players with higher military will steal resources
column10: science
column11: kill leaders
column12: take population or culture. It is very difficult to win with a large military
column13:
but it is very easy to lose because of a weak one.

Victory is achieved by the player whose nation has the most culture at the end of the modern age.

@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/fVwPntkJKgaEo0rIC0RwpA__original/img/1jawNpljTXwnT4km_2CjGwoUPR8=/0x0/filters:format(jpeg)/pic2663291.jpg@https://cf.geekdo-images.com/fVwPntkJKgaEo0rIC0RwpA__thumb/img/31usGlzlBReEFf60bcgbvDTjwCg=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic2663291.jpg@4.4246@120@2@4

column1: 410@Gaia Project@Gaia Project is a new game in the line of Terra Mystica. As in the original Terra Mystica
column2: fourteen different factions live on seven different kinds of planets
column3: and each faction is bound to their own home planets
column4: so to develop and grow
column5: they must terraform neighboring planets into their home environments in competition with the other groups. In addition
column6: Gaia planets can be used by all factions for colonization
column7:
and Transdimensional planets can be changed into Gaia planets.

All factions can improve their skills in six different areas of development — Terraforming
column8: Navigation
column9: Artificial Intelligence
column10: Gaiaforming
column11: Economy
column12: Research — leading to advanced technology and special bonuses. To do all of that
column13:
each group has special skills and abilities.

The playing area is made of ten sectors
column14:
allowing a variable set-up and thus an even bigger replay value than its predecessor Terra Mystica. A two-player game is hosted on seven sectors.

—description from the publisher
